{"uri": "8115952058", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:49:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:49:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:42:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13392413/John-Swinney-pledges-I-new-job-First-Minister.html", "title": "John Swinney pledges to 'give everything I have\u00b4 to new job as...", "body": "John Swinney said it was an \"extraordinary privilege\" to become Scotland's new first minister as he pledged to \"give everything I have\" to the role.\n\nHe spoke out after winning a vote at Holyrood that will see him become the seventh person to be first minister since the Scottish Parliament was established.\n\nHe is now expected to be formally sworn into the position on Wednesday.\n\nMr Swinney became the new leader of the SNP unopposed on Monday - with this happening a week after his predecessor Humza Yousaf announced he was stepping down after his decision to rip up the powersharing deal the party had with the Scottish Greens at Holyrood, leaving him facing a motion of no confidence in his leadership.\n\nFaced with a vote he was unlikely to win, Mr Yousaf announced he would instead quit, formally tendering his resignation to the King on Tuesday.\n\nIn a vote at Holyrood, Mr Swinney won the backing of 64 MSPs, with his nearest rival Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross picking up 31.\n\nHumza Yousaf tendered his resignation to the King on Tuesday, paving the way for John Swinney to succeed him. (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nScottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar secured 22 votes, with the head of the Scottish Liberal Democrats, Alex Cole-Hamilton, winning four.\n\nThe seven Scottish Green MSPs abstained.\n\nWith Mr Swinney leading a minority government at Holyrood, he will have to work with other parties to pass legislation and the Scottish Budget - and after the vote, he shook hands with opposition leaders in the chamber at the Scottish Parliament.\n\nI am here to serve you. I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country. John Swinney\n\nHe did so after conceding he would need to \"reach out to others to make things happen, to pass legislation, to agree a budget\".\n\nMr Swinney told the other parties at Holyrood: \"If we want to fund our schools and hospitals, if we want to give our businesses a competitive edge, if we want to take climate action, if we want to eradicate child poverty, if we want to change people's lives for the better, we have got to work together to do so.\"\n\nBut he said he would \"give all of my energy and my willingness\" to achieve this, committing to be \"the first minister for everyone in Scotland\".\n\nMr Swinney told Scots: \"I am here to serve you. I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country.\"\n\nWith his family watching from the gallery at Holyrood, he thanked his wife Elizabeth, who has multiple sclerosis, making clear his \"profound eternal gratitude\" to her for \"the sacrifices she is prepared to make\" so he could take on the job.\n\nHe told how it was \"something of a surprise\" to be the next first minister, as he had believed his time in government was over when he stepped down as deputy to Nicola Sturgeon last year.\n\nMr Swinney added: \"It is however an extraordinary privilege and it is my honour to accept the office of first minister, committing myself to do the best I can for Scotland.\"\n\nScottish Secretary Alister Jack congratulated Mr Swinney on his election, as he urged the new first minister to \"prioritise the issues that really matter to people in Scotland, like improving failing public services and growing our economy\".\n\nMr Jack added: \"I want him to work constructively with the UK Government on our joint projects to boost Scotland's prosperity - including freeports, city deals and investment zones.\n\n\"Most of all, I hope that Mr Swinney will govern for the whole of Scotland. He needs to put aside his obsession with independence, and concentrate on contributing to a thriving Scotland within a strong United Kingdom.\"", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": {"uri": "8115978483", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:05:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:05:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:02:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/john-swinney-pledges-everything-job-161654299.html", "title": "John Swinney pledges to 'give everything I have' to new job as First Minister", "body": "John Swinney said it was an \"extraordinary privilege\" to become Scotland's new first minister as he pledged to \"give everything I have\" to the role.\n\nHe spoke out after winning a vote at Holyrood that will see him become the seventh person to be first minister since the Scottish Parliament was established.\n\nHe is now expected to be formally sworn into the position on Wednesday.\n\nMr Swinney became the new leader of the SNP unopposed on Monday - with this happening a week after his predecessor Humza Yousaf announced he was stepping down after his decision to rip up the powersharing deal the party had with the Scottish Greens at Holyrood, leaving him facing a motion of no confidence in his leadership.\n\nFaced with a vote he was unlikely to win, Mr Yousaf announced he would instead quit, formally tendering his resignation to the King on Tuesday.\n\nIn a vote at Holyrood, Mr Swinney won the backing of 64 MSPs, with his nearest rival Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross picking up 31.\n\nScottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar secured 22 votes, with the head of the Scottish Liberal Democrats, Alex Cole-Hamilton, winning four.\n\nThe seven Scottish Green MSPs abstained.\n\nWith Mr Swinney leading a minority government at Holyrood, he will have to work with other parties to pass legislation and the Scottish Budget - and after the vote, he shook hands with opposition leaders in the chamber at the Scottish Parliament.\n\nHe did so after conceding he would need to \"reach out to others to make things happen, to pass legislation, to agree a budget\".\n\nMr Swinney told the other parties at Holyrood: \"If we want to fund our schools and hospitals, if we want to give our businesses a competitive edge, if we want to take climate action, if we want to eradicate child poverty, if we want to change people's lives for the better, we have got to work together to do so.\"\n\nBut he said he would \"give all of my energy and my willingness\" to achieve this, committing to be \"the first minister for everyone in Scotland\".\n\nMr Swinney told Scots: \"I am here to serve you. I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country.\"\n\nWith his family watching from the gallery at Holyrood, he thanked his wife Elizabeth, who has multiple sclerosis, making clear his \"profound eternal gratitude\" to her for \"the sacrifices she is prepared to make\" so he could take on the job.\n\nHe told how it was \"something of a surprise\" to be the next first minister, as he had believed his time in government was over when he stepped down as deputy to Nicola Sturgeon last year.\n\nMr Swinney added: \"It is however an extraordinary privilege and it is my honour to accept the office of first minister, committing myself to do the best I can for Scotland.\"\n\nScottish Secretary Alister Jack congratulated Mr Swinney on his election, as he urged the new first minister to \"prioritise the issues that really matter to people in Scotland, like improving failing public services and growing our economy\".\n\nMr Jack added: \"I want him to work constructively with the UK Government on our joint projects to boost Scotland's prosperity - including freeports, city deals and investment zones.\n\n\"Most of all, I hope that Mr Swinney will govern for the whole of Scotland. He needs to put aside his obsession with independence, and concentrate on contributing to a thriving Scotland within a strong United Kingdom.\"\n\nScottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross said the SNP had previously looked to the \"extreme Greens\" for policies, while at the same time \"continuing the push for the same old tired campaign for independence and a referendum\".\n\nMr Ross said Mr Swinney must \"swiftly change course\" from that and \"deliver a bold new policy agenda\".\n\nHe urged the new SNP leader to rule out \"any agreement, by the backdoor or otherwise\" with the Scottish Greens, with the Tory telling Mr Swinney: \"If he wants to lead a government that represents the values of the clear majority of our country, he cannot be reliant on the Greens for his agenda.\"\n\nUrging him also to put independence \"on the backburner\", Mr Ross continued: \"The First Minister and his party must treat today as a reset moment - they must bring an end to a decade of division that has plagued our country since the 2014 referendum.\"\n\nScottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar said Scotland needed a \"change of direction\" rather than just a change of leader.\n\nMr Sarwar said: \"I hope we see a new approach from John Swinney, one that genuinely puts the national interest before party interest.\"\n\nStressing the need to \"get on with fixing the mess of the last 17 years\" of SNP government, the Labour MSP added that \"that change can only come with an election\".", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], He voiced 'profound and eternal gratitude' that she was willing to make sacrifices so he could serve Scotland.\n\nAttention will now turn to his Cabinet, with questions over whether Kate Forbes will be handed the key post as his deputy amid tensions over her devout Christian views. Appointments will happen after he is sworn in tomorrow.\n\nDespite swipes that he is a 'Sturgeon apologist' and 'continuity' option, Mr Swinney was the only SNP leadership candidate running when nominations closed yesterday.\n\nHe managed to convince former finance secretary Ms Forbes to join his team rather than challenge him, in a move billed a 'stitch-up' by opponents.\n\nJohn Swinney is set to be installed as Scottish First Minister after being confirmed as the new SNP leader yesterday\n\nIn a valedictory speech at Holyrood this afternoon, Humza Yousaf thanked colleagues who had shown him 'kindness' amid the 'toxic nature of our political debate'\n\nHumza Yousaf officially quit as Scottish First minister today paving the way for John Swinney to be installed within hours\n\nMr Swinney won the backing of 64 MSPs, with his nearest rival Scottish Conservatives leader Douglas Ross picking up 31. As the Greens abstained that was enough for a simple majority.\n\nPitching for the role in the chamber, Mr Swinney said: 'I hope we can all recognise that despite our political differences, we're all here because we want the best for Scotland, whatever our specific role happens to be.\n\n'For me, it is with all my experience - but with much more than that - with my burning ambition for a better future for this country, that I am seeking to become first minister.'\n\nHe said his 'core belief' is that 'Scottish self-government is the right way forward for Scotland'.\n\nHe pledged to listen to those who voted for pro-independence parties in 2021 as well as those who did not.\n\nMr Yousaf said in his final speech: 'Let me offer thanks to every single colleague across the political divide for the kindnesses that you have shown me over the years.\n\n'We often, and I'm guilty of this too, lament the toxic nature of our political debate and it's true, there is entrenched tribalism that feels difficult to free ourselves from.\n\n'However I will remember far more fondly the kindness and generosity of colleagues over the years.'\n\nMr Swinney swerved a late obstacle yesterday as he persuaded activist Graeme McCormick not to go ahead with forcing a leadership contest, even though he had secured the support required to stand.\n\nIn his victory speech in Glasgow yesterday, Mr Swinney acknowledged the scale of the infighting and crises which have engulfed the SNP and admitted the party has been through a 'rough, tough time'.\n\nBut he claimed that his party has now 'come back together again' under his leadership and 'got our act together'.\n\nScottish Tory leader Douglas Ross said Mr Swinney would just 'double down on the independence obsession' rather than tackling Scotland's problems.\n\n'It's difficult to see how he can be the fresh start Scotland needs, when he's the ultimate continuity candidate,' he said.\n\n'John Swinney was joined at the hip with the disgraced Nicola Sturgeon and his fingerprints are all over her numerous policy failures and cover-ups.\n\n'The stitch-up the SNP have engineered to ensure John Swinney's coronation highlights the mess they're in.\n\n'Is a failed former leader from two decades ago - who, as education secretary, sent Scotland plummeting down international league tables - really the best they have to offer?\n\nMr Yousaf's time as First Minister was spent dealing with a long list of crises, including developments in the police probe into the SNP's funding and finances, a series of policy U-turns, disciplinary issues, defections and bitter infighting between factions in his party.\n\nIn his speech yesterday, Mr Swinney claimed the speedy leadership process can allow the SNP to 'get back on the front foot'.\n\nA Norstat poll at the weekend showed the SNP is on course to fall to just 15 seats following the general election, and to slide behind Labour at the next Holyrood election.\n\nThe SNP vote share in a Westminster election was seen as dropping to its lowest level since the 2014 independence referendum.\n\nThe party would hold just 15 of its 43 seats with Scottish Labour winning 28 - a dramatic increase from its current two.\n\nMr Swinney was the only nominee for SNP leader after he persuaded former Finance Secretary Kate Forbes (pictured) to join his team rather than challenge him\n\nMr Yousaf's fall from grace was sparked when he summarily ditched the coalition deal with the Greens in Scotland\n\nMr Yousaf signed his resignation letter to the King as the transition takes effect\n\nAccording to the Sunday Times survey, the SNP had support from 29 per cent of the electorate - a fall of three points in a month, while Labour's share increased by two points to 34 per cent.\n\nUnder Nicola Sturgeon, the SNP became the third largest party at Westminster, winning 56 of 59 Scottish seats in 2015.\n\nThe Scottish Conservatives, whose vote share remained at 16 per cent in the poll, would add three seats to return nine MPs - while the Liberal Democrats, on 8 per cent, would boost their yield by one to five MPs.\n\nScottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar said: 'John Swinney's coronation is entirely about managing the SNP rather than running our country.\n\n'At a time when Scotland is crying out for change, the SNP is offering more of the same.'", "source": with this happening a week after his predecessor Humza Yousaf announced he was stepping down after his decision to rip up the powersharing deal the party had with the Scottish Greens at Holyrood, leaving him facing a motion of no confidence in his leadership.\n\nFaced with a vote he was unlikely to win, Mr Yousaf announced he would instead quit, formally tendering his resignation to the King on Tuesday.\n\nIn a vote at Holyrood, Mr Swinney won the backing of 64 MSPs, with his nearest rival Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross picking up 31.\n\nScottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar secured 22 votes, with the head of the Scottish Liberal Democrats, Alex Cole-Hamilton, winning four.\n\nThe seven Scottish Green MSPs abstained.\n\nWith Mr Swinney leading a minority government at Holyrood, he will have to work with other parties to pass legislation and the Scottish Budget - and after the vote, he shook hands with opposition leaders in the chamber at the Scottish Parliament.\n\nHe did so after conceding he would need to \"reach out to others to make things happen, to pass legislation, to agree a budget\".\n\nMr Swinney told the other parties at Holyrood: \"If we want to fund our schools and hospitals, if we want to give our businesses a competitive edge, if we want to take climate action, if we want to eradicate child poverty, if we want to change people's lives for the better, we have got to work together to do so.\"\n\nBut he said he would \"give all of my energy and my willingness\" to achieve this, committing to be \"the first minister for everyone in Scotland\".\n\nMr Swinney told Scots: \"I am here to serve you. I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country.\"\n\nWith his family watching from the gallery at Holyrood, he thanked his wife Elizabeth, who has multiple sclerosis, making clear his \"profound eternal gratitude\" to her for \"the sacrifices she is prepared to make\" so he could take on the job.\n\nHe told how it was \"something of a surprise\" to be the next first minister, as he had believed his time in government was over when he stepped down as deputy to Nicola Sturgeon last year.\n\nMr Swinney added: \"It is however an extraordinary privilege and it is my honour to accept the office of first minister, committing myself to do the best I can for Scotland.\"\n\nScottish Secretary Alister Jack congratulated Mr Swinney on his election, as he urged the new first minister to \"prioritise the issues that really matter to people in Scotland, like improving failing public services and growing our economy\".\n\nMr Jack added: \"I want him to work constructively with the UK Government on our joint projects to boost Scotland's prosperity - including freeports, city deals and investment zones.\n\n\"Most of all, I hope that Mr Swinney will govern for the whole of Scotland. {"uri": "2024-05-348966532", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:02:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:02:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T09:50:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.rocketnews.com/2024/05/john-swinney-sworn-in-as-scotlands-first-minister/", "title": "John Swinney sworn in as Scotland's first minister", "body": "PA MediaBy James Cook & Mary McCoolBBC News SNP leader John Swinney has been sworn in as the seventh first minister of Scotland.He was confirmed in the role during a brief, formal ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh.Mr Swinney takes office 25 years after he was first elected to the Scottish Parliament. The first minister is now expected to appoint his cabinet, in a series of meetings at his official residence, Bute House.His appointments will be confirmed in parliament on Thursday.Big tensions remain in SNP as John Swinney takes leadershipWill John Swinney change the SNP's fortunes?After the ceremony, Mr Swinney, 60, told reporters it was an \"enormous privilege\", but said it had been a \"very abrupt\" change for his family.\"It's an extraordinary opportunity to change lives for the better and I intend to use every moment that is available to me to do so,\" he said.He vowed his minority SNP administration government would seek to work collaboratively across parliament, with a particular focus on eradicating the \"curse\" of child poverty. Last week he promised a senior role to the former finance secretary Kate Forbes, who declined to challenge him for the leadership of the SNP.The ceremony to install Mr Swinney as first minister was overseen by Scotland's senior judge, Lord Carloway.The Perthshire North MSP swore the oath of office, declared his allegiance to the King and was confirmed as keeper of the Scottish Seal.He confirmed his appointment by putting pen to parchment on a table in the well of the court, Scotland's supreme body for civil law since 1532. PA MediaMr Swinney won the nomination for first minister in a parliamentary vote on Tuesday.He was backed by all 63 SNP MSPs and Alba's sole Holyrood representative, Ash Regan. Seven Green MSPs abstained, guaranteeing Mr Swinney the required majority.Following a tumultuous two weeks for the SNP, Mr Swinney became party leader on Monday.A contest was narrowly avoided, with a rival candidate - veteran SNP activist Graeme McCormick - withdrawing his bid at the 11th hour. This paved the way for Humza Yousaf to formally resign as first minister on Tuesday - a move prompted by his tearing up of the power-sharing agreement with the Scottish Greens. He had been in post for just over a year, having taken over the role from Nicola Sturgeon.Jane BarlowMr Swinney has 16 years' cabinet experience and led the SNP between 2000 and 2004.He will take office in the week the Scottish Parliament marks 25 years since devolution.Previously, he said he would not be an \"interim leader\" or a \"caretaker\" and that he intended to see out a full term.He has said he will seek to govern on a \"moderate centre left\" platform, and will be open to working with any other political party in the parliament to pass legislation.This was reflected in his speech to MSPs on Tuesday in which he struck a conciliatory note, praising the achievements of other major parties in the devolved parliament.This video can not be playedTo play this video you need to enable JavaScript in your browser.He pledged to be the \"first minister for everyone in Scotland\", adding: \"I am here to serve you, I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country.\"The economy, the NHS and other public services, and \"a drive to lift children out of poverty\" are his priorities for government.While Ms Forbes is expected to make a return to cabinet but it is unclear where other ministerial roles will be allocated.PA MediaIt is also not clear which roles Mr Swinney will keep, though The Times previously reported he intended to have a \"slimmed-down\" government.Having confirmed he has no intention of resurrecting a deal with the Greens, Mr Swinney will attempt to pass a budget and other key bills with a minority administration of 63 MSPs.Until recently Mr Swinney's career on the frontbenches looked to be over.He stepped down from the cabinet in 2023 after 16 years in key roles under both Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon.Following the collapse of the Bute House Agreement, and Mr Yousaf's resignation, Mr Swinney was publicly urged to stand for first minister by senior party members - which he said he accepted out of a \"profound sense of duty\".The SNP leader said the decision had been made with his family, expressing \"eternal gratitude\" to his wife Elizabeth Quigley, who has multiple sclerosis and relies on him for {"uri": "2024-05-347995805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:25:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:25:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:19:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/05/07/john-swinney-pledges-to-give-everything-i-have-to-new-job-as-first-minister/", "title": "John Swinney pledges to 'give everything I have' to new job as First Minister", "body": "The SNP leader won a vote that will see him become the seventh person to become First Minister since 1999.\n\nJohn Swinney said it was an \"extraordinary privilege\" to become Scotland's new first minister as he pledged to \"give everything I have\" to the role.\n\nHe spoke out after winning a vote at Holyrood that will see him become the seventh person to be first minister since the Scottish Parliament was established.\n\nHe is now expected to be formally sworn into the position on Wednesday.\n\nMr Swinney became the new leader of the SNP unopposed on Monday - with this happening a week after his predecessor Humza Yousaf announced he was stepping down after his decision to rip up the powersharing deal the party had with the Scottish Greens at Holyrood, leaving him facing a motion of no confidence in his leadership.\n\nFaced with a vote he was unlikely to win, Mr Yousaf announced he would instead quit, formally tendering his resignation to the King on Tuesday.\n\nIn a vote at Holyrood, Mr Swinney won the backing of 64 MSPs, with his nearest rival Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross picking up 31.\n\nThe seven Scottish Green MSPs abstained.\n\nWith Mr Swinney leading a minority government at Holyrood, he will have to work with other parties to pass legislation and the Scottish Budget - and after the vote, he shook hands with opposition leaders in the chamber at the Scottish Parliament.\n\nMr Swinney told the other parties at Holyrood: \"If we want to fund our schools and hospitals, if we want to give our businesses a competitive edge, if we want to take climate action, if we want to eradicate child poverty, if we want to change people's lives for the better, we have got to work together to do so.\"\n\nBut he said he would \"give all of my energy and my willingness\" to achieve this, committing to be \"the first minister for everyone in Scotland\".\n\nMr Swinney told Scots: \"I am here to serve you. I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country.\"\n\nWith his family watching from the gallery at Holyrood, he thanked his wife Elizabeth, who has multiple sclerosis, making clear his \"profound eternal gratitude\" to her for \"the sacrifices she is prepared to make\" so he could take on the job.\n\nHe told how it was \"something of a surprise\" to be the next first minister, as he had believed his time in government was over when he stepped down as deputy to Nicola Sturgeon last year.\n\nMr Swinney added: \"It is however an extraordinary privilege and it is my honour to accept the office of first minister, committing myself to do the best I can for Scotland.\"\n\nScottish Secretary Alister Jack congratulated Mr Swinney on his election, as he urged the new first minister to \"prioritise the issues that really matter to people in Scotland, like improving failing public services and growing our economy\".\n\nMr Jack added: \"I want him to work constructively with the UK Government on our joint projects to boost Scotland's prosperity - including freeports, city deals and investment zones.\n\n\"Most of all, I hope that Mr Swinney will govern for the whole of Scotland. He needs to put aside his obsession with independence, and concentrate on contributing to a thriving Scotland within a strong United Kingdom.\"", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8116134258", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "19:11:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T19:11:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T19:10:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/world/uk/2024/05/07/scotlands-new-first-minister-promises-to-reach-out-to-opposition/", "title": "Scotland's new first minister promises to reach out to opposition", "body": "John Swinney's erstwhile SNP leadership rival Kate Forbes is expected to be brought back into the cabinet\n\nJohn Swinney will be sworn in as Scotland's new first minister on Wednesday after his nomination passed a vote on Tuesday of the members of the devolved parliament in Holyrood.\n\nMr Swinney, who replaces Humza Yousaf, became the new leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP) on Monday after no other candidates entered the race to succeed the outgoing leader, who quit last week in advance of a confidence vote called by the opposition.\n\nOn Tuesday, Mr Yousaf sent his formal resignation to Britain's King Charles, following which Mr Swinney was nominated as his successor.\n\nThe leaders in Scotland of the three unionist parties in Holyrood, the Conservatives, Labour and the Liberal Democrats, all put themselves forward to be first minister in a vote in parliament. Although the SNP is two seats short of a majority, Mr Swinney emerged with the most votes, clearing the way for his formal appointment at the Court of Session in Edinburgh on Wednesday morning.\n\nAttention will shift in the afternoon to the cabinet reshuffle that Mr Swinney is expected to implement. Kate Forbes, the former finance secretary who has sat on the backbenches since losing a bitter leadership contest with Mr Yousaf last year, is expected to return to a frontline role.\n\nMs Forbes, a social conservative who is also seen as one of the most capable politicians in the party, was widely viewed as Mr Swinney's biggest rival for the leadership when Mr Yousaf quit. She considered making a leadership bid during a period of high drama in Scottish politics last week, but decided to stand aside and back Mr Swinney after talks between the two. He has promised her a \"significant role\" in his government.\n\nMr Swinney, a party veteran who was previously SNP leader two decades ago, has promised to unite the party after a fractious 14 months since the resignation of former leader Nicola Sturgeon, who has since become embroiled in a financial scandal. After 17 years in power, the SNP's support has also slipped in the polls with Labour resurgent north of the Scottish border with England.\n\nIn a Holyrood speech during the debate to confirm his nomination as first minister, Mr Swinney acknowledged that as leader of a minority administration, he will need to \"reach out to others to make things happen\".\n\nHe praised Labour and the Liberal Democrats on Tuesday for their governance of Scotland during the early years of devolution in the late 1990s and early 2000s. He also praised the Conservative Party for its role in opposition.\n\nIn a sign that Alex Salmond's nationalist Alba party may also be prepared to back him on certain issues, it appeared its sole member of parliament, Ash Regan, voted for Mr Swinney in the first minister vote.\n\nMr Yousaf ended the SNP's previous government arrangement with the Scottish Greens, whom many in the SNP blame for dragging the government to the left with policies unpopular with some voters. The Scottish Greens abstained in the vote for first minister, but indicated they may back Mr Swinney on individual policies on a case-by-case basis.", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-05-349374262", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:15:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:15:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:11:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/kate-forbes-gets-scotland-deputy-181120030.html", "title": "Kate Forbes gets Scotland's Deputy First Minister job after agreeing not to contest SNP leadership", "body": "John Swinney has appointed Kate Forbes as Scotland's Deputy First Minister after she extracted a high price for agreeing not to stand against him for the SNP leadership.\n\nMr Swinney made Ms Forbes his deputy and Economy Secretary in his new Cabinet, giving her responsibility for fixing poor relations between the SNP and Scotland's business community.\n\nHowever, he made no other major changes to the Cabinet he inherited from Humza Yousaf, his predecessor, despite a series of debacles that has raised concerns about its competence.\n\nMs Forbes, 34, is the youngest ever Deputy First Minister after she agreed to give Mr Swinney a clear run for the SNP leadership during face-to-face talks last week. His allies were desperate to avoid a contest following the sudden resignation of Mr Yousaf.\n\nHer appointment was also intended to signal that Mr Swinney is serious about trying to drag the SNP back to the political centre ground after the end of its power-sharing agreement with the hard-Left Greens.\n\nMs Forbes has previously expressed \"significant concerns\" about the SNP-Green coalition's self-ID gender reforms, environmental policies and income tax hikes.\n\nBut the Scottish Tories said that, apart from Ms Forbes, Mr Swinney had unveiled \"Humza Yousaf's Cabinet with a different figurehead\". They said her appointment was intended to \"gloss over the huge splits in the SNP.\"\n\nThe Greens also reacted with hostility to Ms Forbes's appointment. Patrick Harvie, their co-leader and a minister in Mr Yousaf's government, posted on social media a picture of a road sign stating \"No right turn\".\n\nImmensely talented politician\n\nMr Swinney announced his Cabinet after being sworn in as First Minister at the Court of Session in Edinburgh, with Ms Forbes the first SNP MSP to arrive at his Bute House official residence.\n\nAs the most powerful member of Mr Swinney's administration, other than the First Minister himself, she is in pole position to succeed him if the 60-year-old stands down after the 2026 Scottish Parliament election.\n\nHe said: \"I am very pleased to appoint Kate as Deputy First Minister and look forward to working with her in this new government.\n\n\"She is an immensely talented politician, and her new role will prove critical as we focus on our key commitments of eradicating child poverty, investing in public services and supporting economic growth.\"\n\nA devout Christian, she triggered uproar in last year's SNP leadership contest with Mr Yousaf when she expressed opposition to gay marriage and children being born out of wedlock.\n\nMr Swinney questioned at the time whether her views made her \"an appropriate individual to be SNP leader and first minister.\"\n\nBut he rejected the Green accusations that Ms Forbes' appointment as his deputy meant he had lurched to the Right, saying the SNP would remain a Centre-Left party.\n\nSpeaking alongside Ms Forbes outside Bute House, he also denied that LGBT Scots should be concerned, saying he would be \"the First Minister for everyone\".\n\nShona Robison had earlier resigned as Deputy First Minister, writing to Mr Swinney that Ms Forbes should have the post \"to unite the party behind your leadership.\"\n\nHowever, she retained her position as Finance Secretary despite widespread hostility to this year's Scottish Budget, in which she introduced a sixth income tax band.\n\nMr Swinney also kept Jenny Gilruth at education, Neil Gray at health, Angela Constance at justice, Mairi McAllan at net zero and energy, Fiona Hyslop at transport and Shirley-Anne Somerville at social justice.\n\nIn addition, Angus Robertson remained Constitution and Culture Secretary and Mairi Gougeon Rural Affairs Secretary after serving in the same posts in Mr Yousaf's crisis-hit government.\n\nMr Swinney said he had \"selected a Cabinet team that blends experience and energy, with a strong focus on the priorities my government will pursue - eradicating child poverty, driving economic growth, meeting climate obligations and investing in our vital public services\".\n\nMs Forbes said: \"I am deeply honoured to accept John's invitation to be his Deputy First Minister.\n\nMore of the same\n\n\"This is a moment of extraordinary privilege for me. Having previously served in Cabinet, I know the duty that all Ministers have to reflect the government's priorities and the missions that drive them.\"\n\nShe will also take on responsibility for Gaelic.\n\nBut Craig Hoy, the Scottish Tory chairman, said: \"This uninspiring cabinet is further evidence that John Swinney as First Minister will just mean more of the same.\"\n\nJackie Baillie, Scottish Labour's deputy leader, said: \"After 17 years of failure, every single institution in Scotland is now weaker and those responsible remain at the heart of government.\n\n\"This is a continuity Cabinet that cannot be trusted to fix the chaos and instability they have created.\"\n\nMr Harvie said: \"There will be many people across our country who will be very concerned and who will want to know that this Scottish Government remains committed to a greener and more equal future for Scotland.\"\n\nMr Swinney also had a phone call with the Prime Minister in which he pledged to \"work constructively with the UK Government in a good-faith effort to deliver for the people of Scotland and reduce polarisation in politics\".\n\nA Scottish Government spokesman said: \"The First Minister made clear that the Scottish Government will continue to respectfully persuade people in Scotland of the case for independence, and that the decision on Scotland's future should be for the Minister", "body": "John Swinney, Scotland National Party leader and Scottish First Minister\n\nA 60-year-old Scottish politician, John Swinney has been legally sworn in as Scotland's seventh first minister on Wednesday.\n\nHis swearing in was followed by Humza Yousaf's signing of a letter to the King tendering his resignation as Scotland's first minister after.\n\nYousaf resigned after John Swinney was elected as the Scotland National Party, SNP's new leader.\n\nLast week, Yousaf, who was sworn in on March 29, 2023, said he \"paid the price\" for the way he ended the power-sharing deal with the Scottish Greens.\n\nIn his letter to King Charles, the Glasgow Pollok MSP said his resignation would take effect from the start of parliamentary business on Tuesday.\n\n\"Throughout my time as first minister, I have been most grateful for your counsel and the kindness you have shown to both Nadia and I,\" Yousaf wrote in his letter to the King.\n\nTaking over from the 39-year-old, Swinney is now Keeper of the Scottish Seal, also known as the Great Seal, after taking the oath of office and pledging his allegiance to the King, British media reported.\n\nThe seal allows the monarch to authorise official documents without having to sign each one.\n\nAs Keeper of the Scottish Seal, Swinney has been given the authority to make decisions on behalf of the crown, which effectively means he can lead the country with the support of the Scottish parliament.\n\nThe ceremony took place at the Court of Session in Edinburgh in front of Scotland's most senior judge, the Lord President Lord Carloway.\n\nSwinney's family, including his wife Elizabeth, brother David, and 13-year-old son Matthew, accompanied him to court.\n\nSpeaking to reporters after the ceremony, Swinney said taking the oaths had been an \"overwhelming moment\" as he spoke of his pride at being first minister and his family's support.\n\n\"I look forward to dedicating my future to serving the people of Scotland. It's an extraordinary opportunity to change lives for the better and I'll continue to use every moment that's available to me to do so,\" he said.\n\n\"For my family this is a very abrupt change of our circumstances. We didn't think this would happening about 10 days ago,\" he added.\n\nSwinney, who was deputy first minister under Nicola Sturgeon, previously said he is \"no interim leader\" and intends to lead the SNP beyond the next general and Scottish elections.\n\nHe has vowed to focus on the economy, jobs, the cost of living, the NHS, education, public services, and the climate crisis.\n\nAddressing the opposition, he said, \"If we want to fund our schools and hospitals, if we want to give our businesses a competitive edge, if we want to take climate action, if we want to eradicate child poverty, if "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13391951/John-Swinney-installed-Scottish-Minister-Humza-Yousaf-officially-quits-Sturgeon-apologist-make-Kate-Forbes-deputy-despite-clashes-devout-Christian-views.html", "title": "John Swinney is installed as Scottish First Minister after SNP chaos", "body": "John Swinney was officially installed as Scottish First Minister today after Humza Yousaf quit.\n\nThe new SNP leader was elected to the post in a Holyrood vote, with the Greens ensuring he could not be blocked.\n\nThe confirmation came hours after Mr Yousaf signed his resignation letter to the King, and gave a valedictory speech slamming 'bigots'.\n\nMr Swinney becomes the third holder of the top role in barely a year.\n\nAttention will now turn to his Cabinet, with questions of whether Kate Forbes will be handed the key post as his deputy amid tensions over her devout Christian views.\n\nDespite swipes that he is a 'Sturgeon apologist' and 'continuity' option, Mr Swinney was the only candidate running when nominations closed yesterday.\n\nHe managed to convince former finance secretary Kate Forbes to join his team rather than challenge him, in a move billed a 'stitch-up' by opponents.\n\nJohn Swinney is set to be installed as Scottish First Minister after being confirmed as the new SNP leader yesterday\n\nIn a valedictory speech at Holyrood this afternoon, Humza Yousaf thanked colleagues who had shown him 'kindness' amid the 'toxic nature of our political debate'\n\nHumza Yousaf officially quit as Scottish First minister today paving the way for John Swinney to be installed within hours\n\nMr Yousaf signed his resignation letter to the King as the transition takes effect\n\nMr Yousaf's fall from grace was sparked when he summarily ditched the coalition deal with the Greens in Scotland\n\nMr Yousaf said in his final speech: 'Let me offer thanks to every single colleague across the political divide for the kindnesses that you have shown me over the years.\n\n'We often, and I'm guilty of this too, lament the toxic nature of our political debate and it's true, there is entrenched tribalism that feels difficult to free ourselves from.\n\n'However I will remember far more fondly the kindness and generosity of colleagues over the years.'\n\nMr Swinney swerved a late obstacle yesterday as he persuaded activist Graeme McCormick not to go ahead with forcing a leadership contest, even though he had secured the support required to stand.\n\nIn his victory speech in Glasgow yesterday, Mr Swinney acknowledged the scale of the infighting and crises which have engulfed the SNP and admitted the party has been through a 'rough, tough time'.\n\nBut he claimed that his party has now 'come back together again' under his leadership and 'got our act together'.\n\nScottish Tory leader Douglas Ross said Mr Swinney would just 'double down on the independence obsession' rather than tackling Scotland's problems.\n\n'It's difficult to see how he can be the fresh start Scotland needs, when he's the ultimate continuity candidate,' he said.\n\n'John Swinney was joined at the hip with the disgraced Nicola Sturgeon and his fingerprints are all over her numerous policy failures and cover-ups.\n\n'The stitch-up the SNP have engineered to ensure John Swinney's coronation highlights the mess they're in.\n\n'Is a failed former leader from two decades ago - who, as education secretary, sent Scotland plummeting down international league tables - really the best they have to offer?\n\nMr Yousaf's time as First Minister was spent dealing with a long list of crises, including developments in the police probe into the SNP's funding and finances, a series of policy U-turns, disciplinary issues, defections and bitter infighting between factions in his party.\n\nIn his speech yesterday, Mr Swinney claimed the speedy leadership process can allow the SNP to 'get back on the front foot'.\n\nA Norstat poll at the weekend showed the SNP is on course to fall to just 15 seats following the general election, and to slide behind Labour at the next Holyrood election.\n\nThe SNP vote share in a Westminster election was seen as dropping to its lowest level since the 2014 independence referendum.\n\nThe party would hold just 15 of its 43 seats with Scottish Labour winning 28 - a dramatic increase from its current two.\n\nMr Swinney was the only nominee after he persuaded former Finance Secretary Kate Forbes (pictured) to join his team rather than challenge him\n\nAccording to the Sunday Times survey, the SNP had support from 29 per cent of the electorate - a fall of three points in a month, while Labour's share increased by two points to 34 per cent.\n\nUnder Nicola Sturgeon, the SNP became the third largest party at Westminster, winning 56 of 59 Scottish seats in 2015.\n\nThe Scottish Conservatives, whose vote share remained at 16 per cent in the poll, would add three seats to return nine MPs - while the Liberal Democrats, on 8 per cent, would boost their yield by one to five MPs.\n\nScottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar said: 'John Swinney's coronation is entirely about managing the SNP rather than running our country.\n\n'At a a man of unfailing courtesy who served my party but also this parliament and country with distinction.\"\n\nThe veteran SNP politician pledged to bring his party back to the \"moderate, centre-left\" and said he would focus on the economy, jobs and the cost of living.\n\nIt's his second term as SNP leader after taking on the job between 2000 and 2004.\n\nHe is the longest-serving SNP parliamentarian, having served in Holyrood since its opening in 1999.\n\nHe has been a senior government minister every year since the SNP came to power in 2007 until his resignation as deputy first minister alongside Nicola Sturgeon in 2023.\n\nHe was Alex Salmond's finance secretary throughout his entire premiership and continued the role into Sturgeon's time as first minister before becoming education secretary.\n\nHe was also the longest-serving deputy first minister in Scottish history with nine years in government alongside Sturgeon.\n\nHe becomes SNP leader and First Minister at a difficult time for his party and Government.\n\nPolice Scotland's investigation into SNP's funding and finances is ongoing, with the force charging former chief executive Peter Murrell - Sturgeon's husband - with embezzlement of party funds last month.\n\nSturgeon and former treasurer Colin Beattie were arrested last year but released without charge, pending further investigations.\n\nHe also enters Bute House - the official residence of Scotland's devolved leader - at a time when polling suggests the SNP could lose seats at the next election to Scottish Labour.\n\nSwinney's party has been declining in both Westminster and Holyrood polls. minister after Holyrood vote", "body": "John Swinney will become Scotland's new first minister after being backed by a majority of MSPs.\n\nFollowing his victory in the SNP leadership race on Monday, the 60-year-old faced a vote at Holyrood to confirm him as Humza Yousaf's successor.\n\nThe Scottish Greens abstained from the vote, with Mr Swinney able to fend off challenges from Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar, and Scottish Liberal Democrats leader Alex Cole-Hamilton.\n\nHis name will now be submitted to the King, with an official swearing-in ceremony expected to take place at the Court of Session in Edinburgh as early as Wednesday.\n\nMr Swinney will then be able to appoint his cabinet.\n\nMr Yousaf was forced to step down last week in the face of two votes of no confidence after terminating the power-sharing Bute House Agreement with the Scottish Greens.\n\nDuring his final speech as first minister, Mr Yousaf said his heart would \"forever belong to Scotland\" as he told how leading his country had given him the opportunity to defy \"racist bigots\".\n\nHe said: \"Young Humza Yousaf could never have imagined he would be able to lead this country.\n\n\"I was six-years-old when I was first told to go home, and I am afraid since then it has been a regular occurrence - in fact, almost daily if you look at my social media feeds.\"\n\nHe said that \"racial slur\" had hurt him most \"simply because I have no other home than this one, I never will, I never have\".\n\nMr Yousaf continued: \"My heart will forever belong to Scotland.\n\n\"So, to have the opportunity to defy the far-right, to defy the racist bigots who told me to go home, to be in a position to serve my home, to contribute to public life in my home, and to have the opportunity to lead my home - that has been the most tremendous honour that I didn't think was reserved for people who looked like me.\"\n\nMr Swinney was unopposed in the SNP leadership contest and promised a \"new chapter\" for the party as he pledged to use \"respect and courtesy\" to make the case for Scottish independence.\n\nRead more:\n\nWho is John Swinney?\n\nFormer finance secretary Kate Forbes had been tipped to join the race, but instead threw her support behind him.\n\nMr Swinney previously said he would want Ms Forbes to \"play a significant part\" in his government if elected.\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Listen above then tap here to follow the Sky News Daily wherever you get your podcasts \ud83d\udc48\n\nResponding to questions after his post-win speech on Monday, Mr Swinney confirmed he will not be reinstating the Bute House Agreement with the Scottish Greens, preferring to take issues on a case-by-case basis.\n\nBefore the vote took place for a new first minister, the Scottish Greens announced its MSPs would be abstaining.\n\nParty co-leader Lorna Slater stated although the SNP is the largest party at Holyrood and has the right to form a government, \"it does not have an automatic right to our votes\".\n\nShe added: \"We need to see what vision the first minister has for Scotland and what direction he wants to take.\"\n\nMs Slater said her party would work \"positively and constructively\" and would \"not indulge in opposition for its own sake or political gameplaying\".\n\nShe added: \"We will aim to work with and support the Scottish government on an issue-by-issue basis.\n\n\"We will back them when they are delivering progressive policies that protect our environment and help to tackle child poverty, and we will oppose them or Opportunity' as Scotland's New First Minister", "body": "John Swinney, who was leader of the SNP from 2000 to 2004, has completed his political comeback by being sworn in as Scotland's first minister.\n\nJohn Swinney, the new leader of the SNP, has been sworn in as Scotland's first minister, describing it as an \"extraordinary opportunity.\"\n\nHe was backed by the 63 SNP MSPs and Ash Regan from the Alba Party.\n\nScotland's most senior judge, the Lord President Lord Carloway, presided over the ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh on Wednesday morning.\n\nMr. Swinney, 60, made his statutory declarations and became first minister and keeper of the Scottish Seal.\n\nMs. Forbes was finance secretary under former First Minister Nicola Sturgeon but pulled out of the leadership contest to succeed her in March 2023 because she is a member of the Free Church of Scotland and her religious views were out of kilter with the SNP's views on gender identity.\n\nMr. Swinney's wife Elizabeth, brother David, and 13-year-old son Matthew were at the ceremony and he said it had been an \"overwhelming moment.\"\n\nHe said, \"I look forward to dedicating my future to serving the people of Scotland.\"\n\nMr. Swinney led the SNP between 2000 and 2004 but the party's electoral success came under his successors Alex Salmond and Ms. Sturgeon.\n\nThe Perthshire North MSP becomes the seventh person to be first minister since the introduction of devolution 25 years ago.\n\nThe first three were from the Labour Party and the other four -- Mr. Salmond, Ms. Sturgeon, Mr. Yousaf, and now Mr. Swinney -- were from the SNP.\n\nMr. Swinney became the leader of the SNP after a hardliner, Graeme McCormick, decided against challenging him.\n\nSome hardliners have called for the SNP to hold a second independence referendum without Westminster's support, in a similar way to Catalonia's referendum in Spain, and at last year's party conference Mr. McCormick called Mr. Yousaf's position \"flatulence in a trance.\"\n\nBefore unveiling his new Cabinet on Wednesday, Mr. Swinney said, \"It's important that I have a Cabinet that brings together the strengths and talents of the Scottish National Party, a Cabinet that can work constructively and collaboratively with Parliament and with other parties to ensure our agenda can be taken forward.\"\n\nAfter her appointment, Ms. Forbes issued a statement in which she said, \"I am deeply honoured to accept John's invitation to be his deputy first minister.\"\n\n\"This is a moment of extraordinary privilege for me. Having previously served in Cabinet, I know the duty that all ministers have to reflect the Government's priorities and the missions that drive them,\" she added.\n\n\"Because if some people are beyond the pale, then those are dark and dangerous days for Scotland,\" added Ms. Forbes.\n\nEarlier this week Labour's leader in Scotland, Anas Sarwar, said: \"At a time when Scotland is crying out for change, the SNP is offering more of the same. John Swinney has been at the heart of this incompetent government for 17 years and at the heart of the SNP for 40 years.\"\n\nThe next elections to the Scottish Parliament are not until 2026.", {"uri": "8116106503", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "18:46:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T18:46:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T18:45:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/5/7/john-swinney-elected-as-new-scotland-leader", "title": "John Swinney elected as new Scotland leader", "body": "Swinney replaces Humza Yousaf, who formally resigned on Tuesday after just over a year in office.\n\nScotland's Parliament has approved political veteran John Swinney of the Scottish National Party (SNP) to lead the country as first minister.\n\nSwinney, 60, succeeds Humza Yousaf, who formally resigned from the role earlier on Tuesday after his announcement last week that he would step down after just more than a year in charge.\n\nYousaf, 39, made the announcement before a confidence vote in the Scottish Parliament that he was set to lose, having ditched the SNP's junior coalition partners, the Scottish Green Party, in a row over climate policy.\n\nSwinney won the backing of 64 members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs) in the vote that was all but a foregone conclusion. His nearest rival, Scottish Conservatives leader Douglas Ross, picked up 31.\n\nThe political veteran said it was \"something of a surprise\" to find himself taking the top job at this stage of his career but added it was \"an extraordinary privilege\".\n\n\"I am here to serve you. I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country,\" he told parliament after accepting the nomination.\n\nSwinney, an old party hand who led the pro-independence SNP from 2000 to 2004 when the nationalists were in opposition, was elected unopposed as leader of the SNP on Monday.\n\nHe is seen as an experienced operator able to reach across the political divide, which is key to the SNP being able to rule as a minority government.\n\nSwinney must also unite his divided party, split between those on the left supportive of trans rights and urgent climate action and members on the right wanting to focus on issues such as health and the economy.\n\nHe has said that alongside advancing the case for Scottish independence, he wants to eradicate child poverty.\n\nBut he inherits a difficult political legacy with former SNP leader and ally Nicola Sturgeon embroiled in a party funding scandal and a challenging domestic policy landscape.\n\nThe SNP is expected to lose several seats in the United Kingdom Parliament to a resurgent Labour Party at a general election due this year.\n\nThe SNP currently holds 43 seats at Westminster. Labour hopes a comeback in its former stronghold of Scotland will help it win an outright majority in the nationwide vote.\n\nBritish Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, a Conservative, said he looked forward to \"working constructively\" with Swinney \"on the real issues that matter to families - delivering jobs, growth and better public services for people across Scotland\".\n\nCritics have accused the SNP, in power in the devolved parliament in Edinburgh for 17 years, of focusing on pursuing independence at the expense of issues like the cost-of-living crisis and education.\n\nThe party has struggled to rebuild momentum for another independence referendum since Scotland voted against leaving the UK in 2014.\n\nDespite the SNP slumping in the polls since Sturgeon quit in March last year, support for independence continues to hover around 40 percent, giving the party cause for hope.\n\nThe SNP holds 63 seats in the 129-member Scottish Parliament, two short of a majority, meaning Swinney will need the support of other parties to pass legislation.\n\nHe has said he will not resurrect the defunct power-sharing deal between the SNP and the Scottish Greens and will approach issues on a case-by-case basis.", "source": {"uri": "aljazeera.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Al Jazeera Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humza_Yousaf", {"uri": "8116027106", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:39:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:39:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:39:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/27783220/john-swinney-new-first-minister-scotland/", "title": "John Swinney becomes new First Minister of Scotland after winning Holyrood vote", "body": "JOHN Swinney has become Scotland's new First Minister after winning a vote at Holyrood.\n\nMr Swinney won the backing of 64 MSPs, with his nearest rival Scottish Conservatives leader Douglas Ross picking up 31.\n\nIt comes just eight days after predecessor Humza Yousaf announced he was stepping down after his decision to terminate the powersharing agreement the SNP had with the Scottish Greens at Holyrood left him facing a vote of no confidence in his leadership.\n\nMr Yousaf formally tendered his resignation to the King earlier on Tuesday.\n\nMr Swinney is currently the First Minister-designate and will be officially appointed this afternoon with a Royal Warrant from The King.\n\nHe will be officially sworn in at the Court of Session tomorrow and take the Official Oath in front of the Lord President of the Court of Session and other senior judges.\n\nJohn Swinney said: \"It is an extraordinary privilege and it is my honour to accept the office of First Minister, committing myself to do the best I can for Scotland.\n\n\"If we want to fund our schools and our hospitals, if we want to give our businesses a competitive edge, if we want to take climate action, if we want to eradicate child poverty, if we want to change people's lives for the better, we have to work together to do so.\n\n\"I commit my Government to working to create that agreement across the Chamber. I hope there is the space and the willingness for that to happen in the interests of the people who sent us here.\n\n\"To the people of Scotland I would simply say this. I offer myself to be the First Minister for everyone in Scotland. I am here to serve you. I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country.\"\n\nEx-First Minister and former SNP chief Nicola Sturgeon congratulated the new FM.\n\nShe posted to X: \"I have worked closely with John Swinney for more than 30 years.\n\n\"He was by my side throughout my time as FM - as deputy, friend and confidante.\n\n\"He is one of the kindest and most decent people I know - and without doubt, the right person to be FM in this moment, for both party and country.\n\n\"Aside from his family, I doubt there is anyone in Scotland prouder of John today than I am. I wish him all the luck in the world.\"\n\nScottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross said in Parliament: \"I know that the First Minister, given his long career in cabinet, will be acutely aware of that burden and that the decision to take up that role will not have been as easy one for him.\n\n\"And so, I wish him well in taking on that burden. I also want to say how rightly proud his family must be today.\n\n\"We all know the strain elected office has on our families but that is magnified ten-fold, when the politician holds the office of First Minister.\n\n\"So on behalf of the Scottish Conservatives, we offer strength and support to the entire Swinney family as they provide the personal backing that will be so important to our First Minister.\n\n\"I hope that he will lead a government not for just one side of the constitutional argument but for all of Scotland.\n\n\"Because a government acting in the national interests is what the Scottish people deserve.\n\n\"Yet it is what the SNP have failed to deliver for the last three years.\n\n\"The legislative achievements of this session are few and far between and that looks unlikely to change.\n\n\"Instead, we saw an SNP Government, having ran out of its own ideas, increasingly look for policy direction from the extreme Greens.\n\n\"While continuing to push the same old, tired campaign for independence and a referendum.\n\n\"John Swinney must swiftly change course and deliver a bold new policy agenda for this SNP Government instead of treading water like his {"uri": "8116001993", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:19:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:19:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:18:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/politics/article/2024/may/07/john-swinney-becomes-scottish-first-minister-after-vote-by-msps", "title": "John Swinney becomes Scottish first minister after vote by MSPs", "body": "New SNP leader becomes seventh to hold the office vacated by Humza Yousef but without support of Green members\n\nThe new Scottish National party leader John Swinney will become Scotland's seventh first minister after winning the backing of MSPs.\n\nAs is traditional, opposition leaders stood against Swinney in the vote, which he won just eight days after Humza Yousaf dramatically announced his departure, with the backing of 64 SNP MSPs, while the seven Scottish Greens abstained.\n\nAccepting the nomination, Swinney spoke personally of how he had wrestled with the decision to stand for leadership, which he won unopposed on Monday.\n\nHe reminded the chamber that his wife, Elizabeth Quigley, lives with multiple sclerosis. \"She is indefatigable in trying to make sure that MS does not get in the way of her living life to the full, but, much to her frustration, she does often have to rely on her husband for support and assistance.\"\n\nSpeaking directly to her as she watched from the public gallery with his children, Swinney thanked her for \"the sacrifices she is prepared to make to enable her husband to serve our country as first minster\".\n\nSwinney also said he took responsibility for his own part in the growing polarisation of the parliament - his noisy cross-chamber heckles are well known and he has been rebuked for them by the presiding officer on multiple occasions.\n\nHe promised the chamber \"that will all stop - I have changed\", to a smattering of laughter.\n\nSwinney, who was deputy first minister in Nicola Sturgeon's government, will be officially sworn in at the court of session on Wednesday. He is expected to reshuffle his cabinet soon after that, with Kate Forbes - who narrowly lost to Yousaf in last year's leadership contest and agreed to back Swinney after private talks week - likely to take a leading position.\n\nIn his pitch to MSPs, Swinney - who must now govern from a minority position after Yousaf unilaterally axed the governing partnership with the Scottish Greens last week, precipitating his downfall - struck an ameliorative tone, noting the 25th anniversary of the Scottish parliament and praising other parties for their contribution over the years.\n\nOpposition leaders pointed to Swinney's involvement in past Scottish government failures - he is one of the SNP's most experienced politicians and previously served as leader from 2000 to 2004. Scottish Tory leader, Douglas Ross, accused the SNP of \"replacing one continuity candidate with another\" while Scottish Labour's Anas Sarwar called for an early Holyrood election.\n\nScottish Greens co-leader Lorna Slater questioned whether Swinney would \"retreat to the middle ground\" by ditching the policy programme previously agreed between the SNP and her party, including rent controls and a ban on conversion practices, adding that \"our door remains open\" for future collaboration.\n\nThe outgoing first minister, Humza Yousaf, made an emotional final statement in which he thanked MSPs for the opportunity \"to defy the far right, bigots and racists\" who had told him to \"go home\" throughout his life.\n\n\"I have no other home than this one,\" Yousaf, the first Muslim to hold the {"uri": "2024-05-348130836", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "18:51:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T18:51:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T18:35:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/john-swinney-ll-unionists-park-183520686.html", "title": "John Swinney: I'll work with Unionists if they park independence opposition", "body": "John Swinney has offered to work with Scotland's Unionist parties if they park their opposition to independence, as he was voted in as the new First Minister.\n\nMr Swinney acknowledged the deep divisions in the Holyrood chamber over independence, but argued that MSPs should ask whether these \"prevent us from working collaboratively within the existing powers of the parliament\".\n\nIn an attempt to reinvent himself as a peacemaker, following years of barracking opposition MSPs, he said he wanted to collaborate with them to improve Scotland's ailing NHS and economy.\n\nAfter being elected the new First Minister, he immediately crossed the chamber floor to shake the hands of Douglas Ross and Anas Sarwar, respectively the Scottish Tory and Labour leaders.\n\nMr Ross had earlier urged him to treat his election as a \"reset moment\" and end the \"decade of division that has plagued our country\" since the 2014 independence referendum.\n\nHe said Mr Swinney should \"put campaigning for independence on the backburner\" and argued the minority SNP government should reach out to the \"whole parliament\" rather than only the pro-separation Greens.\n\nHowever, he said Mr Swinney was the \"continuity candidate\" after Nicola Sturgeon and Humza Yousaf, leading to \"the same distracted nationalist government, run by the same people, that we've seen for the last 17 years.\"\n\nMr Sarwar challenged the SNP to stop accusing its opponents of being \"traitors\" to Scotland and mocked the \"pretence of them somehow being the great unifiers of our nation\".\n\nHe also gave a scathing assessment of Mr Swinney's record in office, describing him as the \"worst education secretary in the history of our parliament\" and highlighting his deletion of all his WhatsApps from the pandemic.\n\n\"We need to see an end to the culture of secrecy and cover-up but I fear the SNP have elected to the highest office one of its champions,\" the Scottish Labour leader said.\n\nMr Swinney was formally elected First Minister hours after Humza Yousaf submitted his resignation to the King. His nomination was backed by the SNP's 64 MSPs, while the seven Greens abstained, giving him the required majority.\n\nThe 60-year-old, who was previously SNP leader between 2000 and 2004, will be sworn in as First Minister at the Court of Session on Wednesday morning.\n\nHe will then unveil his new Cabinet, with a prominent role expected for Kate Forbes after she agreed to his pleas not to stand against him for the party leadership, meaning he did not face a contest.\n\nIt is a remarkable comeback for Mr Swinney, who was deputy first minister in Ms Sturgeon's government and stepped down from the Scottish Cabinet in tandem with her in March last year.\n\nIt had been assumed his career in frontline politics was over but Mr Yousaf's ignominious fall from power, after he botched his decision to end his power-sharing deal with the Greens, left the SNP in crisis.\n\nIn a speech to MSPs following his election as First Minister, he admitted it was \"something of a surprise\" to accept the office and said that eradicating child poverty would be his government's priority.\n\nHe admitted he would lead a minority administration that needed the votes of other parties and noted the Scottish Parliament is \"intensely polarised at this time.\"\n\nTo laughter, Mr Swinney said: \"I accept my part in creating that environment - whether that is by shouted put-downs from the front bench or heckling from a sedentary position. I do promise, Presiding Officer, that will all stop - I have changed.\"\n\nHe acknowledged that Holyrood was divided on independence but asked: \"Does our disagreement on the constitution prevent us from working collaboratively within the existing powers of the parliament to eradicate child poverty, build the economy, support jobs, address the cost of living crisis, improve the health service and tackle the climate crisis?\n\n\"I will give all of my energy, and my willingness to engage and listen, to ensure that is not the case. I invite others to do the same.\"\n\nMr Yousaf's 'most prominent supporter'\n\nMr Swinney also paid tribute to his wife Elizabeth, who has multiple sclerosis and was watching from the gallery, saying he wanted to express his \"profound eternal gratitude for the sacrifices she is prepared to make to enable her husband to serve our country as First Minister.\"\n\nMr Ross noted Mr Swinney had been Alex Salmond's Finance Secretary, Ms Sturgeon's deputy and Mr Yousaf's \"most prominent supporter\".\n\n\"Scotland waits to see whether he will be a nationalist leader, like his predecessors, or a national leader that Scotland needs to take our country forward,\" Mr Ross said.\n\nAlister Jack, the Scottish Secretary, congratulated Mr Swinney but said: \"He needs to put aside his obsession with independence, and concentrate on contributing to a thriving Scotland within a strong United Kingdom.\"\n\nMs Sturgeon tweeted: \"I have worked closely with John Swinney for more than 30 years. He was by my side throughout my time as FM - as deputy, friend and confidante.\n\n\"He is one of the kindest and most decent people I know - and without doubt, the right person to be FM in this {"uri": "2024-05-348574877", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "06:29:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T06:29:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T06:27:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/john-swinney-set-to-be-sworn-in-as-first-minister-and-appoint-cabinet-4619553", "title": "John Swinney set to be sworn in as Scotland's first minister and appoint cabinet", "body": "The ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh will involve the Perthshire North MSP making his statutory declarations, after which he will be granted his official title of First Minister and Keeper of the Scottish Seal.\n\nHe is then expected to begin cabinet appointments with Kate Forbes expected to be handed a key role.\n\nYesterday, Mr Swinney pleaded with his rivals for a new collaborative politics as he vowed to end the \"intensely polarised\" nature of Holyrood.\n\nAfter accepting the nomination, Mr Swinney stressed that Holyrood is \"not the collaborative place it has been in the past\" as he committed to work with all other opposition parties to make progress in his leadership at the helm of a minority SNP government.\n\nMr Swinney pointed to the \"eradication of child poverty\" as well as improving public services and growing the economy as his key priorities as he acknowledged he will only be able to get things done if he reaches out to his opponents.\n\nHe warned that Holyrood has been \"intensely polarised\" in recent years, adding that he will \"accept my part in creating that environment\", including by having \"shouted put-downs from a front bench\" and \"heckling from a sedentary position\".\n\nWith a wry smile, Mr Swinney added: \"That all stops. I've changed.\"\n\nHe said: \"This is not the collaborative place it has been in the past.\"\n\nIn a vote at Holyrood, Mr Swinney won the backing of 64 MSPs, with his nearest rival Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross picking up 31. Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar secured 22 votes, with the head of the Scottish Liberal Democrats, Alex Cole-Hamilton, winning four. The seven Scottish Green MSPs abstained.\n\nMr Swinney, who got up from his seat on the front bench to shake hands with every opposition leader after his speech, questioned whether \"our disagreement on the constitution prevent us from working collaboratively within the existing powers of the parliament to eradicate child poverty, build the economy, support jobs, address the cost of living crisis, improve the health service and tackle the climate crisis\".\n\nHe added: \"I will give all of my energy, and my willingness to engage and listen, to ensure that is not the case. I invite others to do the same.\"\n\nThe Perthshire North MSP pointed to \"a focus on the economy, our National Health Service and public services\" as well as \"a drive to lift children out of poverty\".\n\nDespite his pledge to work with unionist parties, Mr Swinney insisted that \"Scottish self-government is the right way forward for Scotland\" through independence.\n\nMr Swinney claimed that ending the Union would \"equip this parliament with the powers it needs to match the success of those comparable independent states\". He added that independence would provide \"more resources for our National Health Service\" and \"the opportunity to grow our economy free from a broken Westminster economic model\".\n\nHe added: \"Both those who are against independence and those who are in favour deserve to be heard through dialogue, debate and deliberation.\n\n\"I believe it's possible to argue respectfully our different positions.\"\n\nIn accepting the nomination to become the next First Minister, Mr Swinney paid thanks to his family, watching in the Holyrood gallery, particularly his wife Elizabeth who has multiple sclerosis.\n\nHe acknowledged he had taken time to talk over whether taking on the top job was right for his family, concluding that \"we will manage\".\n\nMr Swinney added that he has \"profound eternal gratitude for the sacrifices she is prepared to make to enable her husband to service our country as First Minister\".\n\nMr Ross also pointed to the \"strain\" being an elected politician has have on families, stressing \"that is magnified tenfold when the politician holds the office of first minister\".\n\nHe said his party would \"offer our strength and support to the entire Swinney family\".\n\nBut Mr Ross warned that Mr Swinney's government \"cannot just serve one side of the constitutional argument\", adding that \"it must deliver for the whole of Scotland\".\n\nThe Tory leader claimed that \"the legislative achievements of this session (of parliament) are few and far between\". He accused Mr Swinney's predecessors of having \"run out of its own ideas\", and borrowed \"policy ideas from the extreme Greens\".\n\nHe said: \"John Swinney must swiftly change course and deliver a bold, new policy agenda for the SNP government instead of treading water like his predecessors.\"\n\nMr Ross called on Mr Swinney to \"reach beyond a nationalist coalition to compromise and find consensus in this parliament\".\n\nBut he added that the \"key to delivering that would be putting the campaign for independence on the backburner\" and treat him taking the keys to Bute House \"as a reset moment\".\n\nThe Scottish Labour leader also appeared to back more collaboration, calling on Mr Swinney to \"work across this chamber in a way that has sadly escaped his predecessors\".\n\nMr Sarwar added: \"We will continue to work constructively when we can and promote the national interest.\"\n\nBut Mr Sarwar claimed that the SNP has been \"one of the architects of divisive politics\".\n\nHe added: \"I do now question the rhetoric and the pretense of them now somehow being the great unifiers of our nation.\"\n\nThe Labour leader called for \"an end to the incompetence in managing our public services\".\n\nMr Swinney has indicated a shift away from SNP governments being propped up by the Scottish Greens. Mr Yousaf's move to tear up the Bute House Agreement signalled the end of his premiership and has prompted the first minister in waiting to appeal to unionist opponents instead.\n\nCo-leader of the Scottish Greens, Lorna Slater, said that despite the end of her party's co-operation agreement with the government, \"there was so much work still to be completed\", highlighting plans for rent controls and decarbonising how buildings are heated and demands for a \"water-tight ban on conversion therapy\".\n\nShe called on Mr Swinney to \"lay out whether the government will continue with these progressive policies\" or \"retreat to the middle ground\" and \"rely on the Tories\" for support.\n\nMs Slater added: \"Our door remains open.\"\n\nNicola Sturgeon, who was first minister when Mr Swinney served as deputy, wished him \"all the luck in the world\".\n\nWriting on X, formerly known as Twitter, she added: \"I have worked closely with John Swinney for more than 30 years. He was by my side throughout my time as FM - as deputy, friend and confidante.\n\n\"He is one of the kindest and most decent people I know - and without doubt the right person to be FM in this moment, for both party and country.\n\n\"Aside from his family, I doubt there is anyone in Scotland prouder of John today than I am.\"\n\nScottish Secretary Alister Jack said: \"I would like to congratulate John Swinney on being elected First Minister of Scotland.\n\n\"I hope that he will prioritise the issues that really matter to people in Scotland, like improving failing public services and growing our economy. I want him to work constructively with the UK government on our joint projects to boost Scotland's prosperity - including freeports, city deals and investment zones.\n\n\"Most of all, I hope that Mr Swinney will govern for the whole of Scotland. He needs to put aside his obsession with independence, and concentrate on contributing to a thriving Scotland within a strong United Kingdom.\"", "source": {"uri": "scotsman.com", "dataType": "news",
