{"uri": "2024-05-348060106", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:31:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:31:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:29:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/john-swinney-vows-to-end-intensely-polarised-holyrood-and-form-new-politics-with-opponents-4619553", "title": "John Swinney vows to end 'intensely polarised' Holyrood and form new politics with opponents", "body": "He called for an end to bitter disputes at Holyrood as he pledged to work more collaboratively with political rivals\n\nJohn Swinney has pleaded with his rivals for a new collaborative politics as he vowed to end the \"intensely polarised\" nature of Holyrood after being nominated as Scotland's seventh First Minister.\n\nThe SNP leader will be sworn in as Humza Yousaf's successor at the Court of Session on Wednesday after MSPs backed him in a vote to be nominated as the next First Minister.\n\nAfter accepting the nomination, Mr Swinney stressed that Holyrood is \"not the collaborative place it has been in the past\" as he committed to work with all other opposition parties to make progress in his leadership at the helm of a minority SNP government.\n\nMr Swinney pointed to the \"eradication of child poverty\" as well as improving public services and growing the economy as his key priorities as he acknowledged he will only be able to get things done if he reaches out to his opponents.\n\nHe warned that Holyrood has been \"intensely polarised\" in recent years, adding that he will \"accept my part in creating that environment\", including by having \"shouted put-downs from a front bench\" and \"heckling from a sedentary position\".\n\nWith a wry smile, Mr Swinney added: \"That all stops. I've changed.\"\n\nHe said: \"This is not the collaborative place it has been in the past.\"\n\nIn a vote at Holyrood, Mr Swinney won the backing of 64 MSPs, with his nearest rival Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross picking up 31. Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar secured 22 votes, with the head of the Scottish Liberal Democrats, Alex Cole-Hamilton, winning four. The seven Scottish Green MSPs abstained.\n\nMr Swinney, who got up from his seat on the front bench to shake hands with every opposition leader after his speech, questioned whether \"our disagreement on the constitution prevent us from working collaboratively within the existing powers of the parliament to eradicate child poverty, build the economy, support jobs, address the cost of living crisis, improve the health service and tackle the climate crisis\".\n\nHe added: \"I will give all of my energy, and my willingness to engage and listen, to ensure that is not the case. I invite others to do the same.\"\n\nThe Perthshire North MSP pointed to \"a focus on the economy, our National Health Service and public services\" as well as \"a drive to lift children out of poverty\".\n\nDespite his pledge to work with unionist parties, Mr Swinney insisted that \"Scottish self-government is the right way forward for Scotland\" through independence.\n\nMr Swinney claimed that ending the Union would \"equip this parliament with the powers it needs to match the success of those comparable independent states\". He added that independence would provide \"more resources for our National Health Service\" and \"the opportunity to grow our economy free from a broken Westminster economic model\".\n\nHe added: \"Both those who are against independence and those who are in favour deserve to be heard through dialogue, debate and deliberation.\n\n\"I believe it's possible to argue respectfully our different positions.\"\n\nIn accepting the nomination to become the next First Minister, Mr Swinney paid thanks to his family, watching in the Holyrood gallery, particularly his wife Elizabeth who has multiple sclerosis.\n\nHe acknowledged he had taken time to talk over whether taking on the top job was right for his family, concluding that \"we will manage\".\n\nMr Swinney added that he has \"profound eternal gratitude for the sacrifices she is prepared to make to enable her husband to service our country as First Minister\".\n\nMr Ross also pointed to the \"strain\" being an elected politician has have on families, stressing \"that is magnified tenfold when the politician holds the office of first minister\".\n\nHe said his party would \"offer our strength and support to the entire Swinney family\".\n\nBut Mr Ross warned that Mr Swinney's government \"cannot just serve one side of the constitutional argument\", adding that \"it must deliver for the whole of Scotland\".\n\nThe Tory leader claimed that \"the legislative achievements of this session (of parliament) are few and far between\". He accused Mr Swinney's predecessors of having \"run out of its own ideas\", and borrowed \"policy ideas from the extreme Greens\".\n\nHe said: \"John Swinney must swiftly change course and deliver a bold, new policy agenda for the SNP government instead of treading water like his predecessors.\"\n\nMr Ross called on Mr Swinney to \"reach beyond a nationalist coalition to compromise and find consensus in this parliament\".\n\nBut he added that the \"key to delivering that would be putting the campaign for independence on the backburner\" and treat him taking the keys to Bute House \"as a reset moment\".\n\nThe Scottish Labour leader also appeared to back more collaboration, calling on Mr Swinney to \"work across this chamber in a way that has sadly escaped his predecessors\".\n\nMr Sarwar added: \"We will continue to work constructively when we can and promote the national interest.\"\n\nBut Mr Sarwar claimed that the SNP has been \"one of the architects of divisive politics\".\n\nHe added: \"I do now question the rhetoric and the pretense of them now somehow being the great unifiers of our nation.\"\n\nThe Labour leader called for \"an end to the incompetence in managing our public services\".\n\nMr Swinney has indicated a shift away from SNP governments being propped up by the Scottish Greens. Mr Yousaf's move to tear up the Bute House Agreement signalled the end of his premiership and has prompted the first minister in waiting to appeal to unionist opponents instead.\n\nCo-leader of the Scottish Greens, Lorna Slater, said that despite the end of her party's co-operation agreement with the government, \"there was so much work still to be completed\", highlighting plans for rent controls and decarbonising how buildings are heated and demands for a \"water-tight ban on conversion therapy\".\n\nShe called on Mr Swinney to \"lay out whether the government will continue with these progressive policies\" or \"retreat to the middle ground\" and \"rely on the Tories\" for support.\n\nMs Slater added: \"Our door remains open.\"\n\nNicola Sturgeon, who was first minister when Mr Swinney served as deputy, wished him \"all the luck in the world\".\n\nWriting on X, formerly known as Twitter, she added: \"I have worked closely with John Swinney for more than 30 years. He was by my side throughout my time as FM - as deputy, friend and confidante.\n\n\"He is one of the kindest and most decent people I know - and without doubt the right person to be FM in this moment, for both party and country.\n\n\"Aside from his family, I doubt there is anyone in Scotland prouder of John today than I am.\"\n\nScottish Secretary Alister Jack said: \"I would like to congratulate John Swinney on being elected First Minister of Scotland.\n\n\"I hope that he will prioritise the issues that really matter to people in Scotland, like improving failing public services and growing our economy. I want him to work constructively with the UK government on our joint projects to boost Scotland's prosperity - including freeports, city deals and investment zones.\n\n\"Most of all, I hope that Mr Swinney will govern for the whole of Scotland. He needs to put aside his obsession with independence, and concentrate on contributing to a thriving Scotland within a strong United Kingdom.\"", "source": {"uri": "scotsman.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8117429888", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:10:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:10:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:07:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13395833/Kate-Forbes-Deputy-First-Minister-John-Swinney-appoints-Scottish-Cabinet.html", "title": "Kate Forbes made Deputy First Minister as John Swinney appoints...", "body": "Kate Forbes has been appointed as John Swinney's Deputy First Minister as the SNP leader assembles his Cabinet.\n\nMs Forbes had challenged Humza Yousaf for the SNP leadership last year but opted not to stand against Mr Swinney, who had promised her a \"significant\" role in his Government.\n\nMr Swinney put party unity at the heart of his pitch to succeed Mr Yousaf as SNP leader.\n\nFormer finance minister Ms Forbes was the first to arrive at Mr Swinney's official residence in Edinburgh on Wednesday as he put together his top table.\n\nJohn Swinney is appointing his new Cabinet (Andrew Milligan/PA)\n\nIn a statement, Ms Forbes said: \"I am deeply honoured to accept John's invitation to be his Deputy First Minister.\n\n\"This is a moment of extraordinary privilege for me. Having previously served in Cabinet, I know the duty that all ministers have to reflect the Government's priorities and the missions that drive them.\n\n\"I look forward to working with John and Cabinet colleagues, delivering for the people of Scotland and building a better country.\"\n\nShe succeeds Shona Robison as Deputy First Minister, who is moving to another role in Government.\n\nThe full list of Cabinet responsibilities is expected to be confirmed later on Wednesday.\n\nMr Swinney said: \"I am very pleased to appoint Kate as Deputy First Minister and look forward to working with her in this new Government.\n\n\"She is an immensely talented politician, and her new role will prove critical as we focus on our key commitments of eradicating child poverty, investing in public services and supporting economic growth.\"\n\nAs well as Ms Forbes, those seen entering Bute House for the Cabinet appointments include Wellbeing Economy, Energy and Net Zero Secretary Mairi McAllan, Transport Secretary Fiona Hyslop and Health Secretary Neil Gray.\n\nShona Robison arrives at Bute House (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nEarlier, Mr Swinney was questioned on what role he planned to give Ms Forbes, but would say only that he is \"a man of my word\" - referring to his speech last week where he said he wanted her to have a \"significant role\" in his team.\n\nHe also said being sworn in as Scotland's new First Minister was an \"overwhelming moment\".\n\nJohn Swinney, left, took the oath while his family watched on (Andrew Milligan/PA)\n\nScotland's most senior judge, Lord President Lord Carloway, presided over the ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh on Wednesday morning where Mr Swinney made his statutory declarations and was granted his official title of First Minister and Keeper of the Scottish Seal.\n\nMr Swinney raised his right hand and bowed his head as Lord Carloway read the three oaths of office - for the role of First Minister, the Keeper of the Great Seal and the oath of allegiance to the King.\n\nThe Lord President then addressed the court about the independence of the judiciary.\n\nMr Swinney's family, including his wife Elizabeth, brother David and 13-year-old son Matthew, accompanied him to court.\n\nSpeaking to reporters after the ceremony, the Perthshire North MSP said: \"It's a really overwhelming moment to take the oath of office in front of the Lord President of the Court of Session and formally assume the role of First Minister,\" he said.\n\n\"I look forward to dedicating my future to serving the people of Scotland.\n\n\"It's an extraordinary opportunity to change lives for the better and I'll continue to use every moment that's available to me to do so.\"\n\nJohn Swinney with his wife Elizabeth Quigley and son Matthew,13 (Andrew Milligan/PA)\n\nHe added: \"For my family this is a very abrupt change of our circumstances. We didn't think this would happening about 10 days ago.\"\n\nHe said they are making plans to adapt and it had been \"very precious\" to have his family at his side at the swearing in ceremony.\n\nHe had pledged to devote himself to the job after being voted into the role at Holyrood on Tuesday, and he becomes the seventh person to be First Minister since the Scottish Parliament was established 25 {"uri": "2024-05-347987388", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:17:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:17:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:11:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/john-swinney-elected-scotlands-leader-161121132.html", "title": "John Swinney elected as Scotland's new leader", "body": "Scotland got its second leader in as many years on Tuesday, as parliament approved political veteran John Swinney to lead the country as first minister.\n\nSwinney, 60, succeeds Humza Yousaf, who formally resigned from the role earlier in the day, following his announcement last week that he would step down after just over a year in charge.\n\nYousaf, 39, announced his resignation last Monday before a confidence vote in the Scottish parliament that he was set to lose, having ditched his junior coalition partners, the Scottish Green Party, in a row over climate policy.\n\nSwinney won the backing of 64 members of the Scottish parliament (MSPs) in the vote that was all but a foregone conclusion, with nearest rival Scottish Conservatives leader Douglas Ross picking up 31.\n\nThe Scottish political veteran, said it was \"something of a surprise\" to find himself taking the top job at his stage of his career, but added it was \"an extraordinary privilege\".\n\n\"I am here to serve you. I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country,\" he told MSPs after accepting the nomination.\n\nSwinney, an old party hand who led the ruling pro-independence Scottish National Party (SNP) from 2000 to 2004 when the nationalists were in opposition, was elected unopposed as leader of the SNP on Monday.\n\nHe is seen as an experienced operator able to reach across the political divide, which is key to the SNP being able to rule as a minority government.\n\nSwinney must also unite his divided party, split between those on the left supportive of trans rights and urgent climate action and members on the right wanting to focus on issues such as health and the economy.\n\nHe has said that alongside advancing the case for Scottish independence, he wants to eradicate child poverty.\n\nBut he inherits a difficult political legacy, with former SNP leader and ally Nicola Sturgeon embroiled in a party funding scandal and a challenging domestic policy landscape.\n\n- Resurgent Labour -\n\nThe SNP is expected to lose several seats in the UK parliament to a resurgent Labour party at a general election due later this year.\n\nThe SNP currently holds 43 seats at Westminster. Labour hopes a comeback in its former stronghold of Scotland will help it win an outright majority in the nationwide vote.\n\nUK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said he looked forward to \"working constructively\" with Swinney \"on the real issues that matter to families -- delivering jobs, growth and better public services for people across Scotland\".\n\nCritics have accused the SNP, in power in the devolved parliament in Edinburgh for 17 years, of focusing on pursuing independence at the expense of issues like the cost-of-living crisis and education.\n\nThe party has struggled to rebuild momentum for another independence vote since Scotland voted against leaving the UK in a referendum in 2014.\n\nBut despite the SNP slumping in the polls since Sturgeon quit in March last year, support for independence continues to hover around the 40 percent mark, giving the party cause for hope.\n\nThe SNP holds 63 seats in the 129-member Scottish parliament, two short of a majority, meaning Swinney will need the support of other parties to pass legislation.\n\nHe has said he will not resurrect the defunct power-sharing deal between the SNP and the Scottish Greens, known as the Bute House for the role of First Minister, the Keeper of the Great Seal and the oath of allegiance to the King.\n\nJohn Swinney, left, took the oath while his family watched on (Andrew Milligan/PA)\n\nThe Lord President then addressed the court about the independence of the judiciary.\n\nMr Swinney's family, including his wife Elizabeth, brother David and 13-year-old son Matthew, accompanied him to court.\n\nSpeaking to reporters after the ceremony, Mr Swinney said taking the oaths had been an \"overwhelming moment\" and he spoke of his pride at being First Minister and his family's support.\n\nKate Forbes looks set to be offered a key role in John Swinney\u00b4s Cabinet (PA)\n\n\"It's a really overwhelming moment to take the oath of office in front of the Lord President of the Court of Session and formally assume the role of First Minister,\" he said.\n\n\"I look forward to dedicating my future to serving the people of Scotland.\n\n\"It's an extraordinary opportunity to change lives for the better and I'll continue to use every moment that's available to me to do so.\n\nJohn Swinney in the main chamber at Holyrood after being voted in as First Minister on Tuesday (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\n\"For my family this is a very abrupt change of our circumstances. We didn't think this would happening about 10 days ago.\"\n\nHe said they are making plans to adapt and it had been \"very precious\" to have his family at his side at the swearing in.\n\nAsked about former finance secretary Ms Forbes - who announced she would not run against him for the SNP leadership after a discussion with him - and whether she will have a role in his Cabinet, Mr Swinney referred to his speech last week where he said he wanted her to have a \"significant role\" to play in his team.\n\nJohn Swinney, with his wife Elizabeth Quigley, on the steps of Bute House, the North MSP had pledged to devote himself to the job after being voted into the role at Holyrood on Tuesday, and he becomes the seventh person to be First Minister since the Scottish Parliament was "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/humza-yousaf-formally-resigns-as-scotlands-first-minister-with-letter-to-king-13130981", "title": "Humza Yousaf formally resigns as Scotland's first minister with letter to King", "body": "Humza Yousaf has formally tendered his resignation as Scotland's first minister to the King.\n\nIt now paves the way for MSPs to vote on who should take his place, with new SNP leader John Swinney expected to win Holyrood's backing.\n\nThe vote is expected to take place at the Scottish parliament later on Tuesday.\n\nIn his letter to the King, Mr Yousaf wrote: \"With my humble duty, I write as anticipated in my letter to Your Majesty of 29 April to tender to Your Majesty my resignation from the office of first minister.\n\n\"I propose that my resignation take effect from the start of Scottish parliamentary plenary business on Tuesday 7 May 2024.\n\n\"Throughout my time as first minister, I have been most grateful for your counsel and the kindness you have shown to both Nadia and I.\n\n\"It has been my pleasure to serve Your Majesty and the people of Scotland since March 2023.\"\n\nFollowing his resignation, Mr Yousaf said: \"Being the first minister of the country I love, the country I am raising my family in, and the only country I will ever call home has been a phenomenal honour.\n\n\"As a young Muslim boy, born and raised in Scotland, I could never have dreamt that one day I would have the privilege of leading my country - people who looked like me were not in positions of political influence, let alone leading governments when I was younger.\n\n\"I am proud to have delivered a council tax freeze for households in every local authority in Scotland, invested record amounts in our National Health Service, removed peak fares on our railways, and approved plans for Europe's largest floating offshore windfarm.\n\n\"And through our actions, an estimated 100,000 children are expected to be kept out of poverty this year.\n\n\"From the backbenches of the Scottish parliament, I will continue to champion the rights and the voices of those who are often not heard, be they at home or abroad.\"\n\nMr Yousaf was forced to step down after terminating the Bute House Agreement with the Scottish Greens.\n\nWithin hours of the power-sharing deal coming to an end, Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross announced he would be bringing a motion of no confidence in the first minister.\n\nAngry over the way the party was dumped from government, the Scottish Greens announced its MSPs would be backing the motion.\n\nScottish Labour then announced it was planning a motion of no confidence in the Scottish government.\n\nMr Yousaf reached out to his political opponents in an effort to stem the uprising but conceded that he had \"underestimated the level of hurt and upset\" his actions had caused Scottish Green colleagues.\n\nAfter Mr Yousaf resigned, Mr Ross dropped his motion.\n\nScottish Labour pressed on but the party was defeated in a vote following a debate at Holyrood last week.\n\nMr Swinney, who was deputy first minister under Nicola Sturgeon, is now expected to succeed Mr Yousaf.\n\nRead more:\n\nWho is John Swinney?\n\nMr Swinney was unopposed in the SNP leadership contest and promised a \"new chapter\" for the party as he pledged to use \"respect and courtesy\" to make the case for Scottish independence.\n\nResponding to questions after his post-win speech on Monday, Mr Swinney confirmed he will not be reinstating the Bute House Agreement with the Scottish Greens, preferring to take issues on a case-by-case basis.\n\nIf elected by MSPs and once officially sworn-in at the Court of Session in Edinburgh, Mr Swinney will then be able to appoint his {"uri": "8117745980", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:34:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:34:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:33:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13396655/Swinney-appoints-largely-unchanged-Cabinet-Forbes-returns-deputy.html", "title": "Swinney appoints largely unchanged Cabinet but Forbes returns as...", "body": "Kate Forbes has become Scotland's youngest ever Deputy First Minister as John Swinney announced a largely unchanged Cabinet team.\n\nMs Forbes, 34, a former Holyrood finance secretary, had been tipped to run for the SNP leadership again after Humza Yousaf stood down just over a week ago, but she instead opted to back Mr Swinney and he went on to claim the position of party leader unopposed.\n\nHe has now rewarded her by making her his deputy, and also giving her responsibility for the economy and Gaelic.\n\nBy giving such a key role to Ms Forbes, a critic of some Scottish Government policies who had been on the backbenches during Mr Yousaf's time in charge, Mr Swinney will hope to ease internal tensions within the SNP.\n\nJohn Swinney and Kate Forbes spoke to journalists outside Bute House in Edinburgh - the official residence of the First Minister. (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nThe new First Minister assembled his Cabinet hours after being officially sworn into the post at the Court of Session in Edinburgh, and after he spoke to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.\n\nSpeaking after his top team was announced, Mr Swinney said he is \"committed to working collaboratively across the Parliament to address the pressing issues facing the people of Scotland\".\n\nThat will be required as the SNP is now a minority administration at Holyrood after Mr Yousaf tore up the powersharing deal the party had with the Scottish Greens - a move which ultimately led to his resignation as first minister.\n\nMr Swinney's Cabinet includes eight women - thought to be the most ever - and two other men.\n\nNeil Gray, who was appointed Health Secretary earlier this year, stays in the post, while Angus Robertson remains Constitution, External Affairs and Culture Secretary.\n\nShona Robison, who had been deputy first minister under Mr Yousaf, loses that position but remains in the Cabinet - keeping her finance brief and also taking on responsibility for local government.\n\nFirst Minister John Swinney stands with his newly appointed Cabinet on the steps of Bute House (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nFormer teacher Jenny Gilruth remains Education Secretary, Angela Constance retains her position as Justice Secretary, and Fiona Hyslop continues as Transport Secretary.\n\nMairi McAllan remains in the Cabinet but with a slightly slimmed down brief - she had been the net zero, wellbeing economy and energy secretary, but now has responsibility for net zero and energy.\n\nShirley-Anne Sommerville and Mairi Gougeon also continue in their previous roles - as Social Justice Secretary, and Rural Affairs, Land Reform and Islands Secretary respectively.\n\nMr Swinney said: \"I have selected a Cabinet team that blends experience and energy, with a strong focus on the priorities my Government will pursue - eradicating child poverty, driving economic growth, meeting climate obligations and investing in our vital public services.\n\n\"My overriding priority will be to work to eradicate child poverty in Scotland, an issue on which real progress has been made through measures such as the Scottish child payment.\n\nNew Scottish First Minister John Swinney, with his wife Elizabeth Quigley and their son Matthew,13. (Andrew Milligan/PA)\n\n\"The Government I lead will maximise every lever at our disposal to tackle the scourge of poverty in our country.\"\n\nMs Forbes said she was \"deeply honoured\" to be appointed as his deputy, describing it as an \"extraordinary privilege\".\n\nShe added: \"I look forward to working with John and Cabinet colleagues, delivering for the people of Scotland and building a better country.\"\n\nSpeaking earlier on Wednesday after he was sworn into office at the Court of Session, Mr Swinney had said: \"It's a really overwhelming moment to take the oath of office in front of the Lord President of the Court of Session and formally assume the role of First Minister.\n\n\"I look forward to dedicating my future to serving the people of Scotland.\n\n\"It's an {"uri": "8116089981", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "18:31:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T18:31:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T18:31:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/john-swinney-elected-as-scotlands-new-leader-20240507", "title": "John Swinney elected as Scotland's new leader | News24", "body": "His party is likely to lose seats to Labour in upcoming elections.\n\nScotland got its second leader in as many years on Tuesday, as parliament approved political veteran John Swinney to lead the country as first minister.\n\nSwinney, 60, succeeds Humza Yousaf, who formally resigned from the role earlier in the day, following his announcement last week that he would step down after just over a year in charge.\n\nYousaf, 39, announced his resignation last Monday before a confidence vote in the Scottish parliament that he was set to lose, having ditched his junior coalition partners, the Scottish Green Party, in a row over climate policy.\n\nSwinney won the backing of 64 members of the Scottish parliament (MSPs) in the vote that was all but a foregone conclusion, with nearest rival Scottish Conservatives leader Douglas Ross picking up 31.\n\nThe Scottish political veteran, said it was \"something of a surprise\" to find himself taking the top job at his stage of his career, but added it was \"an extraordinary privilege\".\n\n\"I am here to serve you. I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country,\" he told MSPs after accepting the nomination.\n\nSwinney, an old party hand who led the ruling pro-independence Scottish National Party (SNP) from 2000 to 2004 when the nationalists were in opposition, was elected unopposed as leader of the SNP on Monday.\n\nHe is seen as an experienced operator able to reach across the political divide, which is key to the SNP being able to rule as a minority government.\n\nSwinney must also unite his divided party, split between those on the left supportive of trans rights and urgent climate action and members on the right wanting to focus on issues such as health and the economy.\n\nHe has said that alongside advancing the case for Scottish independence, he wants to eradicate child poverty.\n\nBut he inherits a difficult political legacy, with former SNP leader and ally Nicola Sturgeon embroiled in a party funding scandal and a challenging domestic policy landscape.\n\nThe SNP is expected to lose several seats in the UK parliament to a resurgent Labour party at a general election due later this year.\n\nThe SNP currently holds 43 seats at Westminster. Labour hopes a comeback in its former stronghold of Scotland will help it win an outright majority in the nationwide vote.\n\nUK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said he looked forward to \"working constructively\" with Swinney \"on the real issues that matter to families -- delivering jobs, growth and better public services for people across Scotland\".\n\nCritics have accused the SNP, in power in the devolved parliament in Edinburgh for 17 years, of focusing on pursuing independence at the expense of issues like the cost-of-living crisis and education.\n\nThe party has struggled to rebuild momentum for another independence vote since Scotland voted against leaving the UK in a referendum in 2014.\n\nBut despite the SNP slumping in the polls since Sturgeon quit in March last year, support for independence continues to hover around the 40 percent mark, giving the party cause for hope.\n\nThe SNP holds 63 seats in the 129-member Scottish parliament, two short of a majority, meaning Swinney will need the support of other parties to pass legislation.\n\nHe has said he will not resurrect the defunct power-sharing deal between the SNP and the Scottish Greens, known as the Bute House Agreement, and will approach issues on a case-by-case basis.", "source": {"uri": "news24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "news24"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8116010827", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:26:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:26:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:25:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/politics/24304201.swinneys-coronation-attention-will-turn-cabinet-ministers/", "title": "Wee Ginger Dug: After Swinney's coronation attention will turn to cabinet ministers", "body": "Although the conclusion of the uncontested SNP leadership campaign yesterday marked the coronation of John Swinney as the new party leader, and next first minister of Scotland, his predecessor Humza Yousaf actually remained first minister until today.\n\nYousaf, first minister for just over a year, held his final cabinet meeting on Tuesday morning following which - as the rules of Holyrood dictate - he signed his formal letter of resignation to King Charles.\n\nThe acceptance of which by the head of state marks the exact moment at which he ceases to be the first minister.\n\nWhen that is accomplished Scotland technically has no first minister, but this is not a situation which will last long as MSPs are expected to vote on Tuesday afternoon to accept Swinney as the new first minister.\n\nBarring a last-minute unforeseen upset, Swinney will be elected as first minister with the support of the Scottish Greens, and will then lead a minority SNP government.\n\nREAD MORE: John Swinney to be Scotland's next first minister after Holyrood vote\n\nThe vote is scheduled to take place at 3 pm, and most of the opposition parties are likely to nominate their preferred candidate, each of whom will be called in alphabetical order to address the Chamber for up to five minutes.\n\nOnly Swinney has any chance of garnering sufficient votes to be elected as first minister, and if all goes well he will be elected as first minister by teatime.\n\nAfter winning the vote in Holyrood he will then attend the Court of Session to swear the oath of office, upon the completion of which formality he officially becomes Scotland's first minister.\n\nThe debate and vote will, as has become traditional, be marked by ill-tempered bad behaviour from a Scottish Tory contingent which has become significantly more boorish since Douglas Ross ousted Jackson Carlaw in a coup de prat, and by Anas Sarwar and his resting sneer face.\n\nJohn Swinney and Humza Yousaf share a hug before the vote for the next first minister\n\nBut all that is just so much theatrics for all that it's likely to generate a soundbite or two which will be eagerly seized upon by an anti-independence Scottish media which has just been deprived of the bitterly contested SNP leadership campaign that it had been looking forward to with such obvious relish.\n\nAttention will then switch to the announcement of Swinney's new cabinet.\n\nGreat heed will be paid to the post offered to former finance secretary Kate Forbes, Swinney's putative leadership rival, and flag bearer of the right of the party.\n\nThe two held meetings after Humza Yousaf stepped down following which Forbes put out a statement in which she spoke of the constructive and productive nature of the talks, praising her erstwhile rival, and announcing that she would be supporting Swinney as SNP leader and first minister.\n\nFor his part, Swinney sang Forbes' praises during the speech at which he officially launched his leadership bid and vowed to give her a prominent role in his new government.\n\nThere is speculation that Forbes will be offered either the post of finance secretary or deputy first minister when the new cabinet posts are announced.\n\nThe anti-independence parties are of course making their ritual calls that the new first minister abandon the 'distraction' of pursuing Scottish independence.\n\nHowever, the question of independence is not a 'distraction' in Scottish politics it is the central and defining issue of Scottish politics.\n\nIndependence is not a distraction from tackling poverty, climate change, the housing crisis, the ageing workforce or all the myriad of other issues which affect Scotland.\n\nIndependence is the key to unlocking the powers required to deal with them effectively and to find lasting solutions.\n\nREAD MORE: Tearful Humza Yousaf calls out 'daily' racism in final leader speech\n\nThe real distraction is pretending that the issue of independence must not be addressed, that's like saying a patient needs to take a paracetamol while ignoring a ruptured artery.\n\nThe truth is that the root cause of most of Scotland's economic, demographic, and political challenges is generations of Westminster misrule and until that is addressed nothing of substance will ever change.\n\nIndependence is an issue which is not going to go away no matter how much the Labour, Conservative, and Lib Dem parties wish it would.\n\nThe irony is that the power is entirely with the anti-independence parties to make the Scottish constitutional issue go away, they could do so by removing their election-denying undemocratic block on a second independence referendum.\n\nBut of course, we all know why they're not going to do that, and it's because they know that there is a very high chance that they could lose.\n\nIt is abundantly clear by now that the Labour, Conservative, and Lib Dem parties will only respect the democratic wishes of the people of Scotland as expressed through the ballot box when the people give them the result that they want.\n\nSo naturally they accepted the no vote in the 2014 independence referendum but found various ruses and excuses to explain away the result of the 2021 Scottish Parliamentary election which was fought on the central issue of a second independence referendum, and which produced a Scottish Parliament with its largest ever pro-independence majority.\n\nIt is to the lasting shame of the anti-independence media in Scotland that it not merely allowed the election denial of the Better Together parties to pass without serious challenge, but it actively colluded in enabling it.\n\nHowever, the immediate challenge facing the new first minister will be to unite the SNP and to bring some stability to his party after a torrid and at time, upsetting year.\n\nSwinney is perhaps the best-placed SNP politician to achieve that.\n\nHis task is to bring together the different factions within the SNP and to refocus the party on its core purpose, persuading the people of Scotland of the vital importance of Scottish independence and putting forward a plausible route to achieve it.\n\nIt will not be an easy task, and time is rapidly running out with a Westminster general election expected within the next few months and a resurgently and far more overtly right-wing British nationalist Labour party snapping at the SNP's heels, but with Swinney, the SNP is in a safe pair of hands.", "source": {"uri": "thenational.scot", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Scotland's First Minister in 'overwhelming' ceremony", "body": "Being sworn in as Scotland's new First Minister was an \"overwhelming moment\", John Swinney has said, as he vowed to stick to his pledge to give Kate Forbes a \"significant role\" in his team as he appoints his Cabinet.\n\nScotland's most senior judge, Lord President Lord Carloway, presided over the ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh on Wednesday morning where Mr Swinney made his statutory declarations and was granted his official title of First Minister and Keeper of the Scottish Seal.\n\nMr Swinney raised his right hand and bowed his head as Lord Carloway read the three oaths of office - for the role of First Minister, the Keeper of the Great Seal and the oath of allegiance to the King.\n\nMr Swinney's family, including his wife Elizabeth, brother David and 13-year-old son Matthew, accompanied him to court.\n\nSpeaking to reporters after the ceremony, Mr Swinney said taking the oaths had been an \"overwhelming moment\" and he spoke of his pride at being First Minister and his family's support.\n\n\"I look forward to dedicating my future to serving the people of Scotland.\n\n\"It's an precious\" to have his family at his side at the swearing in.\n\nAsked about former finance secretary Ms Forbes - who announced she would not run against him for the SNP leadership after a discussion {"uri": "8117416379", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:59:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:59:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:59:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/kate-forbes-made-deputy-first-minister-as-john-swinney-appoints-scottish-cabinet/a2025800512.html", "title": "Kate Forbes made Deputy First Minister as John Swinney appoints Scottish Cabinet", "body": "Kate Forbes has been appointed as John Swinney's Deputy First Minister as the SNP leader assembles his Cabinet.\n\nMs Forbes had challenged Humza Yousaf for the SNP leadership last year but opted not to stand against Mr Swinney, who had promised her a \"significant\" role in his Government.\n\nMr Swinney put party unity at the heart of his pitch to succeed Mr Yousaf as SNP leader.\n\nFormer finance minister Ms Forbes was the first to arrive at Mr Swinney's official residence in Edinburgh on Wednesday as he put together his top table.\n\nIn a statement, Ms Forbes said: \"I am deeply honoured to accept John's invitation to be his Deputy First Minister.\n\n\"This is a moment of extraordinary privilege for me. Having previously served in Cabinet, I know the duty that all ministers have to reflect the Government's priorities and the missions that drive them.\n\n\"I look forward to working with John and Cabinet colleagues, delivering for the people of Scotland and building a better country.\"\n\nShe succeeds Shona Robison as Deputy First Minister, who is moving to another role in Government.\n\nThe full list of Cabinet responsibilities is expected to be confirmed later on Wednesday.\n\nMr Swinney said: \"I am very pleased to appoint Kate as Deputy First Minister and look forward to working with her in this new Government.\n\n\"She is an immensely talented politician, and her new role will prove critical as we focus on our key commitments of eradicating child poverty, investing in public services and supporting economic growth.\"\n\nAs well as Ms Forbes, those seen entering Bute House for the Cabinet appointments include Wellbeing Economy, Energy and Net Zero Secretary Mairi McAllan, Transport Secretary Fiona Hyslop and Health Secretary Neil Gray.\n\nEarlier, Mr Swinney was questioned on what role he planned to give Ms Forbes, but would say only that he is \"a man of my word\" - referring to his speech last week where he said he wanted her to have a \"significant role\" in his team.\n\nHe also said being sworn in as Scotland's new First Minister was an \"overwhelming moment\".\n\nScotland's most senior judge, Lord President Lord Carloway, presided over the ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh on Wednesday morning where Mr Swinney made his statutory declarations and was granted his official title of First Minister and Keeper of the Scottish Seal.\n\nMr Swinney raised his right hand and bowed his head as Lord Carloway read the three oaths of office - for the role of First Minister, the Keeper of the Great Seal and the oath of allegiance to the King.\n\nThe Lord President then addressed the court about the independence of the judiciary.\n\nMr Swinney's family, including his wife Elizabeth, brother David and 13-year-old son Matthew, accompanied him to court.\n\nSpeaking to reporters after the ceremony, the Perthshire North MSP said: \"It's a really overwhelming moment to take the oath of office in front of the Lord President of the Court of Session and formally assume the role of First Minister,\" he said.\n\n\"I look forward to dedicating my future to serving the people of Scotland.\n\n\"It's an extraordinary opportunity to change lives for the better and I'll continue to use every moment that's available to me to do so.\"\n\nHe added: \"For my family this is a very abrupt change of our circumstances. We didn't think this would happening about 10 days ago.\"\n\nHe said they are making plans to adapt and it had been \"very precious\" to have his family at his side at the swearing in ceremony.\n\nHe had pledged to devote himself to the job after being voted into the role at Holyrood on Tuesday, and he becomes the seventh person to be First Minister since the Scottish Parliament was established 25 {"uri": "2024-05-350295934", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:37:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:37:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:27:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/john-swinney-scraps-post-minister-101757016.html", "title": "John Swinney scraps post of minister for independence to focus on economy", "body": "John Swinney has axed the post of minister for independence, in a clear signal to Scottish voters that his government is focused on their immediate cost of living concerns before the general election.\n\nThe post, held by Jamie Hepburn, was created by the previous first minister, Humza Yousaf, a year ago, with the main responsibility being publishing a series of papers on how different aspects of government would operate under Scottish independence. With no referendum imminent, opposition parties criticised the publications as a waste of taxpayers' money. The 13th in the series, on justice in an independent Scotland, was published last month.\n\nAlyn Smith MP, the Scottish National party's Europe spokesperson at Westminster, told BBC Radio Scotland's Good Morning Scotland programme that \"all of our government ministers are focused on independence in Europe\".\n\nSwinney said on Monday when he became the SNP leader that he wanted to persuade people of the case for independence by creating a \"vibrant economy\" and tackling challenges across public services.\n\nThe announcement came as part of Swinney's limited cabinet reshuffle on Wednesday. After being sworn in as first minister at the court of session, he appointed Kate Forbes as his deputy. The former finance secretary stepped aside to allow Swinney to stand unopposed for the SNP leadership.\n\nForbes, who narrowly lost to Yousaf in last year's leadership election to replace Nicola Sturgeon, is a social conservative who split the party when she disclosed she would not have voted for equal marriage. She has also been critical of the stalled gender recognition reform bill, which was passed with cross-party support at Holyrood, then blocked by Westminster.\n\nRelated: Making John Swinney leader may be the SNP's smartest move in years | Dani Garavelli\n\nAsked on Wednesday if she had a message for LGBTQ+ people after her return to cabinet, Forbes said she would support Swinney in \"finding places of consensus\".\n\nSwinney also brought back Ivan McKee, a key ally of Forbes and a respected business communicator, as minister for public finance. Emma Roddick, the minister tasked with guiding the bill to ban conversion practices through Holyrood, returns to the backbenches.\n\nPatrick Harvie, the Scottish Greens co-leader, accused Swinney during first minister's questions of sending a message to voters the Scottish government was now moving rightwards with Forbes's appointment.\n\n\"Yesterday that signal came pretty clearly: progressive ministers sacked and the second most powerful job in government given to someone who has opposed LGBT people's legal equality, who's expressed judgmental attitudes against abortion, and who's even expressed the view that people who have families without being married are doing something wrong,\" Harvie said, in reference to Forbes.\n\n\"Is this the Scottish government's vision for the future of Scotland, taking us back to the repressive values of the 1950s?\"\n\nSwinney rejected that attack, insisting his government would \"will be led from the moderate left of centre position that I have always occupied\".\n\nPressed again by Harvie, Swinney told MSPs: \"I want to lead a modern, dynamic and diverse Scotland, a place for everybody. Where everybody feels at home, at peace, that they have a place and that their place in our society is protected by my leadership of this country.\"\n\nSpeaking to BBC Radio Scotland on Thursday, Lorna Slater, the Scottish Greens' co-leader, said her party was experiencing a \"surge\" in membership, \"particularly people in the LGBTQ+ community are now looking at the SNP and thinking: 'Oh my goodness, is this really the home for me?'.\"\n\nSmith said\"Scotland's a big tent but we're too small a community to exclude people, and people of faith should have a role in politics.\" He said Having previously served in Cabinet, I know the duty that all ministers have to reflect the Government's priorities and the missions that drive them.\n\n\"I look forward to working with John and Cabinet colleagues, delivering for the people of Scotland and building a better country.\"\n\nShe succeeds Shona Robison as Deputy First Minister, who is moving to another role in Government.\n\nThe full list of Cabinet responsibilities is expected to be confirmed later on Wednesday.\n\nMr Swinney said: \"I am very pleased to appoint Kate as Deputy First Minister and look forward to working with her in this new Government.\n\n\"She is an immensely talented politician, and her new role will prove critical as we focus on our key commitments of eradicating child poverty, investing in public services and supporting economic growth.\"\n\nAs well as Ms Forbes, those seen entering Bute House for the Cabinet appointments include Wellbeing Economy, Energy and Net Zero Secretary Mairi McAllan, Transport Secretary Fiona Hyslop and Health Secretary Neil Gray.\n\nHe also said being sworn in as Scotland's new First Minister was an \"overwhelming moment\".\n\nMr Swinney raised his right hand and bowed his head as Lord Carloway read the three oaths of office - for the role of First Minister, the Keeper of the Great Seal and the oath of allegiance to the King.\n\nThe Lord President then addressed the court about the independence of the judiciary.\n\nMr Swinney's family, including his wife Elizabeth, brother David and 13-year-old son Matthew, accompanied him to court.\n\nSpeaking to reporters after the ceremony, the Perthshire North MSP said: \"It's a really overwhelming moment to take the oath of office in front of the Lord President of the Court of Session and formally assume the role of First Minister,\" he said.\n\n\"I look forward to dedicating my future to serving the people of Scotland.\n\n\"It's an extraordinary opportunity to change lives for the better and I'll continue to use every moment that's available to me to do so.\"\n\nHe said they are making plans to adapt and it had been \"very precious\" to have his family at his side at the swearing in ceremony.\n\nHe had pledged to devote himself to the job after being voted into the role at Holyrood on Tuesday, and he becomes the seventh person to be First Minister since the Scottish Parliament as he prepares to name his top team.\n\nThe new SNP leader has been sworn in at the Court of Session after being elected to the post at Holyrood yesterday.\n\nMr Swinney's family, including his wife Elizabeth, thirteen-year-old son Matthew and brother David, accompanied him for the ceremony.\n\nAttention now turns to his Cabinet, with questions over whether Kate Forbes will be handed the key post as his deputy amid tensions over her devout Christian views.\n\nDespite swipes that he is a 'Sturgeon apologist' and 'continuity' option, Mr Swinney was the only SNP leadership candidate when nominations closed on Monday.\n\nHe managed to convince former finance secretary Ms Forbes to get behind him rather than challenge him, with rumours she was promised a big job.\n\nJohn Swinney was officially installed as Scottish First Minister today - as he prepares to name his top team\n\nMr Swinney's family, including his wife Elizabeth, thirteen-year-old son Matthew and brother David, accompanied him for the ceremon\n\nThe new SNP leader has been sworn in at the Court of Session after being elected to the post at Holyrood yesterday\n\nJohn Swinney (pictured with wife Elizabeth at Bute House yesterday) will appoint his Cabinet today after being sworn in as First Minister\n\nThere are questions over whether Kate Forbes (pictured yesterday) will be handed the key post as Mr Swinney's deputy amid tensions over her devout Christian views\n\nAt Holyrood yesterday, Mr Swinney won the backing of 64 MSPs in a vote on the new First Minister, with his nearest rival Scottish Conservatives leader Douglas Ross picking up 31. As the Greens abstained that was enough for a simple majority.\n\nAfterwards he said: 'I am leading a minority government. I will need to reach out to others to make things happen to pass legislation to agree a budget.'\n\nHe said Holyrood was 'intensely polarised', adding: 'I accept my part in creating that environment, whether that is by shouting put-downs from the front bench or heckling from a sedantry position.\n\n'I do promise Presiding Officer, that that will all stop. I have changed.'\n\nAmid laughter in the chamber, he added: 'Perhaps time will tell on that one.'\n\nHumza Yousaf, whose extraordinary meltdown paved the way for Mr Swinney to take the top job, earlier penned his resignation to the King.\n\nIn a valedictory speech to MSPs he said: 'Let me offer thanks to every single colleague across the political divide for the kindnesses that you have shown me over the years.\n\n'We often, and I'm guilty of this too, lament the toxic nature of our political debate and it's true, there is entrenched tribalism that feels difficult to free ourselves from.\n\n'However I will remember far more fondly the kindness and generosity of colleagues over the years.'\n\nMr Swinney swerved a late obstacle on Monday as he persuaded activist Graeme McCormick not to go ahead with forcing a leadership contest, even though he had secured the support required to stand.\n\nMr Yousaf's time as First Minister was spent dealing with a long list of crises, including developments in the police probe into the SNP's funding and finances, a series of policy U-turns, disciplinary issues, defections and bitter infighting between factions in his party.\n\nA Norstat poll at the weekend showed the SNP is on course to fall to just 15 seats following the general election, and to slide behind Labour at the next Holyrood election.\n\nThe SNP vote share in a Westminster election was seen as dropping to its lowest level since the 2014 independence referendum.\n\nThe party would hold just 15 of its 43 seats with Scottish Labour winning 28 - a dramatic increase from its current two.\n\nHumza Yousaf officially quit as Scottish First minister yesterday paving the way for Mr Swinney to be installed\n\nMr Yousaf's fall from grace was sparked when he summarily ditched the coalition deal with the Greens in Scotland\n\nMr Yousaf signed his resignation letter to the King as the transition took effect\n\nAccording to the Sunday Times survey, the SNP had support from 29 per cent of the electorate - a fall of three points in a month, while Labour's share increased by two points to 34 per cent.\n\nUnder Nicola Sturgeon, the SNP became the third largest party at Westminster, winning 56 of 59 Scottish seats in 2015.\n\nThe Scottish Conservatives, whose vote share remained at 16 per cent in the poll, would add three seats to return nine MPs - I will need to reach out to others to make things happen to pass legislation to agree a budget.\"\n\nHe said Parliament is \"intensely polarised\", adding: \"I accept my part in creating that environment, whether that is by shouting put-downs from the front bench or heckling from a sedantry position.\n\n\"I do promise Presiding Officer, that that will all stop. I have changed.\"\n\nAmid laughter in the chamber, he added: \"Perhaps time will tell on that one.\"\n\nConcluding his speech at Holyrood, he said: \"To the people of Scotland, I would say simply this: I offer myself to be the First Minister for everyone in Scotland.\n\n\"I am here to serve you. I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country.\"\n\nSpeaking to reporters outside the Scottish Parliament chamber, John Swinney said: \"I think we've got off to a tremendous start. I think it's very clear that my party wants to move forward constructively and positively.\"\n\nThe veteran MSP said he is \"absolutely over the moon\" to have been voted in as First Minister.\n\nHe added: \"I didn't expect to become the First Minister of Scotland, despite my long involvement in politics and my long ministerial service.\n\n\"So, it's a bit of a surprise to have come to me at this particular moment.\n\n\"So, I'm thrilled. Having previously served in Cabinet, I know the duty that all ministers have to reflect the Government's priorities and the missions that drive them.\n\n\"I look forward to working with John and Cabinet colleagues, delivering for the people of Scotland and building a better country.\"\n\nShe succeeds Shona Robison as deputy first minister, who is moving to another role in Government.\n\nThe full list of Cabinet responsibilities is expected to be confirmed later on Wednesday.\n\nSwinney said: \"I am very pleased to appoint Kate as deputy first minister and look forward to working with her in this new Government.\n\n\"She is an immensely talented politician, and her new role will prove critical as we focus on our key commitments of eradicating child poverty, investing in public services and supporting economic growth.\"\n\nAs well as Forbes, those seen entering Bute House for the Cabinet appointments include energy secretary Mairi McAllan, transport secretary Fiona Hyslop and health secretary Neil Gray.\n\nEarlier, Swinney was questioned on what role he planned to give Forbes, but would say only that he is \"a man of my word\" - referring to his speech last week where he said he wanted her to have a \"significant role\" in his team.\n\nHe also said being sworn in as Scotland's new First Minister was an \"overwhelming moment\".\n\nScotland's most senior judge, Lord President Lord Carloway, presided over the ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh on Wednesday morning where Swinney made his statutory declarations and was granted his official title of First Minister and Keeper of the Scottish Seal.\n\nSwinney raised his right hand and bowed his head as Lord Carloway read the three oaths of office - for the role of First Minister, the Keeper of the Great Seal and the oath of allegiance to the King.\n\nThe Lord President then addressed the court about the independence of the judiciary.\n\nSwinney's family, including his wife Elizabeth, brother David and 13-year-old son Matthew, accompanied him to court.\n\nSpeaking to reporters after the ceremony, the Perthshire North MSP said: \"It's a really overwhelming moment to take the oath of office in front of the Lord President of the Court of Session and formally assume the role of First Minister,\" he said.\n\n\"I look forward to dedicating my future to serving the people of Scotland.\n\n\"It's an extraordinary opportunity to change lives for the better and I'll continue to use every moment that's available to me to do so.\"\n\nHe added: \"For my family this is a very abrupt change of our circumstances. We didn't think this would happening about ten days ago.\"\n\nHe said they are making plans to adapt and it had been \"very precious\" to have his family at his side at the swearing in ceremony.\n\nHe His nearest rival was Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross, who picked up 31.\n\nThe Scottish National Party (SNP) elected Swinney as its new leader on Monday after he emerged as the sole contender to pick a new premier.\n\nThe 60-year-old is a veteran who led the SNP from 2000 to 2004 when it was in opposition in the devolved Scottish parliament at Holyrood.\n\nWhen the SNP became the largest party in the parliament in 2007, Swinney was picked to be finance minister.\n\nBut the path ahead could prove rocky for the new first minister, with former SNP leader and ally Nicola Sturgeon embroiled in a party funding scandal.\n\nThe domestic policy landscape is also challenging, with inner party splits and a resurgent Labour Party threatening to take UK parliamentary seats from the SNP at the next election.\n\nYousaf was the first Muslim at the helm of a democratic Western European nation when he was inaugurated as first minister in 2023. However, he resigned last week in the wake of his decision to end a coalition deal with the Green Party.\n\nThat move backfired when it became clear that the party would struggle to rule as a minority {"uri": "8118153515", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:39:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:39:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:38:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13397389/TOM-HARRIS-Mr-Swinney-concluded-splendid-history-doesnt-look-kindly-touch.html", "title": "TOM HARRIS: History doesn't look kindly on out of touch leaders", "body": "The word 'continuity' was rendered toxic by Humza Yousaf's use of it to describe his own candidacy for the SNP leadership last year. It turned out that continuity was the last thing Scotland needed: continued failure to deliver on schools, hospitals, the economy and ferries.\n\nBut now the new First Minister, John Swinney, has rubber-stamped the Cabinet bequeathed to him by his predecessor. There are only two new faces, and both were ministers until Mr Yousaf became First Minister.\n\nThe first, rather obviously, is Mr Swinney himself. The other is Kate Forbes, who has been rewarded by her new boss for not plunging the SNP into another divisive leadership contest so close to an expected UK general election. She becomes Deputy First Minister - the youngest person ever to hold the post - and has been given the portfolio of Economy Secretary.\n\nIt's a canny move by Mr Swinney, even if he had to humiliate Shona Robison, the previous Deputy First Minister and finance secretary, by giving her most important title to Ms Forbes; after running Mr Yousaf a close second in last year's SNP leadership contest (Ms Forbes lost by a narrow 4 per cent margin), there was much criticism of the new First Minister when he offered his defeated rival the rural affairs brief, presumably knowing she would recognise it as the demotion it was and turn it down.\n\nJohn Swinney after being sworn in yesterday\n\nBut Mr Swinney has been in this game too long to make the same stupid mistake. He needs Ms Forbes on board if he is to persuade the country - and his party - that the SNP are once again united.\n\nYet given the seismic events of the past fortnight - Mr Yousaf's unforced error in unilaterally ending the Bute House Agreement with the Scottish Greens, his subsequent realisation that he would lose the vote of no confidence laid before Holyrood by the Scottish Conservatives, and his humiliating resignation statement a couple of days later - more of the same is the last thing Scotland needs.\n\nFrom the outside it looks like Mr Swinney has concluded that, since everything in the Scottish Government is going so splendidly, why bother making big changes?\n\nOrdinary Scots might have good reason to feel bemused at such a conclusion. Parents of school-age children, for example, have little reason to welcome the announcement that Jenny Gilruth, the Education Secretary, remains in post, our new First Minister having written 'ten out of ten' on her jotter.\n\nExcept, Scottish education standards are on the slide, falling ever further behind in international league tables and the much-vaunted Curriculum for Excellence is failing to prepare Scottish youngsters academically.\n\nAt health, Mr Swinney has given Neil Gray the thumbs-up and told him he should stay in post, despite one in seven Scots still languishing on one NHS waiting list or another.\n\nIf Mr Gray is the best person for this most crucial of jobs, it places a worrying question mark over the abilities of more junior, ambitious ministers and backbench nationalist MSPs.\n\nMeanwhile, the First Minister has given the green light to 'Airmiles Angus' Robertson, the cabinet secretary for a whole range of things that Holyrood has no responsibility for, including the constitution and external (or foreign) affairs. Mr Robertson has enjoyed his role of visiting other countries and spreading the gospel of independence while relying on the UK Foreign Office to make all the arrangements for his ego-flattering trips.\n\nIt seems that despite Mr Swinney's insistence on working with a range of opposition parties, he is happy to further erode relations with the UK Government by letting Mr Robertson flout diplomatic rules on behalf of his party.\n\nOne of the losers in this reshuffle is Energy and Net Zero Minister M\u00e0iri McAllan, whose responsibility for the economy has been given to Ms Forbes. She has committed her fair share of gaffes in her short ministerial career, recently welcoming Mr Swinney's candidacy for the leadership of her party as 'the right man for the moment', rather than 'the man of the moment' - which made it sound like the new First Minister was destined, like his predecessor, to be a temporary stopgap until a better leader came along.\n\nLast year, she caused much hilarity among her party's critics by suggesting that 'more often than not world leaders are approaching the Scottish Government asking for our advice on how we have managed to lead the way so successfully on a number of fronts'.\n\nUnfortunately, Ms McAllan was then unable to explain who these unfortunate world leaders were.\n\nWith these political titans ready to carry on business as usual, we may assume that the Scottish Government's own legislative agenda will be similarly unchanged and just as uninspiring.\n\nAll eyes will be on two key pieces of legislation: a Bill tackling misogyny and a ban on conversion therapy. Both are fraught with danger for the First Minister.\n\nHis predecessor has already confirmed that men, as well as women, will come under the protection of the new anti-misogyny Bill, provided they claim to be women themselves.\n\nThis raises an interesting problem: the new Deputy First Minister is a member of the Free Church of Scotland and is known to be sceptical of her party's agenda on trans rights under both Mr Yousaf and Nicola Sturgeon.\n\nOne of Mr Swinney's first acts as putative SNP leader was to avoid answering the question as to whether trans women (biological males) are women, which trans ideology holds to be the case.\n\nMs Forbes will lose much of her own credibility if she goes along with the party line on this sort of cultural issue, and Mr Swinney may be keen to avoid any sort of showdown with her.\n\nAnd this raises another problem for the SNP.\n\nPatrick Harvie, one of the two junior Scottish Green ministers unceremoniously sacked by Mr Yousaf a fortnight ago, reacted to Ms Forbes's elevation to the post of Deputy First Minister by tweeting a 'no right turn' sign.\n\nMr Harvie and his Scottish Greens co-leader, Lorna Slater, were only too happy to work with Ms Forbes, despite her personal views, when she held the powerful finance portfolio under Ms Sturgeon.\n\nBut now the bitterness of their treatment by the party - and the fact that Mr Swinney has already ruled out any possibility of the Bute House Agreement being resurrected - looks set to be a major barrier to the small, extremist party offering its support to this minority SNP government.\n\nMr Swinney has surveyed the problems besetting Scotland, and he has decided that everything is fine and that no major changes are required.\n\nThat is his privilege.\n\nHowever, history does not look kindly on political leaders who are so out of touch that their attitude becomes: 'Crisis? The Scottish political veteran, said it was \"something of a surprise\" to find himself taking the top job at his stage of his career, but added it was \"an extraordinary privilege\".\n\n\"I am here to serve you. I will give everything I have to build the best future for our country,\" he told MSPs after accepting the nomination.\n\nSwinney, an old party hand who led the ruling pro-independence Scottish Natio\u00adnal Party (SNP) from 2000 to 2004 when the nationalists were in opposition, was elected unopposed as leader of the SNP on Monday. {"uri": "8117109578", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "09:55:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T09:55:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T09:55:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/john-swinney-sworn-in-as-scotlands-first-minister-1622773.html", "title": "John Swinney sworn in as Scotland's first minister | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "John Swinney has been sworn in as the new first minister of Scotland and is expected to appoint his Cabinet later.\n\nThe ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh on Wednesday morning saw Mr Swinney make his statutory declarations and be granted his official title of First Minister and Keeper of the Scottish Seal.\n\nScotland's most senior judge, Lord President Lord Carloway, presided over the ceremony.\n\nMr Swinney raised his right hand and bowed his head as Lord Carloway read the three oaths of office - for the role of First Minister, the Keeper of the Great Seal and and the oath of allegiance to Britain's King Charles.\n\nThe Lord President then addressed the court about the independence of the judiciary.\n\nMr Swinney's family, including his wife Elizabeth, brother David and 13-year-old son Matthew, accompanied him to court.\n\nThe Perthshire North MSP pledged to devote himself to the job after being voted into the role at Holyrood on Tuesday, and he becomes the seventh person to be first minister since the Scottish Parliament was established 25 years ago. It came following an unopposed SNP selection process a week after predecessor Humza Yousaf resigned.\n\nMr Swinney said it is an \"extraordinary privilege\" to become Scotland's new first minister as he pledged to \"give everything I have\" to the role.\n\nHe shook hands with opposition leaders in the chamber at the Scottish Parliament after the vote.\n\nMr Swinney told the other parties at Holyrood: \"If we want to fund our schools and hospitals, if we want to give our businesses a competitive edge, if we want to tackle climate action, if we want to eradicate child poverty, if we want to change people's lives for the better, we have got to work together to do so.\"\n\nHe said he will \"give all of my energy and my willingness\" to achieve this, committing to be \"the First Minister for everyone in Scotland\".\n\nHe thanked his wife, who has multiple sclerosis, making clear his \"profound eternal gratitude\" to her for \"the sacrifices she is prepared to make\" so he can take on It came following the SNP leadership race in which he stood unopposed.\n\nRead more:\n\nWho is John Swinney?\n\nMr Swinney, who was deputy first minister under Nicola Sturgeon, previously said he is \"no interim leader\" and intends to lead the SNP beyond the next general and Scottish elections.\n\nHe has vowed to focus on the economy, jobs, the cost of living, the NHS, education, public pledged to \"give everything I have\" to the role.\n\nHe shook hands with opposition leaders in the chamber at the Scottish Parliament after the vote.\n\nSwinney told the other parties at Holyrood: {"uri": "8117502330", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:53:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:53:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:53:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/0ce43d71-a99a-4ee5-8ea8-a625e80014d6", "title": "Kate Forbes appointed deputy first minister of Scotland", "body": "John Swinney, Scotland's new first minister, has appointed Kate Forbes as deputy first minister.\n\nForbes, who was beaten by former first minister Humza Yousaf in last year's leadership election, said being given the role was a \"moment of extraordinary privilege\".\n\nShe decided not to run for leader of the Scottish National party after Yousaf's resignation just over a week ago. Swinney had promised her a significant government role as he seeks to reunite the party.\n\nForbes will work with Swinney to support economic growth, invest in public services and eradicate child poverty, a statement said.\n\nShona Robison has stepped down as deputy first minister but will remain in cabinet.\n\nSwinney described Forbes, who in 2020 became Scotland's first female finance secretary, as \"an immensely talented politician\".\n\nA committed Christian, she is on the right of the party in terms of social and economic policy. Socially conservative views aired during her leadership campaign last year about issues such as gay marriage damaged her standing among liberals.\n\nSwinney has pledged a moderate centre-left policy platform that addresses mainstream concerns as he seeks to roll back a surge in support for Scottish Labour that could result in the loss of many seats in central Scotland at the general election expected this year.\n\nSwinney, who led the nationalist party in opposition between 2000 and 2004, was earlier on Wednesday sworn in as head of the Scottish government at the Court of Session.\n\nThe 60-year-old Swinney, who won a parliamentary ballot to succeed Yousaf on Tuesday, told journalists after the ceremony at Scotland's highest civil court that taking the oaths of office had been an \"overwhelming moment\".\n\nThe former deputy first minister and finance secretary has said he will work with parties across Holyrood to deliver legislation as a minority government.\n\nSwinney has {"uri": "8117717122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:12:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:12:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:12:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/uknews/2024/05/08/swinney-appoints-largely-unchanged-cabinet-but-forbes-returns-as-his-deputy/", "title": "Swinney appoints largely unchanged Cabinet but Forbes returns as his deputy", "body": "Kate Forbes has become Scotland's youngest ever Deputy First Minister as John Swinney announced a largely unchanged Cabinet team.\n\nMs Forbes, 34, a former Holyrood finance secretary, had been tipped to run for the SNP leadership again after Humza Yousaf stood down just over a week ago, but she instead opted to back Mr Swinney and he went on to claim the position of party leader unopposed.\n\nHe has now rewarded her by making her his deputy, and also giving her responsibility for the economy and Gaelic.\n\nBy giving such a key role to Ms Forbes, a critic of some Scottish Government policies who had been on the backbenches during Mr Yousaf's time in charge, Mr Swinney will hope to ease internal tensions within the SNP.\n\nSpeaking after his top team was announced, Mr Swinney said he is \"committed to working collaboratively across the Parliament to address the pressing issues facing the people of Scotland\".\n\nThat will be required as the SNP is now a minority administration at Holyrood after Mr Yousaf tore up the powersharing deal the party had with the Scottish Greens - a move which ultimately led to his resignation as first minister.\n\nMr Swinney's Cabinet includes eight women - thought to be the most ever - and two other men.\n\nNeil Gray, who was appointed Health Secretary earlier this year, stays in the post, while Angus Robertson remains Constitution, External Affairs and Culture Secretary.\n\nShona Robison, who had been deputy first minister under Mr Yousaf, loses that position but remains in the Cabinet - keeping her finance brief and also taking on responsibility for local government.\n\nMairi McAllan remains in the Cabinet but with a slightly slimmed down brief - she had been the net zero, wellbeing economy and energy secretary, but now has responsibility for net zero and energy.\n\nShirley-Anne Sommerville and Mairi Gougeon also continue in their previous roles - as Social Justice Secretary, and Rural Affairs, Land Reform and Islands Secretary respectively.\n\nMr Swinney said: \"I have selected a Cabinet team that blends experience and energy, with a strong focus on the priorities my Government will pursue - eradicating child poverty, driving economic growth, meeting climate obligations and investing in our vital public services.\n\n\"My overriding priority will be to work to eradicate child poverty in Scotland, an issue on which real progress has been made through measures such as the Scottish child payment.\n\nMs Forbes said she was \"deeply honoured\" to be appointed as his deputy, describing it as an \"extraordinary privilege\".\n\nShe added: \"I look forward to working with John and Cabinet colleagues, delivering for the people of Scotland and building a better country.\"\n\nSpeaking earlier on Wednesday after he was sworn into office at the Court of Session, Mr Swinney had said: \"It's a really overwhelming moment to take the oath of office in front of the Lord President of the Court of Session and formally assume the role of First Minister.\n\n\"I look forward to dedicating my future to serving the people of Scotland.\n\n\"It's an extraordinary opportunity to change lives for the better and I'll continue to use every moment that's available to me to do so.\"", "source": {"uri": "jerseyeveningpost.com",
