{"uri": "8118540041", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:51:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:51:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T05:49:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/politics/viewpoint/24306317.john-swinney-must-spring-humza-yousafs-indey-trap/", "title": "Neil Mackay: John Swinney must spring Humza Yousaf's independence trap", "body": "The juvenile sneers of \"boring\" directed at both men show just how detached their opponents are from the disgust most now feel towards showboating politicians with flamboyant, phoney agendas.\n\nSwinney is also a man of admirable personal qualities. The notes he's hit have been pitch-perfect to many ears.\n\nHe's rejected tribalism, said he'd govern for \"everyone in Scotland\", shown a degree of vulnerability when speaking of his personal exhaustion, was honest in his assessment of Holyrood dysfunction, held up his hands admitting his part in polarisation, and promised to focus on what matters: the economy, jobs, the cost of living, the NHS, schools, and child poverty.\n\nThe tributes he paid to his wife, who has multiple sclerosis, were the very model of modern manhood: empathetic, emotionally aware, and drained of braggadocio.\n\nHowever, one can admire an individual's personal qualities and still doubt their wisdom. For Swinney's positioning on independence is a trap waiting to spring and destroy his premiership. He could well become Scotland's shortest-served First Minister unless he changes tack.\n\nHe is wedded to Humza Yousaf's independence strategy. In doing so, he makes himself hostage to an absurd policy.\n\nThe word \"strategy\" has no place attached to the SNP's childish independence plan. It involves the SNP winning the majority of Scottish seats at the next General Election. This, apparently, would allow the Scottish Government to begin negotiations for either independence or another referendum.\n\nThe party's veteran MP Pete Wishart rightly brands it a \"total mess\". There's so much wrong with this \"policy'\" First, the SNP will likely face a walloping from Labour. Latest polling shows the party holding just 15 of its 43 seats, with Scottish Labour taking 28.\n\nSo Swinney is backing a policy consistently undermined by polling. That's just the electoral mathematics. The political strategy is worse.\n\nEven if the SNP were to win a majority of seats - which clearly isn't a majority of votes - are we to imagine that newly-installed Prime Minister Starmer will agree to a referendum which, if he lost, would force him to resign?\n\nIf Swinney goes into a General Election on a manifesto pledge that he will win a majority of seats, thereby triggering independence or another referendum, and fails, then he's done.\n\nHe would become a victim of his own orderly style of leadership. How could a man of honour not step down in the event of failing to meet his key electoral promise? Swinney would cease to be a man of honour if he remained in office.\n\nWhy would he do this to himself? Why would he do this to Scotland if he thinks he can turn the ship of state around? This egregious scheme seems to undermine everything he represents.\n\nREAD MORE BY NEIL MACKAY:\n\nHatred of the SNP and the left is now at absurd levels of radicalisation\n\nSwinney wanted an election when Tories changed leader, he should face one himself\n\nHumza Yousaf deserves to fall and Scotland deserves an election\n\nEvidently, Swinney may well be banking on reversing polls. He may hope that by the time the General Election comes the chaos that's engulfed the Scottish Government for quite some time will be waning in memories and those who drifted despondently to Labour will be returning to the SNP.\n\nWell, as our grandmothers told us: \"You know what hope did.\" If Swinney tacks to the right economically, he won't win back soft independence voters considering voting Labour. If more feuding breaks out in the SNP - and that's as likely as the sunrise these days - then his claims of stable government are dust. If he fails to break the polarisation in parliament and cannot pass legislation as a minority government, then his promises are hollow.\n\nThere are lots of moving parts for Swinney to consider. He does not want a spoke going through his wheel, and his independence strategy is a spoke as big as a tree trunk.\n\nThe biggest problem he faces is that in order to keep his indy pledge he needs to maintain the SNP's hunger for campaigning rather than governing. The public doesn't want more \"hopes and dreams\", more politicians distracted by imagined utopias.\n\nThe public want some jam on the bread. Nor will more indy campaigning be a mark of a politician governing for \"everyone in Scotland'\" it would simply further the nation's divide.\n\nLabour should be cringing at their role in dethroning Humza Yousaf and helping crown Swinney. With Yousaf in power the General Election would have been a much easier battle.\n\nSwinney presents real challenges to Labour. But his indy strategy gives solace to Anas Sarwar. It's not just a fracture point for Swinney, but a possible trigger for his own resignation.\n\nSwinney's fall would usher in more chaos inside the SNP ahead of the Holyrood election, playing straight into Labour's hands.\n\nWill John Swinney dump Humza Yousaf's independence plan? (Image: PA)\n\nSNP supporters can only hope that Swinney - as a now very busy man - is simply using Yousaf's old strategy as a holding pattern, and will soon dump it.\n\nHe has acknowledged independence isn't \"frustratingly close\" as Yousaf said while resigning. So his commitment to his predecessor's independence policy is bizarre.\n\nIndependence - which I support - remains distant. The SNP hasn't done the work to improve what independence means since 2014.\n\nThe party should have governed its way to independence by preforming so well the public could see the benefits of Scotland striking out alone. Instead, nationalists governed miserably. Independence support hasn't shifted since 2014.\n\nSwinney should say that independence is off the table until his party raises support to 60% over a prolonged period. When that happens, he can confront the UK Government in a showdown for the right to a referendum with the people of Scotland behind him.\n\nDumping the current absurd indy plan would allow Swinney to go into an election, he may very well lose, with the ability to survive defeat. He would be able to say that he'd done his best against a backdrop of chaos, without being honour-bound to resign over the independence plan.\n\nIf Swinney cannot see this, then he's not the man of clear-sighted intelligence Scotland needs right now.\n\nHe has vowed he'll be no \"interim leader\". However, this dismal independence strategy is the very policy to ensure that he is remembered by the one word he rejects: 'caretaker'.", "source": {"uri": "heraldscotland.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8119527117", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:07:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:07:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:07:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/scottish-greens-vote-against-appointment-155548458.html", "title": "Kate Forbes elected Scotland deputy first minister despite Green opposition", "body": "The Scottish Greens have voted against Kate Forbes becoming Scotland's new deputy first minister in a fresh row over her conservative views on equality.\n\nRoss Greer, a Scottish Green MSP, said that as a gay Christian he was unable to support a minister \"who feels there is something wrong with us\" and said all seven Green MSPs would oppose her appointment.\n\nDuring the vote on John Swinney's cabinet nominations, the Greens were joined by Labour and the Conservatives in opposing her appointment. The Liberal Democrats abstained, giving Swinney a narrow majority because some opposition MSPs were absent.\n\nThe dispute opens up a fresh rift between the Scottish government's former coalition partners and the first minister, Swinney, the day after he confirmed Forbes would be his deputy and also deleted the post of minister for independence.\n\nSwinney appointed Forbes partly in return for her dropping her bid to stand against him for the Scottish National party's leadership, but chiefly to signal to disenchanted voters the SNP was shifting back to the political centre ground before the general election.\n\nThe row over Forbes's conservative evangelical beliefs, based on Free Church of Scotland teachings, erupted at first minister's questions. Patrick Harvie, the Scottish Greens' co-leader, said her appointment signalled a return \"to the repressive values of the 1950s\".\n\nSwinney rejected Harvie's criticisms. He said Forbes had presided over progressive tax changes and the introduction of the Scottish child payment while finance secretary. The first minister, who like Greer is a member of the Church of Scotland, said he took Harvie's challenges \"very seriously\".\n\n\"When I say that I want to be the first minister for everyone in Scotland, I deeply mean that,\" Swinney added. \"I want to lead a modern, dynamic and diverse Scotland, a place for everybody. Where everybody feels at home, at peace, that they have a place and that their place in our society is protected by my leadership of this country.\"\n\nGreer dismissed those reassurances. He said that he, Forbes and Swinney all believed in Christ, and that he knew Swinney \"shares in the joy\" that LGBT people felt about Scotland's equal marriage reforms.\n\n\"Faith is not the issue here,\" he added. \"The issue is that I am being asked to vote for someone who thinks there is something wrong with me, not because of any views I hold but simply because of who I am.\n\n\"Yesterday Kate Forbes was given the opportunity to reassure LGBT people in a question asked by ITV News. She did not. The first minister had to step in just to say the word LGBT.\"\n\nGreer added that over the last few years it felt as if Scotland \"was going backwards\" on LGBT rights. It was a reference to the bitter disputes over gender recognition and transgender rights, which Swinney's advisers believe have lost them centre-ground voters.\n\nThe Greens claim the former first minister Humza Yousaf's disastrous decision to scrap the Bute House agreement between the SNP and the Greens which precipitated his resignation, and Forbes's re-emergence in government, has led SNP members to defect to the Greens.\n\nHarvie's co-leader, Lorna Slater, told BBC Radio Scotland her party was experiencing a \"surge\" in membership, \"particularly people in the LGBTQ+ community [who] are now looking at the SNP and thinking: 'Oh my goodness, is this really the home for me?'\"\n\nAlyn Smith, an SNP MP who has championed gay equality within his party, defended the principle of Forbes's appointment. \"Scotland's a big tent but we're too small a community to exclude people, and people of faith should have a role in politics,\" he told the same programme.\n\nForbes's position on equality issues was \"a matter for her to work through her conscience\", he said.\n\nLater on Thursday, Out for Indy - the SNP's affiliate group for LGBTQ+ members - issued a statement asking for \"urgent clarification\" from Swinney and Forbes that policies such as the forthcoming ban on conversion practices \"will not be stalled or removed from the programme for government\".\n\nThe statement added: \"At a time when the LGBTQ+ community - especially trans people - face unprecedented violence and attacks both within and outwith politics, more needs to be done to reassure the community - and to assure that the SNP's legacy of fighting for LGBTQ+ rights is not undermined.\"\n\nLGBTQ+ SNP members have told the Guardian they have profound concerns about the \"direction of travel\" signalled over recent days as much as for the future of individual policies, pointing to Yousaf's election pledge last year not just to protect but to advance their rights, and lack of similar assurances from the new leadership.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118137895", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:21:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:21:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:20:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13397357/EUAN-MCCOLM-Return-Forbes-shows-SNP-hit-new-depths-dysfunction.html", "title": "MCCOLM: Return of Forbes shows SNP has hit new depths of dysfunction", "body": "If you want to know how hopelessly dysfunctional the SNP has become, just consider the selection of Kate Forbes by John \u00adSwinney to be his Deputy First Minister.\n\nLast year Ms Forbes stood as a candidate in the race to succeed Nicola Sturgeon as leader of the SNP and First Minister. The MSP for Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch had been identified by Ms \u00adSturgeon as a rising star and set on the fast-track to the top.\n\nBut days into her campaign, Ms Forbes made a schoolgirl error in the world of Nationalist politics: she was asked a question to which she gave an honest answer.\n\nMs Forbes, a member of the socially conservative Free Church of Scotland, admitted that, if she had been a member of the Scottish parliament at the time the matter was being considered, she would have voted against gay marriage.\n\nSuddenly, Ms Forbes was no longer the Sturgeon-championed embodiment of a bright new future but a pariah to be shunned. Horrified senior SNP figures briefed heavily that victory for the young Christian - 34 last month - would be a disaster. She would drag their glorious, progressive party back into the dark ages.\n\nKate Forbes arrives at Bute House after First Minister John Swinney was sworn in at the Court of Session\n\nThat Humza Yousaf, a Muslim, had been an MSP at the time of equal marriage legislation and had not participated in the final vote was brushed away. Sure, he might not have voted but, don't forget, Ms Forbes said she'd have voted against. Didn't that make her much worse?\n\nIn the end, Ms Forbes couldn't defeat SNP establishment favourite Mr Yousaf. But the margin of his victory - 52 per cent to 48 per cent - showed her social conservatism wasn't as out of step with voters as her colleagues might have told themselves.\n\nOne of Mr Yousaf's first \u00addecisions on becoming First Minister showed how insecure he was about Ms Forbes's presence in the upper echelons of the SNP. Rather than having the confidence to bring her into a senior role, he offered her a demotion which - sensibly - she rejected.\n\nWhen, after his disastrous handling of the end of the power-sharing agreement between the SNP and the Greens, Mr Yousaf resigned as First Minister, a week and a half ago, he resurrected the 'Forbes problem'.\n\nAssisted by having been nowhere near Mr Yousaf's government, Ms Forbes was immediately named a frontrunner to become Scotland's seventh First Minister.\n\nCue an outbreak of conniptions across the SNP. There was no way Scotland, a Christian country, could have an openly Christian leader. This was a disaster waiting to happen. Senior figures worried that years of telling a story of Scotland as uniquely progressive and radical would be forgotten with the election of Ms Forbes.\n\nWhen Mr Swinney announced, last Thursday, his intention to stand for the leadership of the SNP, he spoke about this being the right decision for his party and for Scotland.\n\nThis was all terribly noble and moving but the truth was - and will be for the duration of his leadership - that he scrapped his retirement plans to stop Ms Forbes becoming First Minister.\n\nSenior SNP figures - including Ms Sturgeon - urged Mr Swinney to step forward and end the prospect of a Forbes-led party.\n\nYou might think that, for Mr Swinney to have decided the idea of Ms Forbes as First Minister was so unthinkable that he stood for a job he didn't actually want, she must be unusually unsuited to the world of politics. But, as is so often the case when it comes to the SNP, things don't have to make a great deal of sense.\n\nAnd so, yesterday, Mr Swinney announced that Ms Forbes - who he last year wondered whether was an 'appropriate individual' to lead his party - is to be his Deputy First Minister.\n\nA major reason supporters of Ms Sturgeon were so vehemently opposed to Ms Forbes becoming party leader was her opposition to plans to reform the Gender Recognition Act to allow people to self-ID into the sex of their choosing.\n\nMs Forbes shares the concerns of many who believe changing the law would undermine the rights of women and girls.\n\nMr Swinney has said he will work across political divides to take forward his government's agenda. Given their position on gender issue - some MSPs are angry that the NHS has stopped giving experimental, life-altering 'puberty blocker' drugs to children confused about their gender - the Scottish Greens are unlikely to be in the mood to co-operate.\n\nThis would be one very positive outcome from the SNP-generated chaos engulfing Scottish politics.\n\nThe Greens are no longer a credible party of the environment. Now they are cranks, encouraging the reckless medical treatment of children and denouncing anyone who disagrees as a bigot.\n\nThe return of Kate Forbes to government in such a senior position may help the SNP move away from the fringes and back to the political centre where it might start to deal with the things - such as the NHS, education and the economy - that matter to voters.\n\nMeanwhile, the crumbling government is held together by a First Minister who didn't want the job and a deputy so divisive that many of her Cabinet colleagues devoted much of the past two weeks to briefing heavily against her.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": It came following an unopposed SNP selection process a week after predecessor Humza Yousaf resigned.\n\nMr Swinney said it is an \"extraordinary privilege\" to become Scotland's new First Minister as he pledged to \"give everything I have\" to the role.\n\nHe shook hands with opposition leaders in the chamber at the Scottish Parliament after the vote.\n\nMr Swinney told the other parties at Swinney for the top job, which was made vacant with the sudden resignation of Humza Yousaf just over a week ago.\n\nBut the 34-year-old chose not to stand in this month's SNP leadership contest, in part to avoid a repeat of the last one she lost a year ago that exposed deep internal divisions from which the party is still struggling to recover.\n\nSwinney, who was elected unopposed as SNP leader on Monday and was sworn in as first minister on Wednesday, said Forbes will now succeed Shona Robison as Scotland's deputy first minister.\n\nThe appointment comes as Swinney tries to unite his {"uri": "8119402752", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:34:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:34:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:34:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.basingstokegazette.co.uk/news/national/24307731.holyrood-approves-appointment-kate-forbes-deputy-first-minister/", "title": "Holyrood approves appointment of Kate Forbes as Deputy First Minister", "body": "John Swinney's new ministerial team, which includes Kate Forbes as Deputy First Minister, has officially been appointed following a Holyrood vote.\n\nBut the First Minister faced his first challenge leading a minority Government with Ms Forbes's appointment only narrowly backed after the Conservatives, Labour and the Greens voted against.\n\nThree Scottish Liberal Democrats abstained, meaning the appointment passed by 63 votes - the number of SNP MSPs - to 57 against, while six MSPs did not vote.\n\nThe Holyrood vote also saw Ivan McKee appointed as public finance minister, passing with 63 votes to 47, with 10 abstentions.\n\nOpposition to Ms Forbes's Government post follows comments she made on her social views, particularly those on gay marriage and abortion rights, during the 2023 SNP leadership contest.\n\nScottish Green MSP Ross Greer told the First Minister prior to the vote: \"John Swinney knows the esteem that I hold him in.\n\n\"But today he is asking me, and other members of this Parliament who are LGBT, to appoint to the second highest office in this country an individual who believes it was wrong that Parliament granted us the same legal rights as everyone else 10 years ago.\n\n\"I cannot, the Scottish Greens cannot, support the appointment of someone who fundamentally does not believe that everyone in Scotland is equal, worthy of equal rights and respect under the law.\n\n\"We cannot support the appointment of someone who believes that equal marriage is wrong, but also that being born out of marriage, so we will oppose the appointment of Kate Forbes for Deputy First Minister.\"\n\nMr Greer also quoted Mr Swinney, who said he did not hold the same views as Ms Forbes despite being a man of \"deep faith\".\n\nResponding, Mr Swinney said he wants everyone in Scotland to feel represented by the Scottish Government.\n\nHe said: \"I come to these conclusions from a very deep Christian faith.\n\n\"I believe that we are equal in the eyes of God. Every one of us. I hope those comments, which are more forthright about faith than I have ever uttered in my 45 years in politics, will perhaps illustrate to Parliament the magnitude of the seriousness with which I take the issues that Mr Greer puts to me.\"\n\nScottish Tory deputy leader Meghan Gallacher said her party does not support the ministerial appointments.\n\nShe said: \"Instead, we are putting down a marker that this Government must change its approach.\n\n\"The Scottish Conservatives will take every opportunity to oppose this SNP Government and its obsession with independence, but this does not mean that we are not above working with other parties across Parliament to deliver on the real priorities of the Scottish people.\"\n\nScottish Labour's Martin Whitfield said: \"I fear the ambition to work in Scotland's best interests is lacking in this Government.\n\n\"After 17 years of failure, every single institution in Scotland is weaker and those responsible still remain at the heart of Government.\n\n\"Our country needs effective leadership. While I wish genuinely all the ministers who are appointed today well, I feel the task ahead is beyond them.\"\n\nHowever, Scottish Liberal Democrat MSP Willie Rennie said his party would not block the appointments.\n\nHe said: \"We may have a difference of views on equalities, but Kate Forbes does deserve a chance to govern putting those views to one side.\"\n\nThe rest of Mr Swinney's Cabinet is largely unchanged from that under his predecessor Humza Yousaf, with former deputy first minister Shona Robison remaining in the finance brief.\n\nThe minister for independence role has been dropped, with Jamie Hepburn who held the post moved to minister for parliamentary business.\n\nThe ministerial reshuffle saw George Adam, Emma Roddick and Joe Fitzpatrick step down from their roles.\n\nConsisting of 11 Cabinet secretaries, including the First Minister, the Scottish Cabinet is supported by 14 ministers, reducing the size of the Scottish Government by four since the start of {"uri": "2024-05-350489565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:45:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:45:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:36:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/scottish-greens-vote-against-appointment-155548458.html", "title": "Kate Forbes elected Scotland deputy first minister despite Green opposition", "body": "The Scottish Greens have voted against Kate Forbes's appointment as Scotland's new deputy first minister in a fresh row over her conservative views on equality.\n\nRoss Greer, a Scottish Green MSP, said that as a gay Christian he was unable to support a minister \"who feels there is something wrong with us\" and said all seven Green MSPs would oppose her appointment.\n\nDuring the vote on Swinney's cabinet nominations, the Greens were joined by Labour and the Conservatives in opposing her appointment. The Liberal Democrats abstained, giving Swinney a narrow majority because some opposition MSPs were absent.\n\nThe dispute opens up a fresh rift between the Scottish government's former coalition partners and the first minister, John Swinney, the day after he confirmed Forbes would be his deputy and also deleted the post of minister for independence.\n\nSwinney appointed Forbes partly in return for dropping her bid to stand against him for the Scottish National party's leadership, but chiefly to signal to disenchanted voters the SNP was shifting back to the political centre ground before the general election.\n\nThe row over Forbes's conservative evangelical beliefs, based on Free Church of Scotland teachings, erupted at first minister's questions. Patrick Harvie, the Scottish Greens' co-leader, said her appointment signalled a return \"to the repressive values of the 1950s\".\n\nSwinney rejected Harvie's criticisms. He said Forbes had presided over progressive tax changes and the introduction of the Scottish child payment while finance secretary. The first minister, who like Greer is a member of the Church of Scotland, said he took Harvie's challenges \"very seriously\".\n\n\"When I say that I want to be the first minister for everyone in Scotland, I deeply mean that,\" Swinney added. \"I want to lead a modern, dynamic and diverse Scotland, a place for everybody. Where everybody feels at home, at peace, that they have a place and that their place in our society is protected by my leadership of this country.\"\n\nGreer dismissed those reassurances. He said that he, Forbes and Swinney all believed in Christ, and that he knew Swinney \"shares in the joy\" that LGBT people felt about Scotland's equal marriage reforms.\n\n\"Faith is not the issue here,\" he added. \"The issue is that I am being asked to vote for someone who thinks there is something wrong with me, not because of any views I hold but simply because of who I am.\n\n\"Yesterday Kate Forbes was given the opportunity to reassure LGBT people in a question asked by ITV News. She did not. The first minister had to step in just to say the word LGBT.\"\n\nGreer added that over the last few years it felt as if Scotland \"was going backwards\" on LGBT rights - a reference to the bitter disputes over gender recognition and transgender rights, which Swinney's advisers believe have lost them centre-ground voters.\n\nThe Greens claim the former first minister Humza Yousaf's disastrous decision to scrap the Bute House agreement between the SNP and the Greens which precipitated his resignation, and Forbes's reemergence in government, has led SNP members to defect to the Greens.\n\nHarvie's fellow co-leader, Lorna Slater, told BBC Radio Scotland her party was experiencing a \"surge\" in membership, \"particularly people in the LGBTQ+ community [who] are now looking at the SNP and thinking: 'Oh my goodness, is this really the home for me?'\"\n\nAlyn Smith, an SNP MP who has championed gay equality within his party, defended the principle of Forbes's appointment. \"Scotland's a big tent but we're too small a community to exclude people, and people of faith should have a role in politics,\" he told the same programme.\n\nForbes's position on equality issues was - see the full list of appointments", "body": "FIRST Minister John Swinney has named his new Scottish Cabinet.\n\nThe new SNP leader was officially sworn in as Scotland's seventh First Minister on Wednesday, after being confirmed by a vote of MSPs on Tuesday.\n\nSwinney will lead a minority SNP government and familiar faces from the party, including likely future leadership contenders such as Kate Forbes and Mairi McAllan, were seen entering Bute House on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nForbes will take economy portfolio and responsibility for Gaelic, as well as the Deputy First Minister brief.\n\nShona Robison, who Forbes replaced as deputy first minister on Wednesday, will take on the finance and local government briefs.\n\nIn all there are eleven members of the Cabinet, which is majority female.\n\nCommenting on the Cabinet appointments, First Minister Swinney said: \"Ahead of my appointment as First Minister, I committed to working collaboratively across the Parliament to address the pressing issues facing the people of Scotland.\n\n\"With that in mind, I have selected a Cabinet team that blends experience and energy, with a strong focus on the priorities my Government will pursue - eradicating child poverty, driving economic growth, meeting climate obligations and investing in our vital public services.\"\n\nHe added: \"I believe that Scotland's future is best served as an independent country - but I recognise more people need to be convinced of that before independence can be achieved.\n\n\"My Cabinet will also focus efforts on reaching out to those who remain unconvinced, with respect and courtesy, to ensure that the people of Scotland have the democratic right to choose their own future.\"\n\nThe Scottish Conservatives said Swinney's Cabinet was \"simply Humza Yousaf's Cabinet with a different figurehead\".\n\nScots Tory MSP and party chair Craig Hoy went on: \"The return of Kate Forbes is a desperate attempt by both John Swinney and his new deputy to gloss over the huge splits in the SNP and fixate on independence.\"", "source": {"uri": "thenational.scot", "dataType": "news", "title": "The National"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118484736", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:02:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:02:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T05:01:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.thecourier.co.uk/fp/politics/scottish-politics/4973636/john-swinney-snp-leadership/", "title": "What went wrong for Perthshire's John Swinney as SNP leader 20 years ago, and will it be different this time?", "body": "John Swinney's return as SNP leader will feel like deja vu for those who remember his first stint in the job between 2000 and 2004.\n\nThe new first minister says much has changed since then and he is a different man with a wealth of government experience under his belt.\n\nCan Mr Swinney make a better go of leading his party than he did 20 years ago, or will he fall foul of the same problems he did back then?\n\nWe spoke to the people who had a front row seat for that first ill-fated leadership to find out what went wrong, and what might be different this time around.\n\nThe predecessor...and successor\n\nIt was Alex Salmond's first resignation in 2000 that paved the way for John Swinney's promotion to leader in September that year.\n\nThen, in the merry-go-round of Scottish politics, it was Mr Salmond that stepped back into the SNP leadership void in 2004.\n\nBut the two men are far from political allies anymore.\n\nThe ex-SNP leader now heads up the Alba Party has is a regular thorn in the side of his old colleagues.\n\nLooking back, Mr Salmond recalls a grim time for his former party.\n\nThe party struggled in elections at Westminster in 2001, Holyrood two years later, and in Europe months before Mr Swinney quit.\n\n\"John had a torrid time as SNP leader, moving backwards in three elections,\" Mr Salmond told us.\n\n\"The SNP is not always an easy party to lead but back then the key problem was many activists and some of his MSPs lost confidence in his independence strategy.\n\n\"It is not obvious that it is any clearer today.\"\n\nImpatience over independence aside, he was full of praise for Mr Swinney's abilities in government.\n\nThe former first minister said: \"I found John Swinney an outstanding finance secretary over the first two terms of SNP government and a lynchpin of my administration.\"\n\nBut goodwill between the two men may be limited given bad blood between the SNP and Alba.\n\nMr Salmond said Mr Swinney's efforts to avoid any rival candidates putting their name forward was \"unwise\".\n\nBut he added: \"Seeking to avoid a contest fits in with John's nature.\"\n\nHe wants the new first minister to work more closely with his party in lieu of cooperating with the Greens, who helped bring down Humza Yousaf.\n\nThe close ally\n\nNobody was more delighted to see Mr Swinney running for first minister than his Perthshire SNP ally Pete Wishart.\n\nThe veteran MP is a close friend of the new first minister and was in the room when he was elected party leader 24 years ago.\n\nHe said his old pal struggled the first time around due to high expectations placed upon the SNP and the fact he was thrust into the role quickly.\n\nMr Wishart told us: \"There was a feeling we would come to dominate the Scottish Parliament, which was relatively new, and it just didn't happen.\n\n\"John had to learn very quickly on the job. That's sometimes difficult, as Humza Yousaf found following Nicola Sturgeon.\"\n\nBut Mr Wishart, who has been an MP since 2001, reckons Mr Swinney is now perfect for the role.\n\nHe said: \"I've seen the development of somebody who's grown in stature. He knows how to make things work.\n\n\"He's been there through the good and bad times. He is now the finished product. There is no one better equipped to lead our country.\"\n\nJack McConnell takes it back to school\n\nOne man who quite literally had a front row seat for Mr Swinney's leadership was former Labour First Minister Jack McConnell.\n\nHe squared off against his SNP rival every Thursday in Holyrood.\n\nMr McConnell, a maths teacher before he entered politics, reckons Mr Swinney's key focus in the top job needs to be on improving public services - particularly education.\n\nHe said: \"Improving the education service should be the number one priority, and I hope he makes a better job of that now than he did during the pandemic.\"\n\nMr Swinney's position as education secretary came under threat in 2020 during an exams marking scandal.\n\nPupils from poorer backgrounds had their predicted results downgraded because of blanket rules applied to historical results while they were unable to sit formal tests due to Covid.\n\nLabour insiders appear relaxed about the prospect of current leader Anas Sarwar facing off against the new SNP leader each week.\n\nDavid McLetchie was 'tougher'\n\nOne Labour insider told us Lord McConnell actually feared taking on Tory leader David McLetchie much more than Mr Swinney at the time.\n\nThey said: \"David McLetchie was a much tougher opponent for Jack than John Swinney.\n\n\"He was sharper, more charismatic, and Jack would go into debates with the two worried only about David.\"\n\n\"He was incredibly weak,\" said veteran Scottish Labour MSP Jackie Baillie, who was serving as an MSP under Lord McConnell at the time. \"I do think this feels like back to the future.\"\n\nShe added: \"In education, his mission was to close the attainment gap. He's not done that. He made such a disaster of the SQA exams.\"\n\nThe SNP dissenter\n\nDisunity within the SNP ranks was rife during Mr Swinney's first tenure in charge - an all too familiar problem for the party over the past year.\n\nVeteran nationalist Margo MacDonald was expelled from the party in 2003 and would be returned to Holyrood later that year as an independent.\n\nGlasgow MSP Dorothy-Grace Elder quit the SNP a year earlier, and remains scathing about Mr Swinney's time as leader.\n\nShe told us his election as first minister was \"bad news\" for the independence movement.\n\nThe former MSP, who left Holyrood in 2003, said: \"Not all have past experience of Swinney's disastrous time as party leader, the loss of seats, and credibility.\n\n\"I left because of the bullying, dirty tricks, and time waste of his regime - so different from his superficial image. He runs rather than solves anything.\"\n\nThe expert\n\nJames Mitchell, professor of public policy at Edinburgh University, said Mr Swinney has typically been a \"company man\" who's shown loyalty to his party above all else.\n\n\"He was dealt a difficult hand, though nowhere near as difficult as now,\" he told us.\n\n\"He wasn't a leader, was buffeted by events, and lacked strategy.\"\n\nProf Mitchell, who was Strathclyde University's chair in politics at the time, said there is a risk Mr Swinney will make the same mistakes as before.\n\nHe said: \"He's had a lot of experience, but what has he learned?\"\n\nHe also reckons Mr Swinney needs to make some big changes to the SNP's backroom team if he is to succeed.\n\n\"If he is serious and wants to show leadership he'd do a big clearout,\" Prof Mitchell said.\n\nHe added: \"He needs to replace most special advisers and bring in policy experts.\"\n\nRead more:\n\nVIDEO: John Swinney praises wife's support through MS to help him become new first minister\n\nFixing housing crisis will be priority in Perthshire as first minister, says John Swinney\n\nDundee MSP Shona Robison quits as deputy first minister - replaced by Kate {"uri": "8115544974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "12:25:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T12:25:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T12:24:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/12631649/honour-serve-humza-yousaf-kindness-king-charles-resignation-letter/", "title": "Humza Yousaf reveals 'kindness' of King Charles in official resignation letter", "body": "HUMZA Yousaf described being First Minister as a \"phenomenal honour\" as he formally stepped down this afternoon.\n\nThe ex-SNP leader officially tendered his resignation in a letter to His Majesty, King Charles III.\n\nAnd he thanked Charles for his \"counsel\" and \"kindness\" towards him and wife, Nadia El-Nakla, during his time in office.\n\nMr Yousaf had earlier urged Nats members to \"get right behind\" his successor, John Swinney.\n\nHe said: \"Being the First Minister of the country I love, the country I am raising my family in, and the only country I will ever call home has been a phenomenal honour.\n\n\"As a young Muslim boy, born and raised in Scotland, I could never have dreamt that one day I would have the privilege of leading my country - people who looked like me, were not in positions of political influence, let alone leading governments when I was younger.\n\n\"I am proud to have delivered a council tax freeze for households in every local authority in Scotland, invested record amounts in our National Health Service, removed peak fares on our railways, and approved plans for Europe's largest floating offshore wind farm.\n\n\"And through our actions, an estimated 100,000 children are expected to be kept out of poverty this year.\n\n\"From the backbenches of the Scottish Parliament, I will continue to champion the rights and the voices of those who are often not heard, be they at home or abroad.\"\n\nMr Yousaf's resignation letter to King Charles read: \"Your Majesty, With my humble duty, I write as anticipated in my letter to Your Majesty of 29 April to tender to Your Majesty my resignation from the office of First Minister.\n\n\"I propose that my resignation take effect from the start of Scottish parliamentary plenary business on Tuesday 7 May 2024.\n\n\"Throughout my time as First Minister, I have been most grateful for your counsel and the kindness you have shown to both Nadia and I.\n\n\"It has been my pleasure to serve Your Majesty and the people of Scotland since March 2023.\"\n\nIt comes as Mr Swinney was crowned as the SNP's new leader after it was confirmed he would not be opposed in his bid to succeed Mr Yousaf.\n\nThe veteran Nat staved off a late attempt by a party activist to challenge him for the position, avoiding the prospect of a leadership contest.\n\nAs leader of the largest party at Holyrood, Mr Swinney is now set to be voted in by MSPs on Tuesday before officially being sworn in as First Minister at the Court of Session in Edinburgh.\n\nIt should mean that Mr Swinney is in place to face his inaugural First Minister's Questions session at the Scottish Parliament on Thursday.\n\nIt is the second time the MSP for Perthshire North has been SNP leader, having led the party between 2000 and 2004.\n\nFollowing his confirmation, Mr Swinney said: \"I am deeply honoured to have been elected as leader of the {"uri": "2024-05-350534576", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:35:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:35:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:22:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/john-swinney-politics-seems-awfully-172221052.html", "title": "John Swinney's 'new politics' seems awfully familiar", "body": "John Swinney's brave but foolhardy pledge to introduce a \"new politics\" to the bear garden that we've got used to in Scotland lasted just as long as his first session of Question Time. An outspoken and bitter personal attack on the views of Swinney's new deputy, Kate Forbes, by the Scottish Greens, saw to that.\n\nThere is no such thing as \"new politics\", there's only politics, and it will always be a bear garden because, well, that's how things develop in an adversarial system such as ours. The new First Minister reckoned he might be able to con us by promising to be a different sort of leader - you know, one who is polite to his opponents and nice enough to do deals with them.\n\nBut there was never a cat in hell's chance of anything like that happening, and there never will be, for as long as there are seven Scottish Greens sitting in the Holyrood chamber.\n\nThey are not in the slightest bit interested in playing any kind of cosy palsy-walsy partners with anyone else. All they want is to maintain the table-thumping anger that forced Humza Yousaf to chuck them out of the coalition they'd enjoyed with the SNP for the previous three years.\n\nAnd that means that they will insist on continuing to get their way on every issue that they, and they alone, care about - albeit from the back benches now that they're excluded from government.\n\nThey signalled how they plan to proceed earlier this week by being the only party among the five in Holyrood who refused to agree to the Scottish Government adopting a positive approach to the Cass reforms, which called for children who think they may be transgender not to be rushed into treatment they may regret.\n\nScotland's 'killer road'\n\nThen at Question Time, Fergus Ewing, the veteran former SNP minister, asked Swinney if he'd meet a cross-party delegation from every other Scottish party, except the Greens, to make sure that essential work to \"dual\" Scotland's \"killer road\" - the A9 between Perth and Inverness - was not further delayed. He said there had been another fatality this week.\n\nThe Scottish Greens have been frequently accused of opposing improvements to Scotland's trunk roads as part of their agenda to limit road traffic.\n\nHowever, easily the most obvious indication of the hard road which Swinney will now be forced to travel came from Patrick Harvie, one of the Scottish Greens co-leaders. He said - demanded would be a better description - that Swinney should not give in to his party's Right wing after sacking \"progressive ministers\", meaning himself and his co-leader, Lorna Slater.\n\nThen, getting into his stride against Kate Forbes, Harvie complained Swinney had given the second-most powerful job in Government \"to someone who has opposed LGBT people's legal equality ... expressed judgemental attitudes to abortion, and ... even expressed the view that people who have families without being married are doing something wrong\".\n\nThen for good measure he added that Swinney did not understand \"just how worried many LGBT people and others are in Scotland at the moment\". Really?\n\nBarbs won't bother Forbes\n\nAs an attack on a political opponent's personal beliefs Harvie's words were as vicious as I've ever heard but I'm sure it won't be the last from that quarter.\n\nI'm pretty sure that the new Deputy First Minister won't let Harvie's barbs bother her overmuch and Swinney did do the decent thing and insisted that Forbes had instituted progressive taxation - i.e. with the rich paying more.\n\nBut when Douglas Lumsden of the Tories described the Scottish Greens as \"extremists\" he was treated to a wee lecture from the First Minister about how politicians shouldn't use such terms about each other.\n\nWhy not? As far as I'm aware it's not one of those banned \"unparliamentary\" expressions and the Holyrood presiding officer, Alison Johnstone, who had been a Green MSP, didn't seem to bat an eyelid at its use.\n\nAnd anyway, has John Swinney got a better description for his former coalition allies?", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News UK"}, "authors": [], was established 25 years ago, following an unopposed selection process a week after predecessor Humza Yousaf resigned.\n\nMr Swinney said it was an \"extraordinary privilege\" to become Scotland's new first minister as he pledged to \"give everything I have\" to the role.\n\nHe shook hands with opposition leaders in the chamber at the Scottish Parliament after the vote.\n\nMr Swinney told the other parties at Holyrood: \"If we want to fund our schools and hospitals, if we want to give our businesses a competitive edge, if we want to take climate action, if we want to eradicate child poverty, if {"uri": "8119434331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:57:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:57:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:57:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/politics/article/2024/may/09/scottish-greens-vote-against-appointment-of-kate-forbes-as-deputy-first-minister", "title": "Scottish Greens vote against appointment of Kate Forbes as deputy first minister", "body": "Green MSPs cite her conservative views on LGBT rights and equalities in fresh rift with John Swinney\n\nThe Scottish Greens have voted against Kate Forbes's appointment as Scotland's new deputy first minister in a fresh row over her conservative views on equalities.\n\nRoss Greer, a Scottish Green MSP, said that as a gay Christian he was unable to support a minister \"who feels there is something wrong with us\" and said all seven Green MSPs would oppose her appointment.\n\nThe dispute opens up a fresh rift between the Scottish government's former coalition partners and the first minister, John Swinney, the day after he confirmed Forbes would be his deputy and also deleted the post of minister for independence.\n\nSwinney appointed Forbes partly in return for dropping her bid to stand against him for the Scottish National party's leadership, but chiefly to signal to disenchanted voters the SNP was shifting back to the political centre ground before the general election.\n\nDuring the vote on Swinney's cabinet nominations, the Greens were joined by Labour and the Conservatives in opposing her appointment. The Liberal Democrats abstained, giving Swinney a narrow majority because some opposition MSPs were absent.\n\nThe row over Forbes's conservative evangelical beliefs, based on Free Church of Scotland teachings, erupted at first minister's questions. Patrick Harvie, the Scottish Greens' co-leader, said her appointment signalled a return \"to the repressive values of the 1950s\".\n\nSwinney rejected Harvie's criticisms. He said Forbes had presided over progressive tax changes and the introduction of the Scottish child payment while finance secretary. The first minister, who like Greer is a member of the Church of Scotland, said he took Harvie's challenges \"very seriously\".\n\n\"When I say that I want to be the first minister for everyone in Scotland, I deeply mean that,\" Swinney added. \"I want to lead a modern, dynamic and diverse Scotland, a place for everybody. Where everybody feels at home, at peace, that they have a place and that their place in our society is protected by my leadership of this country.\"\n\nGreer dismissed those reassurances. He said that he, Forbes and Swinney all believed in Christ, and that he knew Swinney \"shares in the joy\" that LGBT people felt about Scotland's equal marriage reforms.\n\n\"Faith is not the issue here,\" he added. \"The issue is that I am being asked to vote for someone who thinks there is something wrong with me, not because of any views I hold but simply because of who I am.\n\n\"Yesterday Kate Forbes was given the opportunity to reassure LGBT people in a question asked by ITV News. She did not. The first minister had to step in just to say the word LGBT.\"\n\nGreer added that over the last few years it felt as if Scotland \"was going backwards\" on LGBT rights - a reference to the bitter disputes over gender recognition and transgender rights, which Swinney's advisers believe have lost them centre-ground voters.\n\nThe Greens claim the former first minister Humza Yousaf's disastrous decision to scrap the Bute House agreement between the SNP and the Greens which precipitated his resignation, and Forbes's reemergence in government, has led SNP members to defect to the Greens.\n\nHarvie's fellow co-leader, Lorna Slater, told BBC Radio Scotland her party was experiencing a \"surge\" in membership, \"particularly people in the LGBTQ+ community [who] are now looking at the SNP and thinking: 'Oh my goodness, is this really the home for me?'\"\n\nAlyn Smith, an SNP MP who has championed gay equalities within his party, defended the principle of Forbes's appointment. \"Scotland's a big tent but we're too small a community to exclude people, and people of faith should have a role in politics,\" he told the same programme.\n\nForbes's position on equalities issues {"uri": "8117484775", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:41:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:41:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:41:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/24306523.swinney-strives-become-peacemaker-faces-polarisation/", "title": "Partisan Swinney strives to become peacemaker as he faces polarisation battle", "body": "This article appears as part of the Unspun: Scottish Politics newsletter.\n\nIn a key section of his speech accepting the position of First Minister yesterday, John Swinney put great emphasis on wanting to overcome the polarisation in Scottish politics.\n\nHe told Holyrood that \"as colleagues have - fairly - recognised, the Parliament is intensely polarised at this time\" and admitted his own role in how such a state of affairs had come to pass: \"I accept my part in creating that environment, whether by shouting put-downs from the front bench or heckling from a sedentary position. I promise that that will all stop. I have changed.\"\n\nTo laughter across the chamber, he added: \"Perhaps time will tell on that one.\"\n\nHe harked back to the good times that showed a more consensual approach did work and did deliver results that could improve the lives of the people who live in Scotland.\n\n\"This is not the collaborative place that it has been in the past - a collaborative place that has done so much good to improve the lives of people in Scotland,\" he told MSPs.\n\nLive Blog | John Swinney sworn in as First Minister and names cabinet\n\n\"As the Parliament marks its 25-year anniversary and as one of the relatively small group of members who have been here from the start, I reflect on the major developments that have taken place through collaborative work and agreement over that time: for example, the ban on smoking in public places, which was taken forward by the Labour and Liberal Executive; minimum unit pricing, by the SNP Government; and the introduction of free bus travel for the under-22s, by the SNP-Green partnership. I commit my Government to working to create such agreement across the chamber. I hope that there is space and willingness for that to happen, in the interests of the people who sent us here.\"\n\nAfter finishing his speech, and in a grand gesture of good will, Scotland's seventh First Minister then walked around the chamber to shake hands with the leaders of the main opposition parties.\n\nHe went first to Douglas Ross, as the leader of the Scottish Conservatives, the largest opposition party, and then in turn Labour's Anas Sarwar, the Scottish Greens' co-leaders Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater, then the Lib Dems Alex Cole-Hamilton. He later thanked Ash Regan after the Alba MSP voted for him to become First Minister.\n\nIt was quite a change from the years of barracking and heckling opposition party MSPs, as Mr Swinney indeed conceded.\n\nSo why the sudden change?\n\nOn one reading it could well be that Mr Swinney is determined to turn over a new leaf and try and build a less toxic political discourse in Scotland simply for its own sake.\n\nWhile barracking and heckling may go down well with fervent supporters among all political parties, to most members of the public it's deeply unappealing macho behaviour. So Mr Swinney's new approach is a welcome attempt to create an improved political culture.\n\nUnspun | Who has more of a chance in Scotland: Nigel Farage or Count Binface?\n\nIt also makes him look like a better class of politician, someone who has set his sights on overcoming the bitter divides and strives to be First Minister for \"all of Scotland\".\n\nBut there is also a second need for greater collaboration - and that is one of real politik.\n\nHaving ditched the Greens the new First Minister will be governing as a minority SNP administration and will need the support of MSPs from other parties to get his budget and other legislation through parliament.\n\nFor their part the Greens have already set out their terms for continuing to support the government on key votes.\n\nEssentially this came down to whether the new FM would move forward with a \"water tight ban on conversion therapy\", the introduction of rent controls, and existing commitments to decarbonise home heating systems (ie the removal of gas boilers in favour of green energy heating systems such as heat pumps).\n\nHowever, while Mr Swinney has yet to set out his new policy platform in detail he's made clear he wants to focus on more bread and butter issues - growing the economy (which means creating a more business friendly environment), delivering public services and combating child poverty.\n\nWhile close to the hearts of Greens members, issues like a ban on conversion therapy, rent controls and replacing gas boilers with heat pumps (housebuilders and other business groups are campaigning against the latter two), would not be regarded by most as the pressing priorities for most voters.\n\nAnd while not seen as key bread and butter priorities, they are also the sort of issues that can lead to a great deal of unwelcome negative headlines.\n\nAny such a change of direction by Mr Swinney will of course be attacked by Green MSPs who will argue that the new First Minister Swinney has given up on progressive values and given into the SNP's 'right wing'.\n\nIt's also potentially a tricky matter internally for the SNP with some in his own party at Holyrood still close to the Greens and highly supportive of some of the policies such as on gender issues set out in the Bute House Agreement.\n\nSo without the continued support from the Greens Mr Swinney needs to reach out across the chamber and make new allies among the Tories, Labour, Lib Dems and even Alba.\n\nHow Mr Swinney strives to deliver his more consensual approach and how the opposition parties decide to respond remains to be seen.\n\nGiven the proximity of a general election - expected later this year - and a Holyrood election in two years - when politicians tend to become more partisan rather than less - it's a difficult time for the Scottish Government to be seeking new allegiances.", "source": {"uri": "heraldscotland.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Herald"}, "authors": [], (Danny Lawson/PA)\n\n\"We will have to see if John can recover his knack of 2007 to 2011, as opposed to more recent manifestations.\"\n\nClaiming the Greens, who until two weeks ago were part of the Scottish Government thanks to a powersharing deal with the SNP, had \"developed a sense of entitlement\", Mr Salmond also advised the new First Minister to \"redirect\" his policies \"to the people's priorities and redirect away from the Green hobby horses\".\n\nMr Salmond now leads the rival pro-independence Alba Party and he suggested its sole MSP Ash Regan could be a key ally for Mr Swinney, saying he should send his Government whips to \"beat a path to Ash Regan's door\".\n\nMs Regan voted for Mr Swinney to become First Minister when MSPs were balloted on who should succeed Humza Yousaf in the post on Tuesday.\n\nMr Salmond said that vote had been a \"generous sign of good will\".\n\nWith Mr Yousaf stepping down after his decision to end the powersharing deal with the Greens left him likely to lose a vote of no confidence in his leadership, Mr Salmond noted: \"Ash Regan has one vote, but every vote is important. {"uri": "8116679474", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "05:07:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T05:07:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T05:05:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.glasgowtimes.co.uk/news/24304547.thomas-kerr-more-old-continuity-swinney/", "title": "Thomas Kerr: 'More of the same old continuity under John Swinney'", "body": "Like myself, I am sure many Glasgow Times readers are wondering if John Swinney is really the best the SNP have to offer our country.\n\nAfter shady backroom stitch-ups, firstly to do a deal with Kate Forbes and then to even stop long-term activist Graeme McCormick delay his entry into Bute House, the man who stepped down as SNP leader 20 years ago is back in the hotseat.\n\nIt quickly became apparent that the SNP wanted to avoid a re-run of last year's bitter leadership contest when the aforementioned Forbes lay the boot into Humza Yousaf's record for all the public to see.\n\nHowever, is the man who failed 20 years ago at leading them and the man who has his fingerprints all over the SNP's record of failure, really what the SNP believe Glaswegians and the rest of the country are asking for right now?\n\nThe SNP have gone Back to the Future in a desperate bid to shore up the civil war among their party, by appointing the man who was by the side of Nicola Sturgeon every step of the way.\n\nSo-called Honest John has been at the heart of this government's biggest failures and has been an architect of its culture of cover-up.\n\nDespite insisting it was their number one priority, under Swinney's stewardship of Scottish education, saw us plummeting down international league tables (well, the ones he allowed us to be a part of anyway).\n\nHe also presided over the exams scandal at the height of pandemic, in which pupils from our most deprived areas - like the ones I represent - were staring down the barrel of poorer results through no fault of their own.\n\nThe latest SNP leader only clung to his job due to support from his friends in the Greens.\n\nOr what about the Covid Recovery version of Swinney who deleted WhatsApp messages on an industrial scale despite knowing this might mean grieving families never get the answers they deserve?\n\nOr the Swinney who backed Sturgeon every step of the way and had to be dragged kicking and screaming - by the threat of another vote of no confidence in him - to hand over relevant legal advice in relation to the Alex Salmond inquiry.\n\nOr the Finance Secretary that decided to hike up taxes on hard-working Scots?\n\nThe incumbent of Bute House might have changed, but you are only going to get more of the same old continuity under Swinney.\n\nThe real priorities of Glasgow such as our schools, roads, public transport services, housing and the numbers losing their lives to drugs will all be cast aside as Swinney pushes his independence obsession at every turn.\n\nThat is where his - and his party's - focus will be as it is just about the only thing they can agree on these days.\n\nYousaf had to go, and Douglas Ross deserves every bit of credit for bringing forward a vote of no confidence in him, but by replacing Sturgeon's prot\u00e9g\u00e9, with Sturgeon's loyal deputy, it is surer than ever that the nationalists are out of ideas.\n\nThat is why getting rid of Yousaf was just the start for the Scottish Conservatives. In key seats right across Scotland, we will be urging voters to send Swinney and the SNP a message at the General Election and take the next step of booting out this rotten SNP Government for good.", chamber to win support for the Scottish budget.\n\nAs Mr Swinney was sworn in to the top job in Scottish politics on Wednesday morning, Mr Salmond told the PA news agency: \"He's got a tough job on with the parliamentary arithmetic.\"\n\nRecalling the cross-party work by Mr Swinney as finance secretary, the former SNP leader added: \"He needs to go back to recalling these days.\n\n\"We will have to see if John can recover his knack of 2007 to 2011, as opposed to more recent manifestations.\"\n\nClaiming the Greens, who until two weeks ago were part of the Scottish Government thanks to a from the Green hobby horses\".\n\nMr Salmond now leads the rival pro-independence Alba Party and he suggested its sole MSP Ash Regan could be a key ally for Mr Swinney, saying he should send his Government whips to \"beat a path to Ash Regan's door\".\n\nMs Regan voted for Mr Swinney to become First Minister when MSPs were balloted on who should succeed Humza Yousaf in the post on Tuesday.\n\nMr Salmond said that vote had been a \"generous sign of good will\".\n\nWith Mr Yousaf stepping down after his decision to end the powersharing deal with the Greens left him likely to lose {"uri": "2024-05-350295933", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:37:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:37:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/john-swinney-removes-independence-minister-133000607.html", "title": "John Swinney removes independence minister role from SNP Cabinet", "body": "John Swinney has removed the role of independence minister from his frontbench team.\n\nThe new First Minister quietly ditched the controversial position by failing to mention it in a Scottish Government press release listing that announced the appointment of junior ministers.\n\nJamie Hepburn, who previously filled the post, was named as the new parliamentary business minister but no replacement for him was declared.\n\nThe decision raises hopes that Mr Swinney will finally put a stop to the Scottish Government's independence campaign, nearly a decade after its clear defeat in the 2014 referendum.\n\nHolyrood's Unionist parties welcomed the decision to remove the role, which they have repeatedly criticised as a waste of taxpayers' money after Humza Yousaf created it last year.\n\nMr Hepburn was paid an extra \u00a333,989 to be independence minister but it was unclear what his daily duties involved. His few media appearances involved unveiling a series of civil service papers on separation, which made little public impact.\n\nNationalists were unhappy at the move to scrap the role, however, and Alex Salmond's Alba Party has accused Mr Swinney of making \"the decision to deprioritise independence in order to try broaden support\" in Holyrood for his minority government.\n\n'Obsession with independence must go'\n\nChris McEleny, the party's general secretary, said: \"Instead of appealing to Unionists, the First Minister should be reaching out to Alba Party's Holyrood leader Ash Regan MSP to turbo charge efforts to drive forward the case for independence.\"\n\nAlyn Smith, the SNP MSP for Stirling, said that having Mr Hepburn as independence minister had been \"really effective to focus Government on getting the independence white papers out of the door\".\n\nHe told BBC Radio Scotland: \"There has been a series of them, which I think need a much wider audience and a greater attention.\" Mr Smith said the role's responsibilities would be taken on by Angus Robertson, the Constitution Secretary.\n\nCraig Hoy, the Scottish Tory chairman, said: \"While it's welcome that this divisive and wasteful post has been axed, the SNP Government's obsession with independence needs to go with it - and we know that will never happen.\n\n\"John Swinney has doubled down on the SNP's separation fixation, as his campaign slogan - uniting for independence - illustrates.\"\n\nWillie Rennie, the former Scottish Liberal Democrat leader, welcomed Mr Hepburn, who is the Cumbernauld and Kilsyth MSP, being given a different job.\n\nHe said: \"For months I have been campaigning to free the Cumbernauld One from the drudgery of producing independence paper after independence paper that no one reads. I am delighted to say that goal has now been achieved.\"\n\nPamela Nash, the chief executive of campaign group Scotland in Union, said: \"The Scottish Government has finally seen sense and abolished this wasteful and costly role - but John Swinney should go further.\n\n\"Now the Independence Minister jersey has been retired, the First Minister should commit to publishing no more papers on separation, and promise to redeploy the civil servant team to more important matters.\"\n\nMr Swinney announced the junior minister roles in his government after unveiling his new Cabinet, which was identical to Humza Yousaf's bar the addition of Kate Forbes.\n\nHe appointed Ms Forbes as Deputy First Minister and Economy Secretary after she agreed not to stand against him for the SNP leadership, following Mr Yousaf's sudden resignation last week.\n\nIn addition, he reduced the number of junior ministers, with George Adam, Emma Roddick and Joe FitzPatrick leaving government.\n\nIvan McKee, a close ally of Ms Forbes, was surprisingly given the public finance brief after he warned last week that the party backing a \"continuity\" candidate such as Mr Swinney was \"eerily reminiscent\" of the decision last year to back Mr Yousaf. {"uri": "8118445823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:24:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:24:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:22:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/politics/24307606.swinney-cannot-afford-treat-independence-afterthought/", "title": "Lesley Riddoch: Swinney cannot afford to treat independence as an afterthought", "body": "SO, it's the \"dream team\" at the helm of the SNP with the punters' favourite Kate Forbes installed as deputy beside John \"safe pair of hands\" Swinney.\n\nThere's no change in the Cabinet except for the inclusion of Forbes, which has left the opposition carping about a \"continuity Cabinet\".\n\nOf course, the absence of new faces could equally mean policy not personality will drive the next government.\n\nWhich would be fine. But since there's been no leadership contest, debate, or Scottish election - what policy direction will the new government take?\n\nREAD MORE: The small but potentially crucial changes in John Swinney's Scottish Cabinet\n\nLeaving important issues of human rights and gender identity aside for a moment, both Swinney and Forbes have supported policy on the \"left\" and \"right\" with Forbes attracting the support of Robin McAlpine from left-leaning think tank Common Weal.\n\nAnd despite her criticism of the Scottish Greens, the new Economy Secretary talks readily about the need to invest in the Green Transition.\n\nSo, what's it to be?\n\nGreen or fossil-coloured brown? Left or right? Higher personal taxes (which annoys business) or a \"business\" agenda?\n\nA Rishi-style pick 'n' mix of unrelated proposals designed to appease warring factions?\n\nA \"let's please everyone\" eye-catching confetti of assorted \"changes\" which vanish in the first economic storm?\n\nA general \"change\" message may sound good, win votes, and satisfy a definite itch amongst voters and the media.\n\nBut very soon generalisations about the direction of change must get specific.\n\nAfter all, the cursed Liz Truss was change personified - destroying living standards and Britain's economic credibility in the process.\n\nBoth Fergus Ewing and Patrick Harvie support \"change\" - from radically different perspectives.\n\nJohn Swinney was sworn in as the new First Minister of Scotland\n\nSo, what kind of change is Swinney after? We know he aims to \"eradicate child poverty, drive economic growth, meet climate obligations, invest in our vital public services and ... reach out to those who remain unconvinced about Scottish independence\".\n\nBut can he eradicate child poverty while Westminster controls so many economic levers or will that pledge become as difficult to fulfil as Nicola Sturgeon's determination to close the educational attainment gap?\n\nYou'd imagine a long-standing finance secretary who helped embed the Scottish Social Security system will have done the maths.\n\nIt's also a clever choice of priority - which opposition party can possibly oppose it? Not even the Tories.\n\nAnd yet, is that affordable without deep cuts elsewhere - and is it bold enough to help the SNP reach dry land in the General Election and beyond?\n\nIt's still possible - probable according to some polls - that the party will lose Westminster seats and perhaps even control of the Scottish Parliament in 2026.\n\nDespite an unbelievably smooth velvet revolution at the helm of the SNP this week, things aren't great. And time is of the essence.\n\nLabour fell from power in 2007 because it lost its change credentials.\n\nThe party looked entitled and sluggish - unwilling to tackle stuck problems or problematic structures and not nearly bold enough to create a progressive, modern, and confident Scotland.\n\nPolling suggests some voters feel the same about the SNP - including some independence supporters. How can the SNP avoid Labour's fate?\n\nREAD MORE: Scotland's first ever Cabinet Secretary for Gaelic welcomed\n\nWell, they must avoid the temptation to do glitzy window-dressing and devise an agenda that's bold, progressive ... and surprising.\n\nThere needs to be sense, argument, direction and a well-communicated bold strategy. Of course.\n\nBut there also has to be surprise that a minority government will dare to tackle thorny issues other governments - every other Scottish government in 25 years - has left behind.\n\nThis will be difficult for Swinney.\n\nBut despite the media clamour for \"safe\" economic policies and a \"temporary\" (aye right) pausing of the case for independence - choosing safety would be a colossal mistake.\n\nLet's take indy first. The state of the movement in 2024 reminds me of 2017 when Sturgeon decided to \"take independence off the table\" at the Scottish Parliamentary elections and totally scunnered SNP members.\n\nI remember hearing reports of \"indy-free\" leaflets arriving from HQ and being binned by angry activists.\n\nWe can't go back to a slightly embarrassed mention of indy as an afterthought, especially not after Humza Yousaf's \"first activist\" pledge and his assertion that the first line of the SNP manifesto would state that a \"vote for the SNP is a vote for independence\".\n\nThat's the very minimum needed to keep jaded Yessers on board.\n\nAgreed, it's not too clear where else independence supporters can take their votes, with the Greens bringing down an SNP first minister and Alba's Ash Regan joining forces with Unionist parties in a vote of no confidence against his government. But Swinney can't take Yes support for granted.\n\nThere's still the 2017 danger that disillusioned activists just stay at home. What might encourage everyone is a serious platform of long overdue change.\n\nBold progressive measures that surprise critics, seize the agenda (much as Alex Salmond did back in the day) reassure those who doubt Swinney's energy, call the bluff of opposition parties who've long complained about broken systems without producing workable alternatives, and use the Scottish Government's newly acquired internal stability to do what previous leaders could/would not.\n\nAnd that means listening to folk beyond the Holyrood opposition parties and the all-powerful consultant class.\n\nAfter all, it wasn't KPMG that proposed the Scottish Child Payment (SCP), which has become the SNP's most cited and effective change credential.\n\nA coalition of all the poverty charities in Scotland managed to reach and persuade Sturgeon. Last year Professor Danny Dorling said the SCP has made the biggest single change to child poverty anywhere in Europe over the last 40 years.\n\nAn impressive achievement that did NOT come from the SNP, accountants or the consultancy classes. Ditto minimum unit pricing for alcohol, which has produced a 13% reduction in alcohol-related deaths, according to The Lancet.\n\nThat policy was the brainchild of the late Evelyn Gillan, formerly director of Alcohol Focus and one of the few people able to penetrate the shield of minders around Sturgeon.\n\nJohn Swinney with his appointed Cabinet of Ministers\n\nThe move triggered attacks by the powerful alcohol lobby, prompting five years of legal battles at the Court of Session, the European Court of Justice, and the Supreme Court - all of which the Scottish Government won - against the expectations of most sage professionals.\n\nIt's time to do that again.\n\nRestore the SNP's change credentials and surprise everyone by getting off the back foot with long overdue reforms - like abolishing the Council Tax and replacing it (even partly) with a form of land tax.\n\nLike pausing the current ineffectual Land Reform Act and pushing ahead with a Succession Act so children can join the rest of humanity and equally inherit land or a Compulsory Sales Order that lets councils order the sale of derelict land without taking it onto their own books - long promised and very useful now.\n\nSimilarly, it's one thing to have the strongest inward investment track record in Britain, but it means our key economic assets from airports to hydro dams are mostly owned by foreign private companies.\n\nCommon Weal amongst others have a lot of ideas for growing our own small and medium-scale Scottish companies.\n\nWill Forbes take their thinking on board? Her decision not to stand clearly disappointed many, but though she is not in charge, she is in power.\n\nThere will be no policy debate thanks to Swinney's unopposed victory, so it's vital that the SNP organises a truly open autumn conference about ideas without silencing dissent, bypassing popular resolutions, or pricing volunteer indy groups out of attendance.\n\nSwinney has a lot of people to please and mouths to feed.", "source": {"uri": "thenational.scot", "dataType": "news", "title": "The National"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Swinney", {"uri": "8116985703", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "08:40:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T08:40:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T08:39:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://caithness-business.co.uk/article/23521", "title": "Humza Yousaf Steps Down As First Minister - New First Minister Nominated", "body": "First Minister tenders resignation to King Charles.\n\nHumza Yousaf, the youngest and first person of colour to hold the office of Scotland's First Minister has formally stepped down. At his time of appointment, he was the first Muslim leader of any Western nation.\n\nFollowing the First Minister's election in March last year, he announced his intention to stand down last week, remaining in post until a new First Minister was appointed.\n\nMr Yousaf officially tendered his resignation in writing today to His Majesty King Charles III which has been accepted and the Scottish Parliament notified.\n\nHumza Yousaf said:\n\n\"Being the First Minister of the country I love, the country I am raising my family in, and the only country I will ever call home has been a phenomenal honour.\n\n\"As a young Muslim boy, born and raised in Scotland, I could never have dreamt that one day I would have the privilege of leading my country - people who looked like me, were not in positions of political influence, let alone leading governments when I was younger.\n\n\"I am proud to have delivered a council tax freeze for households in every local authority in Scotland, invested record amounts in our National Health Service, removed peak fares on our railways, and approved plans for Europe's largest floating offshore windfarm. And through our actions, an estimated 100,000 children are expected to be kept out of poverty this year.\n\n\"From the backbenches of the Scottish Parliament, I will continue to champion the rights and the voices of those who are often not heard, be they at home or abroad.\"\n\nFirst Minister Humza Yousaf's letter to His Majesty King Charles III:\n\nYour Majesty,\n\nWith my humble duty, I write as anticipated in my letter to Your Majesty of 29 April to tender to Your Majesty my resignation from the office of First Minister. I propose that my resignation take effect from the start of Scottish parliamentary plenary business on Tuesday 7 May 2024.\n\nThroughout my time as First Minister, I have been most grateful for your counsel and the kindness you have shown to both Nadia and I.\n\nIt has been my pleasure to serve Your Majesty and the people of Scotland since March 2023.\n\nHumza Yousaf\n\nParliament votes for John Swinney.\n\nJohn Swinney has been nominated as the seventh First Minister of Scotland, following a vote in the Scottish Parliament today.\n\nMSPs voted 64 to 57 to select Mr Swinney as First Minister from a total of four nominees. There were seven abstentions.\n\nMr Swinney is anticipated to be formally appointed as First Minister this afternoon with a Royal Warrant from His Majesty King Charles III. He will be officially sworn in at the Court of Session on Wednesday, where he will take the Official Oath in front of the Lord President of the Court of Session and other senior judges.\n\nFirst Minister-designate John Swinney said:\n\n\"It is an extraordinary privilege and it is my honour to accept the office of First Minister, committing myself to do the best I can for Scotland.\n\n\"I will be unapologetic about bringing to this Parliament the measures we can take to eradicate child poverty and I look forward to seeking the support of others to achieve that aim. I recognise, that is how it is going to have to work. I am leading a minority Government. I will need to reach out to others to make things happen. If we want to fund our schools and our hospitals, if we want to give our businesses a competitive edge, if we want to take climate action, if we want to eradicate child poverty, if we want to change people's lives for the better, we have to work together to do so.\n\n\"I commit my Government to working to create that agreement across the Chamber. I hope there is the space and the willingness for that to happen in the interests of the people who sent us here.\n\n\"To the people of Scotland I would simply say this. I offer myself to be the First Minister for everyone in Scotland. I am here to serve you.
