{"uri": "8119130632", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:27:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:27:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:27:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/politics/12648277/john-swinney-50-seconds-blame-westminster/", "title": "John Swinney takes just 50 seconds to blame Westminster in first FMQs as leader", "body": "JOHN Swinney today repeatedly refused to say he'd stick to his 2021 pledge to recruit 3,500 more teachers by 2026 - and immediately blamed the UK Government for the risk of not fulfilling the promise.\n\nThe new First Minister was put on the spot about the Scottish Parliament election manifesto pledge at his inaugural FMQs after taking over from Humza Yousaf.\n\nIt comes amid anger over staff cuts in Glasgow, and latest stats showing a drop of more than 200 posts in Scotland.\n\nBut Mr Swinney - Education Secretary in 2021 when the promise was made - refused FOUR times to say if he'd stick to the teachers pledge.\n\nAnd it took him just 50 seconds of his first First Minister's Questions as leader to blame the UK Government for the risk of the SNP Government not fulfilling the promise.\n\nIn response to a question from Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross - who asked him whether he'd stick to the pledge - Mr Swinney said: \"I have to answer directly, Mr Ross's question, about the challenges we face in the public finances, due to the pressures of inflation, and the persistence of austerity that is framing public expenditure from the United Kingdom government.\n\n\"But I assure Mr Ross, and parents most importantly in the city of Glasgow and around the country, of the government's commitment to sustained investment in education to maximise the investment we can make available.\"\n\nWe told this week how the new First Minister faced fury from parents and demands to step in to reverse teacher cuts in Scotland's largest city, where the SNP-led council is set to axe 450 classroom posts.\n\nIt comes despite the SNP's 2021 manifesto pledge to \"recruit 3500 additional teachers and classroom assistants, allowing teachers more time out of the classroom to prepare lessons and improve their skills\".\n\nAnd at FMQs, Mr Swinney - who this week vowed to turn over a new leaf after becoming known for his aggressive hecking in the Holyrood chamber - refused a further three times to give a Yes/No answer.\n\nMr Ross said: \"We were supposed to have a 'different style of politics', but it sounds like the excuses are the same as we've had before.\"\n\nIn his responses, Mr Swinney repeatedly said he wanted to be \"clear\" with parents, but pointed to the \"effect of austerity\" and \"a rampant increase in inflation on the watch of the Conservatives\". He added: \"We will set out our commitments as we take Budget decisions.\n\nPushed for a Yes/No answer by Mr Ross, the First Minister said: \"I've nothing really to add to Douglas Ross about the financial position we face.\"\n\nHowever, Mr Ross accused Mr Swinney of \"not being straight with the public\".\n\nThe Scottish Government has come under fire over the past year for racking up a \u00a31.5 billion budget hole due to pledges it can't afford. The UK Government has insisted it is delivering increases in day-to-day spending for the Scottish Government, which also has tax raising powers.\n\nThe exchanges came hours after Mr Swinney was warned by the Scottish Greens that they may not support him to pass laws.\n\nIt comes just a fortnight after Mr Yousaf's decision to axe the power-sharing Greens sparked a furious backlash from the hardline left-wing party, which said it would vote for a Tory-led motion to get rid of Mr Yousaf - triggering his downfall and eventual resignation.\n\nBut Mr Swinney faces a similar problem of not having a parly majority - and needing either the Greens or another opposition party's support to pass laws.\n\nToday, Ms Slater said Mr Swinney had not reached out to her party since officially becoming First Minister earlier this week.\n\nAnd she said the Nats would need to \"find another party\" to work with on every Bill and Budget.\n\nThe Greens MSP said: \"As a minority government, this government is going to have to find another party to work with on every Bill, every piece of legislation, every Budget, on a case by case basis.\"\n\nMs Slater also suggested those elected to Holyrood should not be \"shouting insults across the chamber\".\n\nShe said: \"They are going to have to chase unionist votes if they want to get things through that the Scottish Greens don't support.\n\n\"This is how a functional parliament should work, especially one with proportional representation, it should be about grown-up politics where we work together on things that we share a common agenda on.\n\n\"It shouldn't be this awful Westminster politics where everybody is factionalised and shouting insults across the chamber and you'd never work with so and so, I mean I don't think anyone wants to see that kind of politics.\"", "source": {"uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Scottish Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_musson@thescottishsun.co.uk", "name": "Chris Musson", that he will be first minister \"for everyone in Scotland'\"\n\nAfter securing the nomination, Mr Swinney said it it was \"an extraordinary privilege\" and \"honour\" to accept the office of first minister.\n\nHe also paid tribute to his \"indefatigable\" wife Elizabeth Quigley, who has multiple sclerosis.\n\nMr Swinney secured the nomination with the backing of 64 MSPs, while the Scottish Green cohort of seven MSPs abstained.\n\nHis appointment as first minister will be rubber-stamped by the King before he is officially sworn in at the Court of Session on Wednesday.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8117125092", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "10:05:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T10:05:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T10:04:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/in-your-area/lanarkshire/lanarkshire-politicians-respond-john-swinneys-32756639", "title": "Lanarkshire politicians respond to John Swinney's election as first minister", "body": "Lanarkshire's constituency parliamentarians have been reacting to John Swinney's election as Scotland's new first minister following yesterday's vote at the Scottish Parliament.\n\nThe new SNP leader - who was elected unopposed to succeed Humza Yousaf following his resignation in the wake of ending the Bute House agreement with government partners the Scottish Greens - gained the most votes in the four-way vote among party leaders at Holyrood.\n\nHe has now been officially sworn in and is beginning work with his cabinet. Local representatives are praising his \"vast experience\" and his immediate focus in his party leadership acceptance speech on addressing child poverty, and invited him onto the campaign trail for this year's general election.\n\nScottish Government minister Mairi McAllan, the Clydesdale MSP, offered her \"fullest congratulations\" and said: \"John Swinney takes up the role of leading our country not borne out of long-held ambition, but rather a profound sense of duty to the country and to the party.\n\n\"Our new First Minister is a unifier, and brings a renewed focus on the priorities of the people of Scotland - the economy, jobs, the cost of living, and the climate crisis.\n\n\"Today is the beginning of a new chapter in our party's history, that will be about coming together, uniting and dedicating ourselves again to the service of Scotland, and I look forward to playing my role alongside our new first minister in delivering for the people of Clydesdale and Scotland.\"\n\nClare Adamson, the Motherwell & Wishaw MSP, said: \"John Swinney commands respect across political divides. He is ideally equipped to serve as first minister, his commitment to the national interest is second to none.\n\n\"Voters put their faith in the SNP to stand up for Scotland and its people. John Swinney has spent his life and career doing just that and vast experience instils confidence. He is an invaluable asset to the SNP.\"\n\nShe added of his predecessor: \"Humza Yousaf's dedication to public service is beyond reproach. He served as first minister with integrity and compassion [and his] leadership at the onset of the crisis in Gaza - advocating for peace - is a mark of his character.\"\n\nRutherglen MSP Clare Haughey said the new First Minister \"brings with him great experience, dedication, and an ability to unite people to work together for the benefit of all\" and said: \"His focus is firmly on the economy, jobs, the cost of living crisis, the NHS, the climate crisis, and public service.\n\n\"We have all been sent to parliament to make a real difference to people's lives, and John's pledge to reach out to everyone in good faith and seek common ground and compromises that will serve our nation well is very welcome.\"\n\nEast Kilbride constituency colleague Collette Stevenson agreed: \"He has a wealth of political knowledge and commands respect from across the Scottish Parliament.\n\n\"I believe our new First Minister will re-energise the party, working hard across the chamber to find consensus [and prioritising] economic growth, the NHS, public services and redoubling efforts to lift children out of poverty.\"\n\nChristina McKelvie, the Hamilton, Larkhall & Stonehouse MSP, said she was \"delighted\" by Mr Swinney's election as First Minister, calling him \"an extremely experienced politician who will lead our country with passion and pride\".\n\nShe said: \"He has a proven track record and brings with him a wealth of knowledge and experience. He will listen to other people's perspectives, governing for the whole of our country and I have no doubt he will deliver a better future for Scotland.\"\n\nFulton MacGregor, the Coatbridge & Chryston MSP, said: \"I'm delighted that John Swinney has stepped forward and been made leader of the SNP, and I'm excited about this new era under his leadership. John has the experience and ability to unify the party and govern the country in the best interests of everyone.\"\n\nConstituency colleague Steven Bonnar MP agreed: \"John Swinney is the right person at the right time to lead the SNP and become our new First Minister. It's been a difficult time for the party, but John has all the experience we could ask for at this time.\n\n\"Our shared goals are simple as we approach the general election - immediately helping those people who face an unrelenting cost of living crisis caused by Westminster, by delivering policy that can help change lives for all the people of Scotland.\"\n\nAngela Crawley, the Lanark and Hamilton East MP, congratulated the new First Minister and said: \"In his first speech as party leader, John made clear that he will focus on tackling the cost of living - something which I wholeheartedly support.\n\n\"He has a wealth of experience in government so I have no doubt that he will be up to the challenge and will work hard for the people of Scotland. I look forward to working with him over the coming months and wish him the very best for his tenure as First Minister.\"\n\nAnum Qaisar, the Airdrie & Shotts MP, added: \"Articulate, intelligent and always leading from the front, John has dedicated his working life to representing the people of Scotland.\n\n\"He is also a kind, just man who is determined to tackle the stain that is child poverty - an issue which is incredibly important to my Airdrie and Shotts constituents and I.\n\n\"I'll be extending an invite to John to join me on my local re-election campaign as he has a huge support here and thoroughly enjoyed campaigning at my by-election with me over in Shotts.\"\n\nMarion Fellows, the MP for Motherwell & Wishaw, welcomed Mr Swinney's unchallenged election as party leader, saying: \"It means there [was] no divisive contest similar to the one that saw SNP politician pitted against SNP politician just over a year ago.\"\n\nShe said: \"Already John is rallying MSPs, MPs and the wider party membership behind him - he has the added bonus that he has a high public profile and is seen as an honest and principled politician who will strive to work for the whole of Scotland.\n\n\"John also has the respect of politicians from other parties. He has my full support and I look forward to the progress we can all make for the people of Scotland.\"\n\nSpeaking at Holyrood following the new First Minister's election, Conservative leader Douglas Ross said: \"John Swinney must swiftly change course and deliver a bold new policy course for this government instead of treadng water.\n\n\"The First Minister and his party must treat today as a reset moment - with our education system at record lows in international rankings, one in seven Scots on an NHS waiting list, violent crime rising and our economy lagging behind the rest of the UK, Scotland faces significant challenges that demand the government's attention.\"\n\nLabour leader Anas Sarwar called the unopposed change of SNP leadership \"an internal stitch-up\" and said: \"At this time of national crisis, people need a government that's willing to lend a hand and support them not feel abandoned by this and the UK government.\n\n\"I hope we see a new approach that puts the national interest first. We need to get on to delivering for the people of Scotland. We share a common purpose to make Scotland the best place to grow up and grow old in.\"\n\n* Don't miss the latest headlines from around Lanarkshire. Sign up to our newsletters here.\n\nAnd did you know Lanarkshire Live is on Facebook? {"uri": "8119834801", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:47:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:47:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:46:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13401731/Forbes-50s-Makes-change-1310s-Patrick-Holyrood-Sketch-Stephen-Daisley.html", "title": "Forbes takes us back to the '50s? A change from the 1310s, Patrick", "body": "Is Graeme McCormick still available? The veteran SNP activist stood aside and let John Swinney become leader without a contest, but on the strength of the First Minister's first parliamentary outing, Mr McCormick was robbed.\n\nSwinney choked. It was his debut First Minister's Questions and he was at turns hesitant, rambling, underbriefed and trying too hard.\n\nWas it an unmitigated disaster? No, in the sense that he didn't set himself on fire or accidentally declare war on Norway, but it was bad.\n\nSitting to his right - no jokes, please - was Kate Forbes, reminiscent of the 'here's what you could have won' segment in old game shows.\n\nDouglas Ross raked over the embers of Swinney's time as education secretary, reminding him of his promise to raise teacher numbers by 3,500 by the end of this parliament.\n\nDeputy First Minister Kate Forbes listens as John Swinney attends his inaugural First Minister's Questions\n\nWould he be sticking to his word?\n\nBack came a halting reply about Westminster funding, but no answer.\n\n'The excuses are the same as we've had before,' Ross spat, before repeating the question.\n\n'I've just come back into office,' the First Minister protested.\n\n'I've not been on this front bench in 12 months.'\n\nHis mewling was pitiful. The bloke was effectively co-leader of Scotland for 16 of the past 17 years.\n\nHe didn't just walk in off the street, despite the impression his performance gave.\n\nRoss levelled his query a third time.\n\nBloodlessly, Swinney stated: 'I've nothing really to add to what I've said to Douglas Ross about the financial position we face.'\n\nAfter years spent cultivating the image of a provincial bank manager, he sounded like he was turning the Tory leader down for a fixed-term mortgage.\n\nThe evasiveness drew barracking from the Conservative benches, led by Craig Hoy, an MSP who speaks more often than he has something to say.\n\nRoss entered Jeremy Paxman territory by asking his teacher-numbers question a fourth time in a row, as Swinney grimaced silently.\n\n'I am going to be straight with the public of Scotland,' he announced. No doubt he'll start any day now.\n\nThings did not improve when Anas Sarwar stepped up, scolding the SNP for fixating on themselves and not the hundreds of teachers about to be made redundant by their colleagues at Glasgow City Council.\n\nEvents of the past two weeks had been 'frankly traumatic for my party', Swinney said. Being part of a mass lay-off is frankly pretty traumatic, too.\n\nThe First Minister refused to intervene, but acknowledged 'challenges', prompting Sarwar to remind the former finance and education secretary who created the 'challenges'.\n\nThe Labour chief urged for 'fresh leadership'.\n\n'I have good news for Anas Sarwar,' Swinney piped up. 'Fresh leadership has just arrived and I am here to deliver it.'\n\nA gale of laughter tore across the chamber, interspersed with applause on the Nationalist benches. Labour MSPs pointed out that some of those chuckling were SNP members.\n\n'They are laughing because they are delighted that I am here to do it,' Swinney protested.\n\n'That is why they are laughing. They are over the moon that I am here.'\n\nLord knows Humza Yousaf was hopeless but the SNP appears to have replaced Mr Bean with Alan Partridge.\n\nScottish Green Party Leader Patrick Harvie today at First Minister's Questions\n\nPatrick Harvie, the angriest little cabbage in all the land, seethed over the appointment of Kate Forbes and accused Swinney of 'taking us back to the repressive values of the 1950s'.\n\nIt makes a change from trying to take us back to the 1310s.\n\nSwinney objected that his government would be 'led from the moderate left-of-centre' and rhymed off the lefty policies Forbes had helped deliver.\n\nHarvie was unplacated.\n\nThe strongest turn of the day came from Labour firebrand Pauline McNeill, who demanded the Crown Office be held 'fully accountable' for wrongful Horizon convictions in Scotland 'because it did not provide the checks and balances that it should have'.\n\nShe wants to haul the Lord Advocate before the parliament.\n\nIt's a call Dorothy Bain, KC, {"uri": "8118540038", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:50:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:50:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T05:49:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/opinion/24307395.listen-swinney-hear-echoes-sturgeon/", "title": "Letters: Listen to John Swinney and you hear Nicola Sturgeon Mk II", "body": "Some will be reassured by our new First Minister's \"Honest John\" persona (\"New FM in pledge to 'create more agreement' in Holyrood\", The Herald, May 8). Others, however, might have noted that within moments of being confirmed in Scotland's top job, he knowingly made three promises that he is all but guaranteed to break. Presumably he hopes that enough Scots will continue to prefer SNP rhetoric over the harsh reality of its continuing failures, scandals and missteps.\n\nSo when John Swinney says he is going to be First Minister for \"everyone\" it will have as much meaning as when his then boss Nicola Sturgeon said the same thing on taking on the top job. She then led Scotland into one of the most divisive periods in its history as she time and again favoured her supporters' dreams for separation over the general public's yearning for effective public services.\n\nEqually, as Mr Swinney claimed he will make eradicating child poverty his defining mission, some will have heard echoes of Ms Sturgeon's \"judge me on our record in education\" commitment, which proved to be utterly meaningless. Indeed, the many in Scotland on NHS waiting lists, or desperate for a ferry service that works, or troubled about the state of their children's education, might wonder how our new First Minister's focus on what sounds good rather than on the biggest challenges that they face will merely delay further any hope for them seeing real improvements.\n\nThen there is that \"more collaborative and respectful politics\" promise. It's presumably possible that by some quirk in nature a leopard changes its spots, but as the SNP's heckler in chief for so many years in Holyrood, it is no wonder that this promise from Mr Swinney was met with some disbelief by MSPs. At future FMQs can we look forward to our new First Minister honestly owning up to the part he and his party have played in all the problems Scotland now faces, or will he follow his predecessors' tactic of deflection and blaming of anyone and anything but SNP mismanagement?\n\nKeith Howell, West Linton.\n\n* I FULLY applaud John Swinney's speech as our new First Minister in promising to be a First Minister for all the people in Scotland. The cold reality however is that Mr Swinney has been one of the main architects of SNP policy for the last 20 years and has brought us to the terrible state that we are in with education and the worst-ever NHS services.\n\nHe wouldn't last five minutes as SNP leader if he started working for the majority of Scottish people who don't want independence.\n\nDennis Forbes Grattan, Aberdeen.\n\nREAD MORE: No Ross Greer, your policies aren't progressive: just stupid\n\nREAD MORE: SNP should have had its retread a decade ago. It's too late now\n\nREAD MORE: What would John Smith make of Anas Sarwar's actions?\n\nConsider the alternatives\n\nALISON Rowat rightly has a bit of fun with John Swinney and the SNP (\"'This is the new, and slightly more humble, face of the SNP'\", The Herald, May 8). She has no room, however, in her article for the alternatives.\n\nWe have Anas Sarwar and Douglas Ross, both LINOs (Leader in Name Only and there to be walked over) and both with long undistinguished careers in Westminster and Holyrood. Mr Sarwar was in the room when Scottish Labour leader Johann Lamont realised her job title was a joke and quit: Mr Sarwar is aware of his status because he followed on from elected Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard whom Keir Starmer boasted he had sacked. Douglas Ross is no better, as it was reported his leadership was ultimately as a result of murky backroom dealings and he has tied his dinghy to the Ship of Fools, aka the British Conservative Party.\n\nI could mention the LibDems (a party I once voted for), but their politics are entirely based on their British nationalism rather than ideology: happy to be in coalition with Tories or Labour, but not any democratic pro-independence party.\n\nI DO not support independence and have no sympathy for the SNP in its current death by a thousand cuts, but others do, and their views are to be respected.\n\nWhat I find disappointing is that already, disproportionate attention has been focused on John Swinney's age and Kate Forbes' genuine religious beliefs as if this was some burden impeding their ability to do their respective jobs.\n\nWith Scotland in a parlous state distraction from the real issues should be minimised and we need to home in on the policies to be followed and on Mr Swinney's and Ms Forbes' ability to get us out of the mire.\n\nTHERE is a silence in the land. We are nearing May 12, the 25th anniversary of the opening of the Scottish Parliament, but this event has been eclipsed by the chaos in the ruling party's leadership. There are vague plans to mark the occasion later in the year, with, for example, the Presiding Officer, Alison Johnstone (Green Party), touring the country to ask people's views about the parliament. But the occasion itself has scarcely been mentioned in public.\n\nBy contrast, in 2019, there were fanfares and a visit from Her Late Majesty to Holyrood, among other events, to celebrate Holyrood's 20th anniversary. But now there is little sign of celebration. As the journalist Chris Deerin rightly says, we now have \"an institution that is flawed, angry and divided. One that, for too many years, has arguably been focused on the wrong things.\" Legislation since 2019 has brought us the hate crime law and the Gender Reform Recognition Bill, two of the worst pieces of law-making in our history, as well as failed attempts by the SNP's Green allies to make our lives more miserable.\n\nIs there anything to celebrate? Holyrood is a lacklustre institution with mostly third-rate politicians, some of whom on the SNP benches are barely able to string a sentence together. It has all cost us billions of pounds, for everything from the building itself, through the inflated salaries - the first minister paid more than the UK's prime minister, for example - to subsidised canteens and superfluous ministers. Yes, Jamie Hepburn, Minister for Independence, I am looking at you.\n\nScottish nationalists think that Holyrood's failings derive from it not having full powers, but governments haven't used all the powers that they have. Why anyone thinks that a sovereign Scottish government would perform any better than what we have had recently is a mystery. Devolution in Scotland serves as an awful warning for anyone so much as thinking of leaving the UK.\n\nIS it any wonder that some contributors to the Letters Pages survey the UK economy and seek refuge in their fantasy of a newly independent Scotland cast adrift on a journey which makes Conor McCarthy's The Road resemble a day trip to Disneyland?\n\nDoes Alistair Easton (Letters, May 7) not appreciate that his confession that Brexit is a disaster, one of many heaped upon us by our neighbours, is not as he would have it a warning not to leave, but only confirms the sheer poverty of any argument to remain in the UK?\n\nThe present Westminster administration has proved itself incapable and indeed has only bankrupted its case.\n\nWill Keir Starmer, confronted by economic reality, be up to the task?\n\nNATALIE Elphicke, the MP for Dover, has defected from the Tories and has been welcomed into the Labour Party, making her the third such defection under Keir Starmer (\"Tory MP defects to Labour just minutes before PMQs\", heraldscotland, May 8). Like the other defectors, Ms Elphick appears to have had an epiphany and no longer wants to be associated with the party that she served so dutifully as an MP since 2019. Presumably she no longer supports the attacks on workers' rights, or the Rwanda legislation that she voted for, or the desperate poverty caused by the two-child benefit cap (oh, hold on: the Labour Party has refused to abolish it, so no issues on that one).\n\nConversely, whilst Tories who have been responsible for growing impoverishment, intolerance and corruption in the UK are welcome in the new-look parliamentary Labour Party there remains no room for people who have dedicated their lives to that party and to tackling injustice, inequality and racism. You have to ask yourself why would Diane Abbot and Jeremy Corbyn want to have anything to do with this lot of imposters.", "source": {"uri": "heraldscotland.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "2024-05-348180718", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "20:00:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T20:00:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T19:53:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/12634549/john-swinney-mr-happy-grumpy-angry-first-minister/", "title": "John Swinney seemed less Mr Happy & more Mr Grumpy - with flashes of Mr Angry", "body": "FOR a guy who's meant to have bagged the job of his dreams, John Swinney has been looking and sounding rather tetchy at times over the past week.\n\nYou'd think the new First Minister would have been Mr Happy given SNP bosses have arranged it for him to take over from Humza Yousaf - without a contest.\n\nSwinney has also been lavished with some fawning media coverage from people who should know better, regurgitating SNP spin about him being a \"safe pair of hands\", and so on.\n\nDespite this, the new First Minister has seemed less Mr Happy and more Mr Grumpy - with flashes of Mr Angry.\n\nYou know who this reminds me of?\n\nGordon Brown. The guy who played second fiddle for most of his career, finally got a shot at the big job, then fluffed it - with his Mr Grumble antics dragging him down.\n\nThere is a time and a place for being furious, of course.\n\nBut for Swinney, now is not that time.\n\nNot least when you've been going on about wanting to put an end to the politics of division and shouting at each other.\n\nThursday will be Swinney's inaugural First Minister's Questions as the FM himself, even if he's done a fair few of these sessions standing in for Sturgeon.\n\nLast week, Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross - let's call him Mr Mischief - saw his chance in Holyrood amid the will-they-won't-they drama over Swinney and possible challenger Kate Forbes.\n\nRoss wound up the pair, mercilessly. Forbes reacted with a smile, albeit a sarcastic one.\n\nBut as Ross shoehorned in Swinney's nickname of \"Honest John\" followed by a \"no-so-honest\" barb, you could almost see the blood rushing to Swinney's head.\n\nHe snarled and shouted and jabbed his hand across the chamber. Hook, line and sinker for Mr Mischief.\n\nNext time, John, just fold your arms, sit back and smile.\n\nAnd at the event launching his campaign last week, Swinney seemed full of pent-up rage. It was an odd spectacle, given he was meant to be sounding a note of optimism.\n\nBut, old habits die hard. Swinney was Sturgeon's enforcer. He's notorious for his loud heckles at Holyrood, being ticked off time and again by the Presiding Officer.\n\nSo, on Monday, and indeed yesterday, it looked like the spin doctors had had a not so subtle word in the ear. Easy now, John. Be gracious.\n\nAll eyes are on you. Nobody likes a scowling grump - especially on day one.\n\nBack in 2007, there were attempts at an image makeover for ex Labour leader Brown, as aides tried to reinvent the crotchety penny-pincher as a polished statesman.\n\nThe mask slipped, of course, many times, including the infamous incident when he was picked up on mic calling a Labour-backing pensioner who'd challenged him over the economy and immigration a \"bigoted woman\".\n\nAnother car-crash episode during those times was Brown's alleged musical love, the Arctic Monkeys.\n\nThis spiralled out of control following an interview about acts he liked, and ended with Brown being unable to name a single track from the Sheffield band.\n\nWhich brings me to what's on John Swinney's AirPods or, more realistically, his 1980s hi-fi.\n\nLazy folk may assume Swinney has a handful of songs on repeat - say, I Want to Break Free, and Caledonia.\n\nPerhaps twice-SNP-leader Swinney is a fan of 1994 Stone Roses album Second Coming, albeit this may not bode well given a fair few critics considered it a flop.\n\nGiven his angry antics of the past few years, Swinney may actually prefer Marilyn Manson, or guttural screamers Slipknot to get warmed up for parly debates.\n\nThose aides around him are obviously acutely aware of this image issue.\n\nThe way Swinney began his SNP acceptance speech on Monday saw him speaking softly, deliberately, kindly - no snarling, no pointing.\n\nIt was similar yesterday at Holyrood, when idealistic soundbites about representing all Scots were the order of the day.\n\nAnyone would think he'd been humming along to Simon and Garfunkel to get himself into the zone.\n\nMore likely, aides had told him that some people have pointed out that Mr Angry does not have the best chances for taking on Anas Sarwar and his message of change and hope.\n\nLet's call the Scottish Labour leader Mr Bounce, given the polls - with the obligatory warning that what goes up, must come down.\n\nSwinney, though, should learn the lessons of recent political history.\n\nIf he slips back into furious mode too readily, people will be quick to sniff out that there's something not quite right with all of this.\n\nThey may suspect that Swinney is actually a reluctant participant in a quick-find-a-caretaker plot by SNP bosses.\n\nAnd with the General Election ahead - like Brown all those years ago - he {"uri": "8117656386", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "15:31:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T15:31:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T15:31:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.newstatesman.com/politics/scotland/2024/05/what-kate-forbes-return-means-for-the-snp", "title": "What Kate Forbes' return means for the SNP", "body": "John Swinney's choice of Deputy First Minister is a rebuke to the Scottish Greens and his party's ultra-progressive wing.\n\nIf John Swinney wants to send a message that the SNP has listened, and will change, the appointment of Kate Forbes as Deputy First Minister is the right way to go about it.\n\nForbes was opposed to the ill-advised gender reforms that have done the Scottish government so much damage. She takes a Blairite approach to reform of the public services, believing that \"what matters is what works\". She is a champion of wealth creation and business innovation as a means of expanding the tax base, providing resources to fund public services, and tackling poverty.\n\nAnd Forbes is popular with the public - certainly more popular than she has been with the self-declared \"progressives\" in the SNP, who are understandably infuriated by her prominent new role.\n\nIn one fell swoop, therefore, Swinney has returned the SNP to what it used to be - a broad, umbrella movement for those who believe in Scottish independence but might disagree on other policy areas. Like The Monkees, they all have to live with each other in the same house. It is an amusing rebuke to the Scottish Greens, the SNP's erstwhile coalition partners who have repeatedly attacked Forbes as representing reactionary, right-wing forces. They richly deserve it - all the right people are booing - and the Deputy First Minister is a more complex and interesting thinker than her opponents seek to portray her as.\n\nThe appointment is also an embrace of competence. As finance secretary, Forbes was well-liked by her civil servants, and drove them hard. She was behind many of the government's most innovative economic policies, in areas such as technology and helping women entrepreneurs, and a careful steward of taxpayers' money. She is admired by business leaders. Her intelligence and intellectual curiosity usually leaves a positive mark on those she interacts with. Whitehall found her the most productive of its devolved interlocutors - she was, as one London civil servant put it to me, able to \"get to yes\" when it came to tricky, cross-parliament negotiations.\n\nIn the end, this is also about electoral performance and self-interest. The SNP has been sliding in the polls due to its seeming disconnection from the concerns of mainstream voters. It has pursued projects, from gender reform to the hate crime bill to the named person plan, that have left much of the electorate scratching its collective head. As school performance has declined and NHS waiting lists have grown, the Nat leadership has at times appeared wired to the moon.\n\nAs he appoints the rest of his cabinet, Swinney will no doubt seek a balance between SNP progressives and conservatives. This will be in some contrast to the Sturgeonite-heavy administration run by Humza Yousaf, which only delivered more of the same failing agenda that his predecessor had.\n\nThe handing of such an influential post to Forbes tells voters that the Scottish government intends to use the two years before the Holyrood election to focus on the big, important policy areas that make a difference to most voters' lives. Scottish Labour, which increasingly appeared as if it was on a glide path to Bute House, will be unnerved, and will have to respond.\n\nThere is no guarantee of success, of course. Swinney will still have to set out a practical agenda that delivers on the symbolism of his appointments. As the leader of a minority government, he will have to construct parliamentary majorities for his bills. And almost two decades into power, the SNP is weighted down by long years of policy error as well as electoral success. Many Scots are simply tired of the same old faces and want change.\n\nNevertheless, along with Swinney's measured early speeches about refocusing on a mainstream, centre-left approach, the appointment of Forbes sends a signal that this will not be a continuity administration. It might not be enough to avoid defeat. It certainly won't be enough to deliver independence. But it can unite most of a warring movement, and should give voters pause for thought.\n\nSmart deal-making, Mr Swinney. That's not nothing. In fact, it's quite promising.", "source": {"uri": "newstatesman.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New Statesman"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_deerin@newstatesman.com", "name": "Chris Deerin", {"uri": "8117452003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:24:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:24:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:20:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/kate-forbes-appointed-scotlands-deputy-131324342.html", "title": "Kate Forbes appointed Scotland's deputy first minister", "body": "Kate Forbes has returned to the Scottish government as deputy first minister.\n\nThe former finance secretary was appointed by new first minister John Swinney after opting not to run against him for the SNP leadership.\n\nShe will replace Shona Robison, who said she had offered to step down from the role but would be willing to take up another cabinet post.\n\nMs Forbes said she was \"deeply honoured\" to accept the position.\n\nMr Swinney is making cabinet appointments at his official residence, Bute House, after being sworn in at the Court of Session.\n\nMs Forbes, who has spent more than a year as a backbench MSP after stepping down from government in March 2023, had been promised a \"significant\" role in the government.\n\nIn a statement, Ms Robison said she had told Mr Swinney last week she believed stepping down in favour of Ms Forbes would help to bring the SNP together.\n\n\"I told you I believed this would strongly signal that for all of us in government, this is the best approach to showing we are united and ready to serve the people of Scotland,\" Ms Robison said.\n\n\"It is also in the best interests of your leadership and for the party; and both of us have always put public duty and the interests of the party over and above any self interest.\"\n\nIn her letter to the first minister, she added: \"You have indicated you are keen I remain in government, and I have said I am committed to serve in cabinet in whatever role you see fit.\"\n\nMr Swinney, in a written response, said he was \"deeply\" appreciative of Ms Robison's offer to \"step aside from the role\".\n\nSeveral other cabinet members, including Health Secretary Neil Gray, Energy Secretary Mairi McAllan and Education Secretary Jenny Gilruth, have also been seen entering Bute House.\n\nFurther announcements are expected on Thursday afternoon.\n\nThe cabinet appointments will be formally approved in parliament on Thursday.\n\nMs Forbes returns to government after more than a year on the backbenches.\n\nShe quit government in March 2023 after narrowly losing out to Humza Yousaf in the SNP leadership contest and rejecting a demotion to a rural affairs minister.\n\nThe Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch MSP had enjoyed a rapid rise following her election to parliament in 2016, aged 26, becoming Scotland's first female finance secretary in 2020.\n\nAfter being named deputy first minister, Ms Forbes said: \"This is a moment of extraordinary privilege for me. Having previously served in cabinet, I know the duty that all ministers have to reflect the government's priorities and the missions that drive them.\"\n\nMr Swinney said Ms Forbes was an \"immensely talented politician\", adding \"her new role will prove critical as we focus on our key commitments of eradicating child poverty, investing in public services and supporting economic growth\".", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/politics/snp-back-pitch-john-swinney-32764647", "title": "SNP back on the pitch with John Swinney and Kate Forbes after year of chaos", "body": "The SNP is in its strongest position in years after a traumatic and brutal ten days.\n\nReplacing Humza Yousaf and Shona Robison with John Swinney and Kate Forbes is like a passenger upgrading from standard to first class.\n\nSwinney installed Forbes as his number two for the same reason Yousaf ditched the Greens - restoring party unity.\n\nSNP MSPs had grown increasingly irritated with the Greens after Nicola Sturgeon's decision to bring them into Government.\n\nThey believed the SNP's mainstream agenda had been hijacked by a party pursuing niche and damaging policies.\n\nYousaf sacked the Greens from Government but ended up bringing himself down in the process.\n\nThe tensions had been aggravated by last year's bitter leadership contest during which Yousaf and Forbes tore each other apart.\n\nShe laid into his record in Government and he used her social conservatism to say she was not fit to be First Minister.\n\nVoters saw a party obsessed with itself and not the bread and butter issues that keep them awake at night\n\nBut while Yousaf's unity move backfired, Swinney's 'big tent' reshuffle has worked a treat.\n\nHe feared the party would never recover from another damaging contest and he gave Forbes the deputy gig to stop her running.\n\nHis SNP Cabinet now represents social democrats, centrists and moderate conservatives like Forbes.\n\nHis 63 SNP MSPs fall short of a majority, but Swinney knows if his group is united they will be hard to beat.\n\nThis is because the opposition will only win votes if the right wing Tories team up with the left wing Greens and bring along Labour and the Lib Dems.\n\nSuch an outcome is possible, but scoring regular wins against the Government will require political gymnastics of incredible flexibility.\n\nSwinney also has scars on his back from his previous disastrous spell as leader twenty years ago.\n\nIn that era, SNP MSPs took daily pot-shots at him and his leadership fell apart.\n\nHe knows from bitter experience the pitfalls of a divided group and will not make the same mistakes this time.\n\nBut there are dangers in dragging Forbes out of political exile and back into Government.\n\nAlthough she is competent, professional and smart, her role as DFM could see the Government take a step to the right.\n\nShe does not believe silent prayer should be banned outside abortion clinics and she was evasive on a conversion therapy ban during the leadership contest.\n\nThe pro-business Forbes could also insist that measures costing firms more money are ditched in the name of enterprise.\n\nBringing Forbes on board could alienate the moderate centre left and effectively make her the favourite to be the next leader.\n\nBut even the opposition parties admit that the SNP reboot makes them more formidable. Swinney, while responsible for a number of serious failures over the last seventeen years, is seen by voters as a serious man and a dutiful husband.\n\nForbes' social conservatism is a turn off for many voters, but she is viewed as a principled and capable politician.\n\nThe SNP under Yousaf was headed for general election catastrophe and a likely loss of Holyrood in 2026.\n\nThey have now stabilised and have an opportunity to remain the largest Scottish party at Westminster..\n\nAs pollster John Curtice said: \"Bringing Yousaf down was the worst thing the Unionists could have done. It's now a reset moment.\"\n\nScots Labour leader Anas Sarwar often says he has ensured his party is back on the pitch after years of irrelevance and squabbling.\n\nHe now has a match on his about Kate Forbes in government, says...", "body": "The Scottish Greens say some people will have \"reasonable concerns\" about the appointment of Kate Forbes to a senior position in John Swinney's government.\n\nGreen co-leader Lorna Slater said a change of direction from Mr Swinney's government would lead to \"disagreements\" with her party.\n\nAs the SNP can only count on 63 of the Scottish Parliament's 128 voting MSPs, the First Minister will likely need to seek support from elsewhere in the chamber to pass major legislation.\n\nWhen Humza Yousaf ended the powersharing deal between the SNP and Scottish Greens, Ms Slater and co-leader Patrick Harvie left the government and became opposition politicians again.\n\nMs Forbes's views on certain social issues like equal marriage are at odds with those of the Greens.\n\nLorna Slater warned the First Minister against a change in direction (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nSpeaking to the PA news agency, Ms Slater said: \"I wish all the Cabinet Secretaries the best and congratulations on their new posts.\n\n\"It is now up to the First Minister to set out what the direction of this government is going to be.\n\n\"Is he going to continue on a progressive path, working for what we had in the Bute House Agreement - rent controls, more action on climate and nature and of course, that watertight ban on conversion therapy.\n\n\"Or is he going to take the government in a different direction?\"\n\nOn the appointment of Ms Forbes, she said: \"I think that some people definitely have concerns, reasonable concerns about having Kate Forbes in a senior leadership position in the government.\n\n\"Of course, she as well as John Swinney stood for election on a manifesto that included gender recognition reform and the ban on conversion therapy.\"\n\nMs Slater said the Greens had worked with Ms Forbes and Mr Swinney as ministers in the past.\n\nShe urged the First Minister to continue with the Greens' priorities, saying \"we will have to have some disagreements if they're going to change direction\".\n\nOn the party's budget demands, she said they would focus on money for active transport and tackling climate change as well as pushing for progressive taxation.\n\nMs Slater said she is \"very concerned\" the Natural Environment Bill, along with other legislation the Greens worked on as ministers, may be dropped or watered down.\n\nKate Forbes and John Swinney speaking to journalists (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nIn a press conference outside Bute House on Wednesday, Mr Swinney was asked how he can regain the trust of the Scottish Greens.\n\nHe said his party would \"pursue an agenda assuring we stimulate opportunity in our society, eradicate child poverty and we'll do that by growing the economy\".\n\nHe said: \"We will seek common ground with all political parties.\n\n\"The onus is on everybody about how to engage in constructive discussion about how the Scottish Parliament can work together to address the priorities of the people of Scotland.\"\n\nMs Forbes told journalists she was \"absolutely delighted\" to be Deputy First Minister and said the role was an \"enormous privilege\".\n\nHowever, she was asked if she had a message for the LGBT community after her previous leadership bid saw her face criticism for her views on social issues - after saying she would not have voted to legalise same-sex marriage.\n\nShe said she would support Mr Swinney in \"finding places of consensus\".\n\nThe First Minister then jumped in to state: \"I will be the First Minister for everyone in Scotland. There were seven abstentions.\n\nMr Swinney is anticipated to be formally appointed as First Minister this afternoon with a Royal Warrant from His Majesty King Charles III. He will be officially sworn in at the Court of Session on Wednesday, where he will take the Official Oath in front of the Lord President of the Court of Session and other senior judges.\n\nFirst Minister-designate John Swinney said:\n\n\"It is an extraordinary privilege and it is my honour to accept the office of First Minister, committing myself to do the best I can for Scotland.\n\n\"I will be unapologetic about bringing to this Parliament the measures we can take to eradicate child poverty and I look forward to seeking the support of others to achieve that aim. I recognise, that is how it is going to have to work. I am leading a minority Government. I will need to reach out to others to make things happen. If we want to fund our schools and our hospitals, if we want to give our businesses a competitive edge, if we want to take climate action, if we want to eradicate child poverty, if we want to change people's lives for the better, we have to work together to do so.\n\n\"I commit my Government to working to create that agreement across the Chamber. I hope there is the space and the willingness for that to happen in the interests of the people who sent us here.\n\n\"To the people of Scotland I would simply say this. I offer myself to be the First Minister for everyone in Scotland. I am here to serve you. The fresh leadership has just arrived - and I'm here to deliver it.\"\n\nSNP member Michelle Thomson asked what support the government was providing to women in enterprise. Mr Swinney said it was committed to implementing the Pathways report on tackling the barriers female entrepreneurs face. He said \u00a31.5m had been allocated this year to support this work in addition to \u00a31.3m already given.\n\nGreens co-leader Patrick Harvie took issue with the appointment of Kate Forbes as Deputy First Minister and asked if her views and the actions of the First Minister in sacking \"progressive\" ministers meant the government was returning to the values of the 1950s.\n\nMr Swinney said that as Finance Secretary Ms Forbes delivered progressive taxation. \"When I say that I want to be the first minister for everyone in Scotland I deeply mean that,\" he said.\n\n\"I want to lead a modern, dynamic and diverse Scotland. A place for everybody.\"\n\nHe admitted that the last two weeks \"have been frankly traumatic for my party. I accept that. And they have had everything to do with running the country.\n\n\"I am now here to lead this government and to lead it with the firmness of direction it needs to address the problems facing the country and to achieve our objectives.\"\n\nThe session closed with a reminder of Mr Swinney's call for greater co-operation among parliamentarians.\n\nIt followed a final question from Douglas Lumsden, the Tory MSP and former co-leader of Aberdeen City Council, who asked: \"The extremist Greens have been ditched from government so can the First Minister tell me that the damaging policy of presumption against new oil and gas will also be ditched?\"\n\nThe First minster responded by challenging the tone adopted by Mr Lumsden. \"I don't think Mr Lumsden's language is appropriate,\" he said, adding that public expected MSPs to conduct their business with courtesy.\n\nHe avoided a direct answer to the question, saying only that: \"I want to ensure that we have a just transition for the oil and gas sector.\n\n\"We have a climate crisis with us. {"uri": "8119274982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:04:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:04:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:04:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/politics/labour-claims-john-swinney-at-32770264", "title": "Labour claims John Swinney 'at the heart of every SNP failure for past 17 years'", "body": "John Swinney has been accused by Scottish Labour of being \"at the heart of every SNP failure of the last 17 years\" as his long record in Government was scrutinised today.\n\nThe newly installed First Minister faced repeated questions on whether he will stick to a pledge he made as Education Secretary in 2021 to increase the number of teachers in classrooms by 3,500 by the time of the next Holyrood election.\n\nThe number of teaching roles has dropped over the last two years as local authorities struggle to make ends meet after real-terms budget cuts and sky-high inflation.\n\nGlasgow City Council, the largest in the country, has previously warned it will be forced to cut 172 positions from its education budget this year - with a further 450 roles at risk over the next three years.\n\nAppearing at his first session of First Minister's Questions since taking on the top job, Swinney was asked by Anas Sarwar if he would now \"step in and save jobs\".\n\nThe Scottish Labour leader told MSPs: \"John Swinney bears responsibility for the broken finances in our councils and the decimation of our education system.\n\n\"So don't give us the warm words, don't try and explain away the record, tell the pupils, their parents and their teachers - what are you going to do to protect their education?\"\n\nSwinney responded it was \"very important to have an open discussion about the choices that face public authorities\".\n\nThe First Minister went on to blame Scottish Labour for failing to resolve a long-standing dispute over equal pay for council staff when it was in charge of Glasgow City Council.\n\nHe told MSPs: \"It's something the Labour party should be utterly ashamed of.\n\n\"I understand the challenges that face Glasgow City Council. That's why I will engage constructively with them, and with Cosla, when I meet with them on Friday.\"\n\nSarwar went on to accuse Swinney of having \"no answer for parents, pupils and teachers\".\n\nHe added: \"Let's look at John Swinney's record. as Finance Secretary, he broke local finances and slashed the budget for local services.\n\n\"As Education Secretary, he abandoned teachers, standards declined, the attainment gap widened, Scotland fell in the international league tables, and shamefully he downgraded the results of working class children during the pandemic.\n\n\"Now, as First Minister, he is trapped by the past defending his own record while Scotland's children pay the price.\n\n\"Scotland once had an education system that was the envy of the world - and I believe that we can get there again. But continuity won't cut it.\n\n\"To give our young people the education and opportunities they deserve, and to unlock the huge potential of our nation, Scotland needs fresh leadership, new ideas and change.\n\n\"So after being at the heart of every single SNP failure for the past 17 years, why does John Swinney think Scotland should accept more of the same?\"\n\nSwinney responded: \"I've got good news for Anas Sarwar. The fresh leadership has just arrived.\"\n\nAs opposition MSPs laughed and SNP members applauded, he added: \"I am right here to deliver it.\"\n\nTo sign up to the Daily Record Politics newsletter, "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://news.stv.tv/politics/humza-yousaf-hits-out-at-racist-bigots-as-he-officially-steps-down-as-scotlands-first-minister", "title": "Humza Yousaf hits out at 'racist bigots' as he steps down as First Minister", "body": "He said it was an 'honour' to be the first person of colour to hold the top job\n\nHumza Yousaf has officially resigned as Scotland's First Minister ahead of a vote to elect his successor.\n\nDuring his last speech as FM to the Scottish Parliament, he told how leading his country had given him the opportunity to defy \"racist bigots\".\n\nYousaf became emotional as he said his heart would \"forever belong to Scotland\".\n\nThe Scottish Government said the King had accepted his letter of resignation on Tuesday morning and that the Scottish Parliament has been notified.\n\nYousaf was replaced as SNP leader by John Swinney on Monday with the MSP set to be voted through as FM on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nYousaf was tearful as he delivered his goodbye speech to MSPs, saying: \"I've had the greatest privilege of my life serving my country in government for almost 12 years, as minister for external affairs and international development, minister for transport, cabinet secretary for justice, cabinet secretary for health and social care and of course most recently as first minister.\n\n\"So my thanks must go to the people who gave me that opportunity by electing me to this place, the good people of Glasgow in 2011 and the fine people of Glasgow Pollok since 2016 who have continued to put their trust in me to stand up for them and to serve them.\n\n\"And also to my predecessors as first minister for giving this boy opportunities he could only have imagined in his wildest dreams.\n\n\"I'm grateful for the trust that you put in me over the years, because you see presiding officer a young Humza Yousaf could never have imagined that he would be able to lead this country.\n\n\"I was six years old when I was first told to go home, and I'm afraid since then it has been a regular occurrence, in fact almost daily if you look at my social media feeds and I won't lie presiding officer, it is that racial slur that probably hurts me the most.\"\n\nThe former SNP leader announced his intention to quit last week following a bitter falling out with his Scottish Greens colleagues in government.\n\nHe had ended the Bute House Agreement with the party and sacked its two leaders from the Cabinet ahead of a vote by Green members that could have ended the deal.\n\nCo-leaders Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater reacted furiously to the shock news and pledged to move against the now-former first minister in a vote of no-confidence.\n\nDuring his resignation speech last Monday, he said it had been an \"honour\" to serve as Scotand's first person of colour to hold the role of first minister.\n\nYousaf said he \"could never have dreamt that one day I would have the privilege of leading my country\", noting that as a boy, people of minority ethnicities were not seen in senior governmental roles.\n\nHe served in Bute House for 13 months after winning the SNP leadership election that was sparked by the resignation of his predecessor Nicola Sturgeon.\n\nHis premiership got off to a rocky start after Police Scotland's long-running investigation into the SNP's funding and finances began making its first arrests.\n\nJust weeks after being voted through as FM, the force arrested Peter Murrell - Sturgeon's husband - with that being followed by the arrests of former party treasurer Colin Beattie and Sturgeon.\n\nAll were released pending further investigation at that point but last month officers charged Murrell with embezzlement of SNP funds.\n\nDuring Yousaf's time in office, he announced a nationwide council tax freeze, a trial on scrapping peak rail fares and effectively increased taxes on middle and higher earners.\n\nCritics of Yousaf have pointed to the failed deposit return scheme, slipping education scores in international tests and NHS waiting times during his tenure.\n\nHe also announced the SNP's independence strategy, which would see the Scottish Government try to begin negotiations with the UK Government to leave the union if the SNP won the majority of Westminster seats at the next election.", "source": {"uri": "news.stv.tv", "dataType": "news", "title": "STV Indeed, one such critic was Mr Swinney.\n\nLast week the North Perthshire MSP told The Herald \"Kate and I are over that,\" when he was reminded of his remarks.\n\nBut while there may be some grumbles among those in the SNP who had forged close allegiances with the Greens during the Bute House Agreement years, among most there is likely to be a sense of relief that ongoing rows inside the party may be coming to an end.\n\nAs well as hoping that Ms Forbes' appointment will mean the drawing of a line under SNP divisions, Mr Swinney's decision to hand make her his number two, also suggests his government will have a new focus on the economy.\n\nSince launching his leadership bid last Thursday the First Minister has stressed that his focus will be on creating jobs, delivering crucial public services and combating child poverty.\n\nMs Forbes said his vision chimed with her own as she ruled out standing in the contest.\n\nTogether the new FM and DFM will be moving the Scottish Government back towards the mainstream of Scottish politics\n\nMs Forbes' appointment is already being enthusiastically welcomed by business organisations.\n\nBut notably the change of direction towards the centre ground is also move away from some of the core issues for the Scottish Greens which have to say the least been challenging for the SNP.\n\nWhile close to the hearts of Greens, a ban on conversion therapy, rent controls and replacing gas boilers with heat pumps (housebuilders and other business groups are campaigning against the latter two), would not be regarded by most as the pressing priorities for a majority of voters and had the habit of attracting unwelcome negative headlines for Mr Yousaf's government.\n\nMs Forbes's appointment was quickly seized on by Scottish Green co-leader Patrick Harvie - who was quick to underline the significant difference from the previous Cabinet.\n\nIn a statement released after she was unveiled as DFM, Mr Harvie said: \"There will be many people across our country who will be very concerned and who will want to know that this Scottish Government remains committed to a greener and more equal future for Scotland.\n\n\"When it comes to delivering fairer and more progressive taxation, a just transition from oil and gas and a watertight ban on so-called conversion therapy, it is vital that this government does not dilute the longstanding commitments that it has made.\"\n\nWhile the Conservatives, Labour and the Lib Dems have decried the new Cabinet - which does indeed include all the same members as before along with the addition of Ms Forbes - as the 'same old, same old', in truth the government of Swinney and Forbes will be a very different one to that of Yousaf and Robison - and one likely to be a harder challenge {"uri": "8118484955", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:02:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:02:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T05:01:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.thecourier.co.uk/fp/opinion/4973518/alasdair-clark-john-swinney-nicola-sturgeon/", "title": "ALASDAIR CLARK: John Swinney must step out from Nicola Sturgeon's shadow to succeed", "body": "Tory MSP Jackson Carlaw dryly noted Holyrood felt \"very retro\" this week, as Alex Salmond made a return and John Swinney became SNP leader for a second time.\n\nMr Salmond's cameo at parliament's petitions committee comes as MSPs probe the government's failure to dual the A9 between Perth and Inverness.\n\nIt's a pledge made by the SNP in 2008 while Mr Swinney was finance secretary, and the party's inability to deliver on the promise will haunt him as he returns to government as first minister more than a decade later.\n\nThis throwback to the SNP's yesteryears also serves as a stark reminder of Mr Swinney's biggest challenge - becoming his own man.\n\nAs finance secretary to Mr Salmond and deputy first minister to Nicola Sturgeon, he has played a crucial role at the very top of every SNP government since 2007.\n\nAnd it's a role he mastered. As Mr Salmond's finance chief, he was viewed as a calm, able figure who had a firm hand on the country's balance sheet.\n\nBut it's his relationship with Ms Sturgeon that may matter most in his first weeks and months as a resident of Bute House.\n\nSeveral documentaries, more than one book and thousands of column inches have been dedicated to examining Mr Salmond's relationship with Nicola Sturgeon.\n\nBut underexamined is her close bond with John Swinney, who was her most trusted lieutenant during her nine years as first minister.\n\nNicola Sturgeon: No one prouder to see John Swinney become first minister\n\nSources say the duo were inseparable. Of all the ministers and cabinet secretaries Ms Sturgeon appointed, it was the Perthshire North MSP she relied on most.\n\nIn congratulating him, Ms Sturgeon said that apart from his family, there would be no one prouder than her as he became First Minister.\n\nShe wrote: \"I have worked closely with John Swinney for more than 30 years. He was by my side throughout my time as FM - as deputy, friend and confidante.\n\n\"He is one of the kindest and most decent people I know - and without doubt the right person to be FM in this moment, for both party and country.\"\n\nHis role during Ms Sturgeon's time as first minister is not well known, precisely because of the way he approached it publicly.\n\nBut one insider told me: \"They spoke most days, probably even every day when it was very busy.\n\n\"I don't think Nicola has said this but the impression was that during Covid, when John worked at home more often and she was working in Edinburgh, she did miss him being there physically during some of the really tough decisions.\"\n\nMr Swinney's reputation from his time as deputy first minister is as the \"details\" man, he was able to navigate both the complex machinery of government and understood the political reality in parliament.\n\nOne Holyrood insider compared Mr Swinney, perhaps unfavourably, to the late Prince Phillip, Duke of Edinburgh.\n\n'He never tried to outshine Nicola Sturgeon'\n\nThey said: \"He knew his place and never tried to outshine Nicola. That was surprising to some people it's what politicians do when they are secretly eyeing up the job for themselves.\"\n\nWhile this dutiful approach to government and public service speaks well of Mr Swinney as a man, the qualities he will require as first minister are very different.\n\nHe will quickly have to step out of his predecessor's shadow, particularly as she deals with the personal scandal of her husband being charged as part of a police probe into the SNP's finance.\n\nBut politically, Mr Swinney, who has no personal first ministerial mandate from voters, will have to define his style if his time as leader is not to be curtailed at the ballot box.\n\nHe has already made tackling child poverty a clear priority, and has spoken earnestly about the importance he places on the love and support of his family.\n\nHis challenge is not an easy one. During Humza Yousaf's time at the top, he struggled to put clear blue water between himself and Ms Sturgeon, particularly as anger grew about the her government's secrecy with the Covid-19 Inquiry.\n\nMany assumed he was simply too afraid to criticise his former boss.\n\nMore importantly, Mr Yousaf also struggled to speak to voters. He never convinced them he had a plan to use government to make their lives better, too often writing off very real problems as \"Westminster's fault\", and was in denial about the deep divisions inside his own party.\n\nIf Mr Swinney is to be more than a caretaker overseeing the SNP's decline, he will be studying Mr Yousaf's 12 months in office very closely.\n\nAfter 17 years of SNP dominance, he will have to demonstrate he's a man with new ideas who is unafraid of confronting the failures of the past - even if he played a central role in the government's responsible.\n\nOtherwise, voters may opt for a fresh face.", "source": {"uri": "thecourier.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Courier"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": But we have been equally clear that the First Minister must quick give a signal of the direction his Government will take.\n\n\"Yesterday, that signal came pretty clearly - progressive ministers sacked, and the second-most powerful job in Government given to someone who has opposed LGBT people's legal equalities, who has expressed judgmental attitudes towards abortion, and has even expressed the view that people who have families without being married are doing something wrong.\n\n\"Is this the Scottish Government's vision for the future of Scotland? Taking it back to the repressive values of the 1950s?\"\n\nSwinney responded: \"No, it's not the direction of the Scottish Government. The Government will be led from the moderate, left-of-centre position that I have always occupied, and which is the policy position of my party.\n\n\"I set out, when I announced my candidacy for the leadership of my party, that I wanted to build on the work of the SNP Government to build a more modern, diverse dynamic Scotland that will ensure opportunities for all of her citizens.\n\n\"I offer Africa's news leader.", "body": "John Swinney speaks at the SNP Annual National Conference in Aberdeen, Scotland, Britain October 9, 2022.\n\nScottish National Party (SNP) veteran John Swinney was sworn in as Scotland's first minister on Wednesday, after he emerged as the sole contender in the contest to pick a new premier after Humza Yousaf's resignation.\n\nYousaf, who had become the first Muslim to lead a democratic western European nation when he was sworn in as first minister in 2023, resigned last week after his decision to end a coalition in the Scottish parliament with the Green Party backfired, triggering a race to determine his successor.\n\nSwinney's key challenge will be to halt the slide in the SNP's popularity after a string of scandals and political missteps, while keeping alive its ultimate goal of winning independence from the United Kingdom.\n\nThe new first minister was SNP leader from 2000-2004 and had also served as Scotland's deputy first minister and finance minister.\n\nThe SNP has dominated Scottish politics for 17 years but its popularity has slipped over the past year amid a funding scandal, a series of political blunders, and criticism of how it runs the country. It now heads a minority government in Holyrood.\n\nThe slide has boosted the hopes of Britain's opposition Labour Party of regaining ground in Scotland, one of the United Kingdom's four nations, as it seeks to win a British parliamentary election expected later this year.\n\nThe SNP aims to reinvigorate the push for another referendum on independence from the United Kingdom.\n\nScots voted against splitting from the United Kingdom by 55% against 45% in a referendum in 2014, but the independence movement says Britain's later departure from the European Union changed the situation and another referendum is justified - a claim that both the ruling Conservative Party and Labour reject.", "source": {"uri": "sabcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "SABC News - Breaking news, special reports, world, business, sport coverage of all South African current events. {"uri": "8117772358", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:53:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:53:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:53:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.kentonline.co.uk/news/national/reasonable-concerns-exist-about-kate-forbes-in-government-says-greens-co-leader-117074/", "title": "Reasonable concerns exist about Kate Forbes in government, says Greens co-leader", "body": "The Scottish Greens say some people will have \"reasonable concerns\" about the appointment of Kate Forbes to a senior position in John Swinney's government.\n\nGreen co-leader Lorna Slater said a change of direction from Mr Swinney's government would lead to \"disagreements\" with her party.\n\nAs the SNP can only count on 63 of the Scottish Parliament's 128 voting MSPs, the First Minister will likely need to seek support from elsewhere in the chamber to pass major legislation.\n\nWhen Humza Yousaf ended the powersharing deal between the SNP and Scottish Greens, Ms Slater and co-leader Patrick Harvie left the government and became opposition politicians again.\n\nMs Forbes's views on certain social issues like equal marriage are at odds with those of the Greens.\n\nSpeaking to the PA news agency, Ms Slater said: \"I wish all the Cabinet Secretaries the best and congratulations on their new posts.\n\n\"It is now up to the First Minister to set out what the direction of this government is going to be.\n\n\"Is he going to continue on a progressive path, working for what we had in the Bute House Agreement - rent controls, more action on climate and nature and of course, that watertight ban on conversion therapy.\n\n\"Or is he going to take the government in a different direction?\"\n\nOn the appointment of Ms Forbes, she said: \"I think that some people definitely have concerns, reasonable concerns about having Kate Forbes in a senior leadership position in the government.\n\n\"Of course, she as well as John Swinney stood for election on a manifesto that included gender recognition reform and the ban on conversion therapy.\"\n\nMs Slater said the Greens had worked with Ms Forbes and Mr Swinney as ministers in the past.\n\nShe urged the First Minister to continue with the Greens' priorities, saying \"we will have to have some disagreements if they're going to change direction\".\n\nOn the party's budget demands, she said they would focus on money for active transport and tackling climate change as well as pushing for progressive taxation.\n\nMs Slater said she is \"very concerned\" the Natural Environment Bill, along with other legislation the Greens worked on as ministers, may be dropped or watered down.\n\nIn a press conference outside Bute House on Wednesday, Mr Swinney was asked how he can regain the trust of the Scottish Greens.\n\nHe said his party would \"pursue an agenda assuring we stimulate opportunity in our society, eradicate child poverty and we'll do that by growing the economy\".\n\nHe said: \"We will seek common ground with all political parties.\n\n\"The onus is on everybody about how to engage in constructive discussion about how the Scottish Parliament can work together to address the priorities of the people of Scotland.\"\n\nMs Forbes told journalists she was \"absolutely delighted\" to be Deputy First Minister and said the role was an \"enormous privilege\".\n\nHowever, she was asked if she had a message for the LGBT community after her previous leadership bid saw her face criticism for her views on social issues - after saying she would not have voted to legalise same-sex marriage.\n\nShe said she would support Mr Swinney in \"finding places of consensus\".\n\nThe First Minister then jumped in to state: \"I will be the First Minister for everyone in Scotland. (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nMr Yousaf continued: \"My heart will forever belong to Scotland.\n\n\"So to have the opportunity to defy the far right, to defy the racist bigots who told me to go home, to be in a position to serve my home, to contribute to public life in my home, and to have the opportunity to lead my home - that has been the most tremendous honour that I didn't think was reserved for people who looked like me.\"\n\nHis comments came as he addressed MSPs after formally tendering his resignation as Scottish First Minister - a post he took on just over 13 months ago.\n\nJohn Swnney is now expected to become Scotland\u00b4s next first minister, after becoming leader of the SNP unopposed on Monday. (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nHe went on to hail new SNP leader John Swinney - who will likely succeed him as Scotland's next first minister - as being \"one of the most empathetic, kind, compassionate people\" had had known.\n\nThe departing leader added: \"Such qualities are crucial in life, they are absolutely necessary as First Minister.\"\n\nMr Yousaf had announced his intention to resign last week, after he ended the powersharing deal between the SNP and the Scottish Greens at Holyrood, provoking a furious response from the smaller pro-independence party.\n\nThat saw him facing a motion of
