{"uri": "8117577453", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:40:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:40:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:40:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.spectator.co.uk/article/the-vindication-of-kate-forbes/", "title": "The vindication of Kate Forbes", "body": "So much for Scotland being the home of 'radical' progressive politics.\n\nAfter almost two decades of the Scottish National party saying that Scots are fundamentally different to their neighbours - wiser, more compassionate, just generally better - the party now reckons Scottish voters might just share the same priorities as those south of the border.\n\nFirst, SNP members selected 60-year-old former deputy first minister John Swinney - a self-declared centrist - as leader to replace the hapless Humza Yousaf. Members clearly wanted to bring some calm to a party riven with splits over independence strategy and policy priorities.\n\nThen, shortly after Mr Swinney was sworn in as Scotland's seventh first minister on Wednesday, it was announced that he has selected Kate Forbes to be his second-in-command. This is a recognition that Scotland is a far more 'small c' conservative nation than the priorities of recent SNP governments might suggest.\n\nWhen Nicola Sturgeon stepped down as her party's leader last year (prompting Swinney's resignation as deputy first minister), Forbes was, along with Ash Regan and Humza Yousaf, one of three candidates to succeed her.\n\nThe victorious Yousaf was the continuity candidate, utterly loyal to his predecessor and determined to follow her priorities, including pushing forward hugely controversial legislation on gender equality.\n\nRegan, something of a lightweight on policy, was the first candidate to fall in that race (shortly after defeat, she defected to the Alba party, established by former SNP leader Alex Salmond). But Forbes gave Yousaf a run for his money.\n\nEarly in the contest, Forbes - a devout member of the deeply socially conservative Free Church of Scotland - revealed that, had she been a member of parliament at the time, she would not have voted in favour of same-sex marriage.\n\nAlthough Forbes insisted she had no desire to roll back any existing equality legislation, senior SNP figures were among those briefing heavily that she must not become leader.\n\nYousaf ended up winning the leadership by just 52 to 48 per cent and, rather than clasping former finance secretary Forbes close, offered her a demotion she was compelled - correctly - to reject.\n\nThe tight result though brought to an end the myth that the SNP is a party of the radical left. In fact, a great many of its members were - and remain - entirely comfortable with Forbes's rather out-of-date views.\n\nWhile Yousaf blundered through a miserable year of leadership, which included major developments in a police investigation into SNP finances, Forbes sat on the backbenches, her reputation for competence growing on the basis that things couldn't get any worse than they were.\n\nForbes's views remain an issue for colleagues. Indeed, a key factor in Swinney's decision to return from the political twilight was the fear among senior figures that she might win a contest to succeed Yousaf and, in the process, create yet more division in a party already in crisis.\n\nAlong with her views on gay marriage, Forbes is no fan of the SNP's obsession with gender ideology. She has expressed concerns about the failed plan to reform the Gender Recognition Act and is sympathetic to the views of feminist campaigners who worry about the impact on women's rights of trans rights.\n\nThe SNP's former government partners, the Scottish Greens, made it clear last week - without naming her - that they would struggle to work with First Minister Forbes. While the choice of Yousaf's replacement was for the SNP, the Greens wanted to see someone who shared their priorities.\n\nForbes does not come near to living up to the 'standards' set by the crank Greens, whose focus on the environment has long since been eclipsed by their desire to push forward contentious legislation backed by government-funded equality groups.\n\nThe appointment of Kate Forbes to the second most powerful position in government will infuriate many on the nationalist left. But the truth is she represents the views of a great many Scots - including half the members of the SNP.", "source": {"uri": "spectator.us", "dataType": "news", "title": "Spectator USA"}, "authors": as First Minister", "body": "An emotional Humza Yousaf has slammed \"racist bigots\" as he stepped down as First Minister.\n\nThe 39-year-old said it had been \"an honour and privilege\" to hold the top job in Scottish politics.\n\nHe said his heart would \"forever belong to Scotland\" as he told how leading his country had given him the opportunity to defy racism.\n\nAs both the youngest person to take on the job and the first person of colour to be First Minister of Scotland, Mr Yousaf said he had had opportunities he could \"only have imagined in his wildest dreams\".\n\nREAD MORE: Humza Humza Yousaf could never have imagined he would be able to lead this country.\n\n\"I was six years old when I was first told to go home, and I am afraid since then it has been a regular occurrence - in fact, almost daily if you look at my social media feeds.\"\n\nHe said that \"racial slur\" had hurt him most \"simply because I have no other home than this one, I never will, I never have\".\n\nMr Yousaf continued: \"My heart will forever belong to Scotland.\n\n\"So to have the opportunity to defy the far right, to defy the racist bigots who told me to go home, to be in a position to serve my home, to contribute to public life in my home, and to have the opportunity to lead my home - that has been the most tremendous honour that I didn't think was reserved for people who looked like me.\"\n\nHis comments came as he addressed MSPs after formally tendering his resignation as Scottish First Minister - a post he took on just over 13 months ago.\n\nHe went on to hail new SNP leader qualities are crucial in life, they are absolutely necessary as First Minister.\"\n\nMr Yousaf had announced his intention to resign last week, after he ended the power sharing deal between the SNP To do so with a new leader returning to the post 24 years after his first attempt is surely impossible. As so often, however, the Scottish National Party has chosen to test the received wisdom of politics and installed John Swinney, a stalwart of its 17 years in power and enthusiastic accessory to its many mistakes, as leader and first minister in the Scottish parliament. Accepting office yesterday, Mr Swinney promised a new start. Little in his long and disappointing record suggests that this will be truly the case.\n\nMr Swinney's return to the role he failed to live up to between 2000 and 2004 is little more than a "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.hertsad.co.uk/news/national/24303935.humza-yousaf-hits-racist-bigots-steps-first-minister/", "title": "Humza Yousaf hits out at 'racist bigots' as he steps down as First Minister", "body": "An emotional Humza Yousaf said his heart would \"forever belong to Scotland\" as he told how leading his country had given him the opportunity to defy \"racist bigots\".\n\nThe departing First Minister said it had been \"an honour and privilege\" to hold the top job in Scottish politics.\n\nAs both the youngest person to take on the job and the first person of colour to be First Minister of Scotland, Mr Yousaf said he had had opportunities he could \"only have imagined in his wildest dreams\".\n\nSpeaking from Holyrood's front bench for the final time, he told MSPs about the racial abuse he had suffered since a young age.\n\nHe said: \"Young Humza Yousaf could never have imagined he would be able to lead this country.\n\n\"I was six years old when I was first told to go home, and I am afraid since then it has been a regular occurrence - in fact, almost daily if you look at my social media feeds.\"\n\nHe said that \"racial slur\" had hurt him most \"simply because I have no other home than this one, I never will, I never have\".\n\nMr Yousaf continued: \"My heart will forever belong to Scotland.\n\n\"So to have the opportunity to defy the far right, to defy the racist bigots who told me to go home, to be in a position to serve my home, to contribute to public life in my home, and to have the opportunity to lead my home - that has been the most tremendous honour that I didn't think was reserved for people who looked like me.\"\n\nHis comments came as he addressed MSPs after formally tendering his resignation as Scottish First Minister - The issue is that I'm being asked to vote for someone who thinks there's something wrong with me, not because of any views I hold, but simply because of who I am.\n\n\"I will not do that, and the Scottish Greens will not do that.\"\n\nIf all MSPs from the four other opposition parties - the LibDems, Labour, Tories, and Alba - had voted against Forbes, then the motion asking parliament to agree to her appointment as a minister would have fallen.\n\nHowever, Alba's Ash Regan backed Forbes, and the LibDems abstained. Furthermore, not all of Holyrood's MSPs were present, meaning the SNP group would have been big enough to wave through Forbes's appointment unopposed.\n\nSwinney's motion looking for MSPs to back Forbes as a minister passed by 63 votes to 57, with three abstentions.\n\nLibDem MSP and former group leader Willie Rennie said his party would not block Forbes's appointment as a show of goodwill and their intention to take a \"new approach\" to Scottish politics.\n\nHe added: \"We may have a difference of views on equalities, but Kate Forbes does deserve a chance to govern, putting those views to one side.\"\n\nIn his response, Swinney said he wanted to see the Scottish Parliament \"work more collaboratively\", and addressed each of the main opposition parties in turn.\n\nAddressing Greer specifically, Swinney (above) said: \"We want to make sure that those values of diversity that have been at the heart of the journey of this parliament over so many years are protected and enhanced as we move forward as a country together.\n\n\"When I say to the country, as I did on Tuesday, that I offer myself as the First Minister for everybody in Scotland, I cannot convey adequately or strongly enough that I mean absolutely everybody.\n\n\"I want every single person in our society to feel they are at home and at peace in our society.\n\n\"And I come to these conclusions actually from some of the motivations that Mr Greer has talked about as well. I come to them from a very deep Christian faith.\n\n\"I believe that nothing can separate us from the love of God. That is the foundation of who I am. Nothing can separate us from the love of God and we are equal in the eyes of God, every one of us.\n\nREAD MORE: Kelly Given: The SNP's shift right runs contrary to all I believe in\n\n\"I hope those comments - which are more forthright comments about faith than I have ever uttered in my 45 years in politics - will perhaps illustrate to Parliament the magnitude of the seriousness with which I take the issues that Mr Greer has talked about as well.\"\n\nForbes did not speak during the debate, but had earlier addressed criticism from the Greens while speaking to journalists.\n\nAfter FMQs, she said: \"I am here to support the First Minister and together we serve all communities in Scotland as we further and progress the rights of every community in Scotland, and I look forward to doing my part in achieving the Government's aims in that regard.\n\n\"Not just that, but when I joined Government yesterday in a clear role to support the First Minister, I signed up to collective changes.\n\nThe late night announcement of the axing of the indy role - much criticised by pro-UK rivals - is likely to anger sections of the independence movement, who insist the issue should be the top priority of an SNP government.\n\nOfficials also confirmed that Emma Roddick had stepped down as Minister for Equalities, Migration and Refugees - with Kaukab Stewart, who had been a junior culture minister, taking over as the Minister for Equalities.\n\nAnd Joe FitzPatrick also departed from ministerial office, having served as the Minister for Local Government and Planning, along with George Adam who had been minister for Parliamentary Business.\n\nThe changes brought in by Mr Swinney means a reduction in the size of the Scottish Government by four since the start of the year.\n\nWe told previously how beaming Kate Forbes landed a plum job as Deputy First Minister yesterday - a week after secret talks John Swinney over an SNP leadership race backroom deal.\n\nThe Leaving aside her more controversial views on social matters like gay marriage - and many in the SNP will hope she does so in government - Forbes' more pragmatic approach to economics could form the basis for cross-party co-operation.\n\nHowever, while SNP politicians were stressing the need to be \"collegiate\", it remains to be seen whether the opposition will be prepared to play ball. This question will be moot if the Scottish Greens are satisfied by forcing Humza Yousaf to resign and are now prepared to offer their informal support.\n\nPatrick Harvie, the Greens' co-leader, fired a warning shot following Forbes' appointment, saying \"there will be many people across our country who will be very concerned and who will want to know that this Scottish Government remains committed to a greener and more equal future for Scotland\". He also pointedly tweeted a \"no right turn\" road sign. Might the Greens try to bring down another SNP politician?\n\nGiven his fragile position, Swinney's decision to make Forbes his deputy was a bold, potentially risky move. But it was also a positive one. He has essentially done what we advised Yousaf to do amid the crisis that led to his downfall. The SNP doesn't have so many talented politicians that it can afford to let people like Forbes languish on the sidelines.\n\nThat said, Forbes only served as Finance Secretary for three years and, while she demonstrated signs of competence during a period dominated by Covid, regarding her as the solution to all Scotland's problems would be overly optimistic. Fixing the NHS, education and the economy are pressing priorities that the SNP has failed to make sufficient progress on for years.\n\nSwinney and Forbes must now demonstrate that independence, blaming Westminster, and culture wars are now secondary to the task of fixing Scotland's most serious and fundamental problems. opportunity to defy \"racist bigots\".\n\nThe departing First Minister said it had been \"an honour and privilege\" to hold the top job in Scottish politics.\n\nAs both the youngest person to take on the job and the first person of colour to be First Minister of Scotland, Mr Yousaf said he had had opportunities he could \"only have imagined in his wildest dreams\".\n\nTo have the opportunity to lead my home - that has been the most tremendous honour that I didn't think was reserved for people who looked like me\n\nSpeaking from Holyrood's front bench for the final time, he told MSPs about go home, and I am afraid since then it has been a regular occurrence - in fact, almost daily if you look at my social media feeds.\"\n\nHe said that \"racial slur\" had hurt him most \"simply because I have no other home than this one, I never will, I never have\".\n\nMr Yousaf continued: \"My heart will forever belong to Scotland.\n\n\"So to have the opportunity to defy the far right, to defy the racist bigots who told me to go home, to be in a position to serve my home, to contribute to public life in my home, and to have the opportunity to lead my home - that has been the most tremendous honour that I didn't think was reserved for people who looked like me.\"\n\nHis comments came as he addressed MSPs after formally tendering his resignation as Scottish First Minister - a post he took compassionate people\" had had known.\n\nThe departing leader added: \"Such qualities are crucial in life, they are absolutely necessary as First Minister.\"\n\nMr Yousaf had announced his intention Does he still? John Swinney took a very hands-on interest in making Scotland's 2009 climate act a world class piece of legislation, says Dr Richard Dixon. ow will an SNP government led by John Swinney rise to the challenge of tackling the climate emergency? Swinney himself has some interesting history on the issue. There is no question that the Scottish Government had a strong incentive to focus on climate change while it contained two Scottish Green party ministers, had two Green special advisors, and was subject to an agreed programme of work on the issue in the Bute House Agreement. Now that Swinney's minority government will have to make deals on a case-by-case basis with whichever party is most amenable, it is hard to see there being so much attention on climate change. However, the urgent need to pass legislation to amend the failing targets and budgets in the 2019 climate act will have to be one of his early priorities. In the run-up to the 2009 climate act, I worked for WWF Scotland, based in Dunkeld. Our constituency MSP was John Swinney. He was also the Finance Secretary. I saw a lot of John as the bill was being developed and going through parliament, and it was obvious that he was taking a very hands-on interest in making the final act world class.", "source": {"uri": "8117809305", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "17:22:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T17:22:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T17:20:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/glance-scottish-cabinet-171311428.html", "title": "At-a-glance: The new Scottish cabinet", "body": "First Minister John Swinney has announced his new cabinet, which will lead what he promises will be a slimmed-down government.\n\nHowever, the arrival of Kate Forbes as his deputy actually increases the cabinet by one. So who's who in the 11-strong senior ministerial team?\n\nAt 60, John Swinney is the oldest person to take the role of first minister since Donald Dewar, who was 61 when he won the first Holyrood election in 1999.\n\nWith that comes enormous experience: 45 years in the SNP, a previous spell as leader, and 16 years as a cabinet secretary including nine years managing Scotland's finances.\n\nFew question his qualifications for the role and he is widely seen as a stabilising voice, popular with colleagues and opponents.\n\nHe will need all his experience to fulfil his promise to seek consensus with opposition parties, with the aim of growing the economy and tackling poverty.\n\nKate Forbes returns to government after little more than a year on the backbenches, and the terms of the deal she struck not to run against Mr Swinney now become clear.\n\nThe 34-year-old becomes Scotland's youngest ever deputy first minister and takes over the economy portfolio as well as responsibility for Gaelic.\n\nThe MSP, who is a member of the Free Church of Scotland, has been criticised for her views on gay marriage, abortion and trans rights.\n\nShe is a former finance secretary and is fluent in Gaelic.\n\nAngela Constance remains at justice and home affairs.\n\nThe former social worker has been in parliament since 2007 and joined the government in 2010.\n\nShe previously served as education secretary and communities and social security secretary before leaving government for a spell.\n\nThe 39-year-old has held the rural affairs brief since 2021.\n\nBefore entering parliament in 2016 she was a councillor in her native Brechin and defeated the sitting MSP, Nigel Don, in a party selection contest.\n\nShe was briefly drugs minister before taking on her current role.\n\nJenny Gilruth also stays in the same job.\n\nThe Mid-Scotland and Glenrothes MSP was a teacher in Edinburgh and Dunfermline before entering politics. She entered government in 2020 as minister for Europe, migration and international development.\n\nShe is married to the former Scottish Labour leader Kezia Dugdale.\n\nNeil Gray was only elected to Holyrood in 2021, having spent the previous six years at Westminster.\n\nHe took over as health secretary earlier this year, after the resignation of Michael Matheson.\n\nThe native Orcadian was a journalist and producer with the BBC in Kirkwall before working for the former health secretary Alex Neil.\n\nA member of the Scottish Parliament since its inception in 1999, Fiona Hyslop has now served in junior and senior government roles under all four SNP first ministers.\n\nShe has been a member of the party for almost 40 years and stood unsuccessfully in council and Westminster elections before devolution.\n\nShe held the culture portfolio for 11 years between 2009 and 2020.\n\nSeen as one of the SNP's brightest young stars, Mairi McAllan became a minister immediately upon being elected to the Scottish Parliament in 2021 at the age of 28.\n\nThe former corporate lawyer and special adviser to Nicola Sturgeon joined Humza Yousaf's cabinet in the transport, net zero and just transition brief.\n\nThis became net zero and energy in February and she is another cabinet member retaining exactly the same role under Mr Swinney.\n\nOne of the SNP's most experienced campaigners, Angus Robertson spent 16 years as an MP for Moray before losing his seat to the Scottish Conservative leader Dougas Ross in the 2017 election.\n\nA German speaker who worked as a journalist in central Europe, he spoke for the SNP on foreign affairs and defence at Westminster and has been both the party's deputy and Westminster leader.\n\nSince being elected to Holyrood in 2021, he has been cabinet secretary for the constitution, external affairs and culture.\n\nA close friend and political ally of former First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, Shona Robison is another of the 1999 intake of MSPs.\n\nShe was a junior minister for public health and sport in her party's first government before joining the cabinet in 2014 but resigned as health secretary four years later.\n\nAfter a spell on the backbenches, the Dundee MSP re-joined the cabinet in the social justice brief before serving as Mr Yousaf's finance secretary and deputy first minister.\n\nShe offered to give up her role as deputy first minister in favour of Kate Forbes as a means of bringing the party together.\n\nShirley-Anne Somerville was an MSP from 2007-2011 before losing her seat.\n\nAfter a spell helping run the Yes campaign she returned to Holyrood in 2016 and has been in government ever since.\n\nShe has been education as well as social justice secretary and between these roles has handled controversial policies such as gender recognition, school standards and the role of the Scottish Qualifications Authority (SQA).", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, Mr Yousaf had 10 Cabinet Secretaries and 18 ministers.\n\nREAD MORE: 'Continuity cabinet': John Swinney keeps Humza Yousaf's ministers\n\nOther posts to be scrapped include the two held by the Scottish Greens and the Minister for Culture, Europe and International Development.\n\nKaukab Stewart who held the post is now Minister for Equalities.\n\nMr Swinney has also brought Ivan McKee back into government.\n\nHe quit last year after Mr Yousaf offered him \"a smaller job\".\n\nThe Glasgow Provan MSP - who was briefly Kate Forbes's campaign manager during 2023's SNP leadership contest - will be Public Finance Minister.\n\nThat post was previously held by Tom Arthur. He has been moved to work under Ms Forbes as the Minister for Employment and Investment.\n\nEmma Roddick, who was minister for equalities, migration and refugees, Joe Fitzpatrick, who had been minister for local government empowerment and planning, and George Adam, who was previously minister for parliamentary business, have all \"stepped down from their previous roles.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Brian Wilson: Opposition's duty is to work to remove Swinney as soon as possible\n\nThe creation of the Minister for Independence post was one of Mr Yousaf's pledges during the SNP leadership contest.\n\nResponsibilities included \"independence strategy, parliamentary co-ordination and liaison regarding devolution, independence and Scotland's constitutional future, communication with people, businesses and organisations regarding devolution, independence and Scotland's constitutional future\".\n\nHowever, the position - which came with a \u00a332,000 salary uplift for Mr Hepburn - had proved controversial.\n\nMr Hepburn's main role was in the production of the Building a New Scotland series of papers. It is not clear if these will continue now that the position has gone.\n\nMr Swinney's decision to scrap the Minister for Independence brief just months out from the tenth anniversary of the 2014 referendum was criticised by Alex Salmond's Alba.\n\nChris McEleny, the party's general secretary tweeted: \"John Swinney's first has removed post of Minister for independence.\n\n\"Sadly, he can only have it one way. {"uri": "8116043422", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:53:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:53:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:52:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://foreignaffairs.co.nz/2024/05/08/mil-osi-united-kingdom-the-scottish-greens-will-keep-working-for-a-better-future-with-courage-and-determination/", "title": "MIL-OSI United Kingdom: The Scottish Greens will keep working for a better future, with...", "body": "Lorna Slater MSPs speech as John Swinney elected First Minister.\n\nCongratulations to John Swinney on behalf of myself and the Scottish Green Group. We recognise the right of the SNP as the largest party in this chamber to form a Government, and we are content, in the spirit of stable governance, that they have managed to do so.\n\nThe Scottish Greens have worked constructively with John Swinney over many years, both as partners in government and from the opposition benches, and we look forward to building a similarly constructive relationship as he takes up the role of First Minister.\n\nHowever, our explicit support for an SNP First Minister has always been conditional on a shared vision and policy programme, one which tackles the climate crisis head on, which builds a fairer, more equal future, and which continues to make the case for an independent Scotland.\n\nThe new First Minister has yet to lay out the vision for his new Government, hence our Group's abstention in the vote today.\n\nI am proud of what the Scottish Greens achieved during our time in Government. Lifting 100,000 children out of poverty, delivering free bus travel for young people, banning new incinerators, the most polluting single use plastics, and putting in place emergency rent controls during the cost of living crisis. These are things which are making people's lives better already, thanks to the Scottish Greens.\n\nBut there was so much work still to be completed. We had just introduced a housing bill, which creates new rights for tenants and a permanent system of rent controls.\n\nOur Heat in Buildings programme was transforming the way we heat our homes, to drive down emissions and give everyone a warm home they can afford to heat. This has been billed as a template for the rest of the UK by the Climate Change Committee.\n\nThe process to appoint Scotland's new National Park was well underway, driving investment into Scotland's rural communities. The proposed Natural Environment bill would have created new protections and legislative tools to help restore nature in Scotland.\n\nBringing in a watertight ban on conversion therapy, to protect some of the most vulnerable people in our society.\n\nThese remain our priorities as Scottish Greens, and we will continue to advocate for the fairer, greener, more equal Scotland that they create.\n\nIn the coming days and weeks, the First Minister must lay out whether his government will continue with these progressive policies, as well as the recent commitment to ramp up action on the climate emergency, or whether he will retreat to the middle ground, and rely on the Tories and other pro-union parties to complete the work of Government.\n\nIf our parties can continue to work towards a shared vision of a fairer, progressive, independent Scotland which takes its responsibilities to future generations seriously, our door remains open.\n\nThe Scottish Greens will keep working for a better future, with courage and determination. {"uri": "8115977990", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:02:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:02:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:01:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/12633730/nicola-sturgeon-face-thunder-humza-yousaf-speech/", "title": "Moment Nicola Sturgeon's face turns to thunder during Humza Yousaf's speech", "body": "NICOLA Sturgeon's face appeared to turn to thunder after Humza Yousaf made a remark during his parting speech in Holyrood.\n\nMr Yousaf formally stepped down as FM today as new Nats chief John Swinney took over the top job.\n\nThe outgoing First Minister resigned after the backlash he faced for tearing up the Bute House Agreement - the SNP's power-sharing arrangement with the Scottish Greens, and leaving the Nats with a minority in Holyrood.\n\nIn a parting speech to the parliament, he reflected on his time as FM and revealed some advice his predecessor gave him when he took over last March.\n\nBut one remark he made didn't seem to go down well with Ms Sturgeon as it took the smile off her face.\n\nMr Yousaf said: \"I remember Nicola Sturgeon saying to me that as First Minister you get to make someone's day every single day.\n\n\"And also quite possibly making someone's day by leaving office I suspect too.\"\n\nThe parliament cameras then cut to Ms Sturgeon smiling during the speech.\n\nBut her face instantly changed after the \"leaving office\" remark and dropped to an angered frown.\n\nMr Yousaf continued: \"Nicola Sturgeon was absolutely right, you can make someone's day through the smallest act of kindness.\n\n\"Stopping for a selfie with someone or through transformative policy like the Scottish child payment.\n\n\"The privilege of serving the people of Scotland through this office never gets tiring.\"\n\nBut there seemed to be no bad blood between the senior Nats after they were spotted hugging after the speech.\n\nMr Swinney is currently the First Minister-designate and will be officially appointed this afternoon with a Royal Warrant from The King.\n\nHe will be officially sworn in at the Court of Session tomorrow and take the Official Oath in front of the Lord President of the Court of Session and other senior judges.\n\nAfter becoming FM, Mr Swinney said: \"It is an extraordinary privilege and it is my honour to accept the office of First Minister, committing myself to do the best I can for Scotland.\n\n\"I will be unapologetic about bringing to this Parliament the measures we can take to eradicate child poverty and I look forward to seeking the support of others to achieve that aim.\n\n\"I recognise, that is how it is going to have to work. I am leading a minority Government. I will need to reach out to others to make things happen.\n\n\"If we want to fund our schools and our hospitals, if we want to give our businesses a competitive edge, if we want to take climate action, if we want to eradicate child poverty, if we want to change people's lives for the better, we have to work together to do so.\n\n\"I commit my Government to working to create that agreement across the Chamber. I hope there is the space and the willingness for that to happen in the interests of the people who sent us here.\n\n\"To the people of Scotland I would simply say this. I offer myself to be the First Minister for everyone in Scotland. I am here to serve you. {"uri": "8119649158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:50:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:50:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:50:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://pjmedia.com/chris-queen/2024/05/09/scots-cast-aspersions-on-their-best-politician-because-of-her-christian-faith-n4928908", "title": "Scottish Leftists Disparage a Rising Political Star Because of Her Christian Faith", "body": "Scotland has long held a crucial place in Christian church history. Centuries of faithful Catholicism followed by a leading role in the Protestant Reformation in the British Isles made Scotland a force in Christianity for a long time. Prominent Christians like pastor John Knox, author George MacDonald, physician John Abercrombie, and singer Sheila Walsh all hailed from Scotland.\n\nKate Forbes, a member of the Scottish Parliament, belongs on any list of influential, faithful Scots. She has served as a member of the Scottish National Party (SNP) since 2011, and she has been a member of the Scottish Parliament since 2016.\n\nThe SNP is a largely center-left party whose members are united around the issue of Scottish independence from the UK. Forbes is one of the party's most conservative members, and she holds traditionally Christian pro-life convictions as well as believing in the biblical positions on sexuality and marriage.\n\nForbes told the BBC in 2021 that her faith is \"essential to my being. Politics will pass - I am a person before I was a politician and that person will continue to believe that I am made in the image of God.\" The BBC also reported that Forbes \"said she had a responsibility to represent all of her constituents regardless of any difference in their beliefs.\"\n\nInsiders have long seen Forbes as a rising star who is one of Scotland's best politicians. She's a compelling communicator with a vision for a prosperous, independent Scotland, but her efforts to advance her career recently ran into the secular buzzsaw.\n\nRecommended: The United Methodist Church Chooses the World Over Truth\n\nIn 2023, when Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon resigned in scandal, Forbes put her name forward to replace her. She finished second in the SNP leadership contest to Humza Yousaf, a Muslim.\n\nYousaf resigned earlier this spring after facing a no-confidence vote. By May 1, Forbes hadn't thrown her hat into the ring to run to replace him. That day, Iain McWhirter wrote in The Spectator that leftists in Scotland had declared war on Forbes:\n\nForbes, who is politically astute, highly articulate, and economically literate, would clearly be the most able candidate to lead the SNP. She is already significantly ahead of Swinney in the latest Ipsos opinion poll. But this has horrified the nationalist establishment and leftie journalists who have launched an almost hysterical campaign to have her stopped.\n\nForbes is being portrayed on social media as 'the candidate for the 19th Century' and a reactionary bigot by the SNP's many pro-LGBT activists.\n\nThis characterization, McWhirter says, comes even though Forbes \"comes across as a young, streetwise woman who just happens to be religious. She has never expressed any intention to roll the clock back to the days of backstreet abortions and persecution of homosexuals. Quite the reverse. She insists that, as a democrat, she has long accepted things like gay marriage even though they conflict with the strict tenets of her Christian faith.\"\n\nOn his podcast on Thursday, Albert Mohler highlighted an op-ed in a London newspaper that treated Forbes as if she had plans to bring Scotland back to the Dark Ages after recent radical left leadership in the country:\n\nThe article by Kenny Farquharson holds up some as political exemplars that are to be applauded, are to be appreciated, because they were progressivist statements. He mentions Nicola Sturgeon there in Scotland and also Humza Yousaf, who was \"the first Muslim to lead a national government in the Western world.\" Farquharson goes on to say, \"This in itself is an extraordinary badge of honor for Scotland.\" But when it comes to Kate Forbes, the threat was that she would be everything people like Kenny Farquharson do not want to see as representative of Scotland and its government.\n\nAnd it's because, the argument here is just really, really clear, it is because she's associated with a form of Christianity that poses a direct threat to the liberationist liberalism of the Scottish culture, now in an extremely secularized form. Farquharson says that what a leader believes is important. \"Who our leaders are matters. What they believe matters. What they represent matters.\" And Farquharson then asked the question, \"What message would a Kate Forbes first ministership send? That single mothers are sinners? That sex outside marriage is wrong? That ghouls should be allowed to stand in the streets outside abortion clinics, muttering incantations? That most of us in secular Scotland are going to hell?\"\n\nSecular leftists were up in arms because, as a Christian, Forbes' \"faith does not reflect the country she wants to lead.\" She eventually decided not to run for leader of the party or first minister, choosing instead to endorse centrist John Swinney, who won the election.\n\nFortunately, Swinney saw the value that Forbes brings to Scottish politics -- which secular leftists refuse to acknowledge -- and named her Deputy First Minister.\n\n\"This is a recognition that Scotland is a far more 'small c' conservative nation than the priorities of recent SNP governments might suggest,\" wrote Euan McColm in The Spectator on Wednesday. In other words, the leftists may have a big bully pulpit, but they don't represent the views of all Scots.\n\n\"The appointment of Kate Forbes to the second most powerful position in government will infuriate many on the nationalist left,\" McColm added. \"But the truth is she represents the views of a great many Scots - including half the members of the SNP.\"\n\nThe radical leftists in Scotland -- and elsewhere -- would want nothing more than to deny conservative, Bible-believing Christians a seat at the political table. Good for Swinney for recognizing what Forbes brings to the table. I, for one, am excited to see what her future holds.", "source": {"uri": "pjmedia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "PJ Media"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_queen@pjmedia.com", "name": "Chris Queen", people who looked like me, were not in positions of political influence, let alone leading governments when I was younger.\"\n\n\"I am proud to have delivered a council tax freeze for households in every local authority in Scotland, invested record amounts in our National Health Service, removed peak fares on our railways, and approved plans for Europe's largest floating offshore windfarm. {"uri": "8119493395", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:41:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:41:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:41:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/24310109.forbes-power-greens-ever---not-happy/", "title": "'She who must not be named in progressive company' wound Greens right up", "body": "Happily, they all seemed none the worse for having had their tea served up to them by this unconscionably smart academic. Holyrood will learn from this.\n\nThis being John Swinney's debut First Minister's Questions, all eyes were on the Scottish Greens. How quickly would they try to sink the boot? They've been jouking about these corridors looking slightly dazed and sporting fixed grins, pretending they care not a jot.\n\nKate Forbes with John Swinney (Image: free)\n\nIn a devastating two-week spell they've lost everything: their places in government; their Harry Potter ministries and the cosy add-ons that came with them. She who must not be named in progressive company, K--- F-----, has usurped them and now wields more power than they ever had.\n\nThere she was, sitting nonchalantly at Mr Swinney's right hand, looking all Protestant and carefree. The problem for Mr Greer and Mr Swinney is not that Ms Forbes is - like them - a good Christian, but that she's the wrong type of Christian. Doesn't she know that, around here, your Christianity must be checked in at the door and then approved by committee? Hopefully, she too will learn lessons.\n\nThe previous day, she'd worn a vivid green frock as she accepted the post of deputy First Minister. This seems to have been triggering for some Greens. Going forward, Ms Forbes will now perhaps consider submitting her apparel choices - as well as her religious beliefs - to the appropriate committee for approval.\n\nPatrick Harvie, chewing wasps, wasted no time in contrived pleasantries. He lamented the departure of 'progressive' ministers like Emma Roddick and Joe Fitzpatrick. Sadly for Ms Roddick and Mr Fitzpatrick their 'progressiveness' was in inverse proportion to their political acumen.\n\nMr Harvie traduced Ms Forbes for her outdated personal views. The 1950s were mentioned and the trauma of LGBT people across Scotland. Mr Swinney could have pointed out that Mr Harvie has known about Ms Forbes' religious beliefs for many years in government and then asked why it was only a problem now.\n\nInstead, he mollified them in a two-minute soliloquy that featured progressive and progressiveness seven times. Progressive taxes; progressive values; progressive attitudes; progressive progress.\n\nDouglas Ross then chose to ask the same question four times instead of asking the four different questions to which he's entitled. Would Mr Swinney deliver on the pledge he'd made as Education Secretary to create 3500 new teaching jobs?\n\nREAD MORE\n\nJohn Swinney has a strategy - and we can start to see it take shape\n\nSwinney should spring Humza Yousaf's indy trap\n\nCuriously, when it was Anas Sarwar's turn he asked more or less the same question. It was as though the two had colluded. Surely not?\n\nAnd then it all became clear. The Scottish Labour leader has also been learning lessons. The previous day, Natalie Elphicke, who makes Nigel Farage look like Ross Greer, defected from the Tories into Sir Keir Starmer's welcoming arms.\n\nThis marked the completion of Operation Invasion of the Tory-Snatchers. Why waste time trying to defeat the Tories when you can just become them instead? I fear we may be seeing a lot more joint manoeuvres between Mr Ross and Mr Sarwar.\n\nMr Swinney has pledged to introduce a new form of political engagement by seeking collaboration and kindness. As though he has a choice in the matter.\n\nHe could easily have had Messrs Harvie, Ross and Sarwar for his lunch. Instead, he chose the path of least resistance. He needs these people.\n\nIf he continues in this vein the rest of us will require the patience of Kate Forbes' saints at First Minister's Questions.", "source": {"uri": "heraldscotland.com", {"uri": "8116331763", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "22:24:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T22:24:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:23:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13393075/EDDIE-BARNES-decade-long-post-referendum-hangover-returning-normal-cause-hope.html", "title": "EDDIE BARNES: After decade-long hangover, are returning to normal?", "body": "Why did he do it? All the drama over the past couple of weeks - from the almighty strop taken by the Scottish Greens, to Alex Salmond's brief return to relevance, to John Swinney's unlikely recasting as Scotland's latest Father of the Nation - has rather obscured this question.\n\nWhy, two weeks ago, did Humza Yousaf suddenly pull the plug on his Green partners, crashing his political career in the process?\n\nAs the dust settles on an extraordinary few days in Scottish politics, it's a question worth returning to.\n\nThe answer, I believe, tells us something important about where Scotland stands as we begin the long run-in to the 2026 Holyrood election.\n\nIt's also, I'd suggest, a cause for optimism.\n\nThe answer to why Humza pulled the plug on his deal with the Greens tells us something important about where Scotland stands, says Eddie Barnes\n\nMr Yousaf wasn't specific about his reasons when he held his fateful press conference two weeks ago.\n\nThe pact with the Greens had simply 'run its course', he declared. Perhaps he didn't want to spell it out.\n\nThe truth was quite simple: with possibly just weeks to run before a general election, Mr Yousaf junked the Greens because the deal had become politically toxic for the SNP, synonymous across Scotland with broken promises (on, for example, the environment), cock-ups (on, for example, the bottle deposit scheme) and fringe cultural issues (on, for example, trans rights).\n\nThe way the SNP and the Greens were running Scotland was going to cost the SNP seats, and it needed to change.\n\nThat final sentence sounds like the ultimate statement of the bleeding obvious but, in our strange political culture in Scotland, it marks a significant break with the recent past and from the way politics has been conducted here for the ten long years since our era-defining referendum.\n\nLet Professor Sir John \u00adCurtice, the great polling guru, explain.\n\n'The thing I've picked up,' Sir John said at the \u00adweekend, 'is that whereas as recently as 2022, people's \u00adwillingness to vote for the SNP was unrelated to their \u00adattitudes to the state of the health service and so on, now they are.\n\nTherefore the insulation of the constitutional question that has been around them for a long time, and indeed has become thicker and thicker over time, has been punctured.'\n\nIn short, the 2014 referendum changed our political culture.\n\nIt saw people identify as either Yes people or No people. The SNP benefited as the party of Yes, a position that hardened even further after the Brexit referendum.\n\nAs Sir John notes, the SNP discovered it was therefore insulated from the usual wear and tear that afflicts political parties in office, when the trains stop running on time or when the health service stops working.\n\nThis insulation meant that, in 2021, Nicola Sturgeon\n\ncould bring the Greens into government without needing to worry too much about whether they'd be any good at \u00adgoverning. Here was our Yes government in action.\n\nWhat has changed, however, is that the umbilical link that connected pro-independence voters to the SNP and the Greens has weakened.\n\nMany of these people have had enough of the way the SNP (and the Greens) have been running the country.\n\nIn focus groups, what used to be 'our' Scottish Government is now viewed, one UK Government source tells me, in the same negative light as everybody else in power. It no longer gets the benefit of the doubt.\n\nA significant poll last week found that more people now believe a Labour-led Scottish Government would do a \u00adbetter job of running Scotland than an SNP-led one.\n\nMany pro-independence voters will agree with that. The constitutional connection they felt with the SNP no longer blinds many of them to the failings the government has overseen. Hence the \u00adreason Mr Yousaf had to act to change the government.\n\nIt suggests that after a decade-long hangover following the referendum, Scotland may finally be returning to something approaching normality.\n\nAnother pollster, Peter Kellner of YouGov, recently took a deep dive into Scottish political attitudes.\n\nHis verdict was that, for the first time since the referendum, the next general election will be fought in Scotland on 'competence not the constitution'.\n\nI note that the 'salience' of constitutional matters - or how much they mean to voters when they cast their vote - is at its lowest ebb since the 2014 referendum.\n\nWe are, perhaps, finally beginning to move on.\n\nWe can all feel it, I think. The Westminster circus that helped feed Scotland's \u00adconstitutional fervour has begun to wane: not even Tory rebels these days can be \u00adbothered to muster much of a rebellion against Rishi Sunak. The crazy show is over.\n\nMeanwhile, in Scotland, the referendum era is beginning slowly to slip into history. The totemic ruling of the Supreme Court, preventing a Holyrood-run poll, has deflated the SNP's campaign entirely.\n\nAnd Father Time has been cruel for nationalism. These days the entire constitutional debate has grown stale and - frankly - very boring, symbolised best by the unreported papers on independence that the SNP government still insists on producing.\n\nIt's not all over, I should say: many Scots still want the \u00adability to yank the emergency cord if the UK once again acts like a runaway train.\n\nPro-independence voters are not necessarily changing their minds - it's just that these same Scots would really rather not have to break the glass on the UK, not when a scary world of pandemics, war and insecurity threatens our futures, thanks very much.\n\nThe fact the SNP has \u00adhappily swapped 'first activist' Mr Yousaf in favour of the softly-softly leadership of John Swinney suggests the Nationalists know it too.\n\nTwo-and-a-half years ago, in my first column in this space, I wrote that thanks to our unrelenting constitutional cold war, Scotland had got stuck.\n\nToday - in what is my last regular column here - I think we can finally begin to detect a shift in the weather. We're not yet unstuck but peer ahead and it's possible to make some predictions.\n\nThose weakening ties between constitutional allegiance and voter behaviour will put the SNP under greater pressure to deliver better \u00adoutcomes.\n\nIt means it'll get judged more and more on its actions.\n\nFailure to deliver will mean that at the 2026 election, the SNP may well shed seats.\n\nThat in turn could lead to a parliament similar to the one we elected in 2007 when the two largest parties - the SNP and Labour - were practically neck and neck.\n\nAnd that would mark a welcome shift. Such a parliament would require Nationalist and Unionist parties to cross the constitutional no man's land and seek to work together. It would necessitate consensus and seriousness.\n\nIt might just see MSPs tackling the deepening challenges Scotland faces and grabbing the many opportunities that are there for the taking.\n\nIt's not a time for gloom, in other words. Scotland has extraordinary strengths, a \u00adtalented workforce and can reasonably claim to be leading Britain in many of the new industries and sectors that will drive wealth creation over the coming years.\n\nIf our politics at Holyrood can catch up with the \u00adambitious nation around it that wants to get on in the world, then there is plenty of cause for hope.", "source": {"uri": John Swinney has said his independence strategy is the same as Humza Yousaf's - a strategy that the SNP's longest serving MP Pete Wishart labelled a 'total mess'.\n\n\"The new SNP government has made the decision to deprioritise independence in order to try broaden support for itself within Parliament.\n\nREAD MORE: John Swinney's Scottish Cabinet: What changes have been made?\n\n\"Instead of appealing to Unionists, the First Minister should be reaching out to Alba Party's Holyrood leader Ash Regan MSP to turbo charge efforts to drive forward the case for independence.\"\n\nSwinney previously told The National his party remain wedded to Yousaf's independence strategy for the next election.\n\nIt involves the SNP winning the majority of Scottish seats at the General Election and taking that as a basis for independence support, which they said they would take to the UK Government to begin negotiations on how to give that \"democratic effect\".\n\nHepburn's brief in the independence role included \"independence strategy, parliamentary co-ordination and liaison regarding devolution, independence and Scotland's constitutional future, communication with people, businesses and organisations regarding devolution\".\n\nSpeaking after the announcement of his Cabinet yesterday, Swinney said he believed \"Scotland's future is best served as an independent country\" but added that \"more people need to be convinced of that before independence can be achieved\".\n\nHe said: \"My Cabinet will also focus efforts on reaching out to those who remain {"uri": "8118398200", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "03:34:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T03:34:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T03:32:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/john-swinneys-new-cabinet-same-32767142", "title": "John Swinney announces new cabinet and retains same old team", "body": "John Swinney delivered his new look cabinet yesterday on his first day as First Minister.\n\nBut there was very little new about it apart from a return to government for Kate Forbes. Every other minister was retained and keeps the same job as they did under Humza Yousaf.\n\nIt's a bit like a new football manager and his assistant taking over a failing football team - but keeping exactly the same players on the park. Swinney insists he is no continuity candidate.\n\nBut that's a hard sell to the voters when he has kept ministers in place who are widely viewed as failing to deliver on public services.\n\nIf you look at almost any area of Scottish life - schools, hospitals, trains, roads - there's a widespread perception that major improvements are required.\n\nChanging those in charge of these services might have signalled Swinney's drive to deliver on bread-and-butter issues like health and education.\n\nSwinney and his team will argue the ministers delivering these services need more time to bring about the improvements we desperately need.\n\nMany of them have had very little time to bring about radical improvements.\n\nHe will also argue that with himself and Kate Forbes at the helm, there will be a greater emphasis on improving public services.\n\nBut in attempting to keep senior members of his own party onside, Swinney has missed a chance to present himself as the real change candidate to the electorate.\n\nThis opens the door to Labour presenting themselves as the transformers who will make the difference that Scotland needs.\n\nIf our public services do not get any better, Anas Sarwar will claim only his party can turn things around.\n\nSwinney has an opportunity to make a difference - and he deserves his chance to shine.\n\nBut sticking with the same team means the real change is Swinney himself, so results rest on his shoulders, and the public will expect to see improvements ... and fast.\n\nIt's just not fare\n\nScrapping peak rail fares has been a huge success.\n\nSo it is unbelievable that SNP ministers are preparing to undo that good work by bringing them back.\n\nAt a time when we face both a cost of living crisis and a climate crisis, it's daft to be reintroducing deeply unpopular peak-time fares.\n\nNot least when regular fares already got hiked by 9 per cent back in April.\n\nIt makes not a jot of sense to hit commuting Scots with a rail costs double whammy when we're trying to get more people out of their cars and into trains.\n\nEspecially when this policy is working and getting us back closer to pre-pandemic passenger levels.\n\nScotRail is nationalised. The power is entirely in Holyrood's hands.\n\nDoubling fares for hard-working Scots who commute by rail would be two fingers up at them and two fingers up to the environment.\n\nSNP ministers must urgently rethink this - and figure out a better plan.\n\nDon't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond - Sign up to our daily newsletter here.", "source": {"uri": "dailyrecord.co.uk", The Scotland that we want to build is one where everyone is free to be themselves and where climate action is at the forefront of our politics.\n\n\"The First Minister must lay out his programme and his vision for Scotland, and where these values lie within it.\"\n\nHarvie posted a picture of a \"no right turn\" sign on social media - an apparent warning for the new Government not to shift its policies to the right.\n\nThe Scottish Green co-leader further told The National: \"With the Scottish Tories targeting a fantastic organisation like LGBT Youth Scotland just as others down south have done with Stonewall, the appointment of a Deputy First Minister with deeply conservative views, and a wave of hostility toward our community in much of the media, it's essential that progressive voices are heard now, to prevent Scotland regressing to the toxic values of the past.\"\n\nFormer finance secretary Forbes was the first to arrive at Bute House - Swinney's official residence - in Edinburgh on Wednesday as he put together his top table.\n\nIn a statement, she said: \"I am deeply honoured to accept John's invitation to be his Deputy First Minister.\n\n\"This is a moment of extraordinary privilege for me. Having previously served in Cabinet, I know the duty that all ministers have to reflect the Government's priorities and the missions that drive them.\n\n\"I look forward to working with John and Cabinet colleagues, delivering for the people of Scotland and building a better country.\"\n\nSwinney said: \"I am very pleased to appoint Kate as Deputy First Minister and look forward to working government if he became SNP leader.\n\nMs Robison will remain in the new first minister's cabinet in a role which has not yet been specified.\n\nMr Swinney thanked the Dundee City East MSP for her \"selfless generosity\" in stepping aside from her post as deputy.\n\nHe said her decision would help him \"create the inclusive and unified team\" he needs to run the country.\n\nHe said: \"I deeply Mr Swinney's No2.\n\nIt's not yet confirmed what senior cabinet role she will be given alongside the post.\n\nBut she previously served as Scotland's finance chief until Nicola Sturgeon quit.\n\nMs Forbes was the main contender against Mr Yousaf in last year's hotly contested SNP leadership race.\n\nShe did not join his government and instead went to the backbenches, where she was occasionally {"uri": "8117838832", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "17:43:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T17:43:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T17:43:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/politics/24307494.john-swinney---champion-scotlands-indigenous-languages-need/", "title": "Why John Swinney could be the champion Scotland's indigenous languages need", "body": "JOHN Swinney's election has the potential to give Scotland's indigenous languages a much-needed boost as the Scottish Languages Bill makes its way through Parliament. The bill is giving our languages legal protection for the first time in their extensive history and that's why it is vital to have a First Minister who truly understands their importance.\n\nAs the former education secretary, Swinney has already shown he is willing to use his platform to promote Scots and Gaelic. But perhaps most significantly, he has acknowledged that the languages are not a political tool, but an integral part of Scotland's culture - even if there is no denying the role that pro-indy politicians have played in protecting them.\n\nReferring to Gaelic, Swinney said the \"good structures\" that were being put in place to support the leid during his time as education secretary were \"not a nationalist plot\" but a way to ensure \"fair treatment\" for a minority language that has existed for over 1000 years.\n\nREAD MORE: John Swinney's Scottish Cabinet: What changes have been made?\n\nSwinney has similarly legitimised Scots, describing it as \"an essential element of our nation's culture and heritage\".\n\nWriting as a Scots author, I have seen first-hand how separating Scotland's languages from politics is essential to promoting their legitimacy outside of Scotland and in the union. But this can only be done through comprehensive education, which the new Scottish Languages Bill has the potential to provide.\n\nAll too often, I have seen the Scots leid reduced to \"pretend language made up by the SNP\", when, the reality is that both Scots and Gaelic predate the Union by hundreds of years. It is therefore comforting to know that Swinney has personally viewed some of the many historic Scots texts housed at the National Library of Scotland, some of which go back as far as 1440.\n\nBut in order to change attitudes, a strong politician who can meet and overcome the challenges presented by the current economic climate is essential, even if that means obtaining further devolution to divert much-needed resources back into Scotland's cultural landscape.\n\nA prime example of why this is needed is Aye Write. Despite being one of Scotland's Scotland's premier book festivals, it initially failed to secure the funding it needed from Creative Scotland to showcase new and emerging literary voices in 2024.\n\nREAD MORE: AI deepfake video of John Swinney on Sky News goes viral on Twitter\n\nScotland's indigenous languages are of huge cultural significance and they need to be fostered for the benefit of Scottish people within and outside Scotland. Even more so when you consider their unifying of power in a Scotland that is more divided than ever by class and politics.\n\nA good example of the unifying power of our leids is a new Scottish deli that's proven a hit in London - Auld Hag's The Shoap. Popular with Scots and people from all over alike. It uses almost entirely Scots language signage and specialises in Scottish scran, showcasing not only the many foods that make Scotland great outside of Scotland but our language.\n\nThat's not to mention the renewed interest in the Scots leid prompted by Len Pennie's \"Scots Word of the Day\", which actually has a predominately American audience. Her promotion of the language even prompted someone at her London book launch ask if it is okay for non-Scots to use our leids, to which the answer was a natural yes.\n\nBut while I think it's important to discuss Scotland's languages outside of politics, a natural symptom of their promotion is a move towards independence. Every country should be free to govern itself and an awareness of what makes a country great - or should I say braw - only reinforces that.\n\nTaking Swinney's experience as a politician out of the equation, his age puts him in a fantastic position to promote the leids. Swinney, 60, is from the same generation as my parents, who grew up experiencing violence - verbal and sometimes physical - for daring to speak their native tongues, so he will understand why so much prejudice still exists today.\n\nBut Swinney has also seen first-hand how there is hope for the future through the revival Scottish languages have enjoyed in recent years - from Billy Kay making history by delivering a speech in Scots to all political parties in Scots in 2022 to the Scottish Languages Bill itself, which was only launched at the end of last year.\n\nWith this in mind, I invite the new First Minister to make fostering the new bill a priority. It is a key to the promotion and representation of Scottish culture at home and abroad that should not be overlooked. But given that Swinney has already used the Scots leid in his first parliamentary speech, and made space for Gaelic in the Cabinet, I am confident this is already the case,", "source": {"uri": UK Government financial mismanagement, blah blah blah.\n\nYeah, we get it. But the point stands that SNP ministers would have plenty of cash to increase teacher numbers by 3500 - as they promised in 2021 - if they made different spending decisions.\n\nThey have chosen, instead, to spend cash on things like more generous benefits than Westminster, more generous pay rises for the public sector, free prescriptions for people on \u00a3100,000 a year, and so on.\n\nMoney doesn't grow on trees, and cloth has to be cut accordingly. It is no wonder they are struggling with yet another pledge they couldn't afford.\n\nIn the Holyrood chamber, Mr Swinney refused - four times - to give a clear Yes/No answer on whether the teacher promise he made in 2021 as Education Secretary would stand.\n\nLaughably, the First Minister had the brass neck to claim he was being \"clear\" with parents - while going out of the way not to be.\n\nMr Swinney's performance at his first FMQs on the hot seat was both odd and underwhelming.\n\nHe was clearly trying extremely hard to suppress the urge to bellow at his opponents - as he's spent the last decade doing - after saying he wanted to ditch shouty politics.\n\nBut in trying to force this softer approach, he gave the impression of someone who had glugged too much Night Nurse.\n\nWhen Patrick Harvie's inevitable character assassination of Kate Forbes arrived, Mr Swinney looked like he wanted to be anywhere apart from Holyrood.\n\nHe bowed his head and read robotically from a script about \"centre left\" values of his government.\n\nThere was no explicit defence of Ms Forbes after Mr Harvie's tirade - a bit strange given Mr Swinney has just appointed her as his No2.\n\nRegardless, perhaps we shouldn't be surprised that it seems that normal service has resumed.\n\nThe problem for Mr Swinney is that he has claimed it will be different now he's in charge. Pesky journalists and opposition politicians will naturally want to put that to the rest.\n\nEarlier this week, the new First Minister promised a \"new chapter\" for the SNP and Scotland.\n\nIt's obviously still early days. {"uri": "8117518108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:03:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:03:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:03:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4039215743541718, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/news/24306617.kate-forbes-views-same-sex-marriage-abortion/", "title": "What are Kate Forbes's views on same-sex marriage and abortion?", "body": "KATE Forbes has been announced as Scotland's Deputy First Minister as John Swinney unveils his new Cabinet.\n\nShe takes over the role from Shona Robison, who has resigned from the position but will remain in Cabinet.\n\nHowever, Forbes's appointment has upset some with the Scottish Greens pointing to \"the appointment of a Deputy First Minister with deeply conservative views\".\n\nREAD MORE: AI deepfake video of John Swinney on Sky News goes viral on Twitter\n\nHere's what Swinney's new deputy has said on a range of social issues.\n\nDuring last year's SNP leadership contest, Forbes said she would have voted against gay marriage in Scotland.\n\nIn an interview with The Scotsman, she said she would not have supported equal marriage as a \"matter of conscience\" if she had been an MSP at the time.\n\nShe said: \"I believe that it should be a conscience vote because of its profound significance in all mainstream faiths.\n\n\"I think for me, Angela Merkel is the example I would follow, I would have voted, as a matter of conscience, along the lines of a mainstream teaching in most major religions that marriage is between a man and a woman.\n\n\"But I would have respected and defended the democratic choice that was made. It is a legal right now and I am a servant of democracy, I am not a dictator.\"\n\nIn a separate interview with BBC Radio Scotland, she said she was a \"servant of democracy\" and stressed that she would defend the \"legal commitment\" the country had made to equal marriage.\n\nIn an interview with ITV, Forbes was asked if she supported the right to have an abortion under current laws.\n\nShe said: \"I couldn't conceive of having an abortion myself. I've seen my baby at 12 weeks and 20 weeks but yes, I defend the right of women to make use of that legal provision to access abortion.\"\n\nShe was further asked if this meant she would defend the current law which allows women to have an abortion during the first 24 weeks of pregnancy.\n\nREAD MORE: Stephen Flynn gives perfect reaction to Natalie Elphicke's defection\n\n\"My position is that I wouldn't change the law as it stands.\"\n\nAsked about legislation put forward by Green MSP Gillian Mackay (below) aiming to stop anti-abortion protesters from gathering outside clinics, Forbes commented: \"I think with the bill the basis of my position is that nobody seeks a termination lightly.\n\n\"There are emotionally vulnerable women seeking these terminations and they should do so free of fear and harassment.\n\n\"In that sense, the purpose of the bill makes sense. Any bill that is good law needs to make sure its targeted and that's where I've said I'm happy to work with her (Mackay).\"\n\nThe buffer zone legislation recently passed Stage 1 and Forbes voted in favour of the legislation.\n\nThe new Deputy First Minister also previously said it was \"up to\" individuals whether they had children outside of marriage although said it was something she would \"avoid\".\n\nAsked by Sky News for her views on having children out of wedlock, she told the broadcaster: \"It's entirely up to them. It's something that I would seek to avoid for me personally.\n\n\"But it doesn't fuss me, it doesn't put me up nor down. The choices that other people make is (up to them).\n\n\"In terms of my faith, my faith would say that sex is for marriage and that's the approach I would practice.\"\n\nShe added: \"For me, it would be wrong according to my faith, but for you I have no idea what your faith is. So, in a free society you can do what you want.\"\n\nDuring the leadership race, Forbes (below) also said she would not have voted in favour of the Scottish Government's gender reform bill.\n\nShe told the BBC she had \"significant concerns\" about self-identification for transgender people in Scotland and said she was unlikely to launch a legal challenge against the UK Government for its use of a Section 35 order.\n\nThe Court of Session ultimately did rule the UK Government could block Scotland's gender reforms from becoming law.\n\nForbes previously said: \"I have been on record saying I had significant concerns and therefore the bill in its current form I would have struggled to vote for.\n\nREAD MORE: Edinburgh: Three arrests as pro-Palestine protesters blockade Leonardo factory\n\n\"I would not have been able to vote for the principle of self-ID.\"\n\nHowever, she added that she \"understands the principle which is that the UK Government should not overturn Scottish legislation\".\n\nAfter John Swinney (below) was officially sworn in as Scotland's seventh First Minister, the Greens called on him to reaffirm his support for a \"fairer, greener, more equal Scotland\".\n\nThe party's co-leader Patrick Harvie said: \"There will be many people across our country who will be very concerned and who will want to know that this Scottish Government remains committed to a greener and more equal future for Scotland.\n\n\"When it comes to delivering fairer and more progressive taxation, a just transition from oil and gas and a watertight ban on so-called conversion therapy, it is vital that this government does not dilute the longstanding commitments that it has made.\n\n\"These are the values that the Scottish Greens remain committed to and that we will work for every day. The Scotland that we want to build is one where everyone is free to be themselves and where climate action is at the forefront of our politics.\n\n\"The First Minister must lay out his programme and his vision for Scotland, and where these values lie within it.\"", "source": {"uri": "thenational.scot", "dataType": "news", "title": "The National"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8115712354", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "14:07:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T14:07:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T14:07:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3960784375667572, "url": "https://www.wired-gov.net/wg/news.nsf/articles/Humza%2BYousaf%2Bsteps%2Bdown%2Bas%2BFirst%2BMinister%2B07052024150500?open", "title": "Humza Yousaf steps down as First Minister | Scottish Government", "body": "First Minister tenders resignation to King Charles.\n\nHumza Yousaf, the youngest and first person of colour to hold the office of Scotland's First Minister has formally stepped down. At his time of appointment, he was the first Muslim leader of any Western nation.\n\nFollowing the First Minister's election in March last year, he announced his intention to stand down last week, remaining in post until a new First Minister was appointed.\n\nMr Yousaf officially tendered his resignation in writing today to His Majesty King Charles III which has been accepted and the Scottish Parliament notified.\n\nHumza Yousaf said:\n\n\"Being the First Minister of the country I love, the country I am raising my family in, and the only country I will ever call home has been a phenomenal honour.\n\n\"As a young Muslim boy, born and raised in Scotland, I could never have dreamt that one day I would have the privilege of leading my country - people who looked like me, were not in positions of political influence, let alone leading governments when I was younger.\n\n\"I am proud to have delivered a council tax freeze for households in every local authority in Scotland, invested record amounts in our National Health Service, removed peak fares on our railways, and approved plans for Europe's largest floating offshore windfarm. And through our actions, an estimated 100,000 children are expected to be kept out of poverty this year.\n\n\"From the backbenches of the Scottish Parliament, I will continue to champion the rights and the voices of those who are often not heard, be they at home or abroad.\"\n\nFirst Minister Humza Yousaf's letter to His Majesty King Charles III:\n\nYour Majesty,\n\nWith my humble duty, I write as anticipated in my letter to Your Majesty of 29 April to tender to Your Majesty my resignation from the office of First Minister. I propose that my resignation take effect from the start of Scottish parliamentary plenary business on Tuesday 7 May 2024.\n\nThroughout my time as First Minister, I have been most grateful for your counsel and the kindness you have shown to both Nadia and I.\n\nIt has been my pleasure to serve Your Majesty and the people of Scotland since March 2023.\n\nFirst Minister to stand down - gov.scot (www.gov.scot)\n\nHumza Yousaf has held a number of ministerial positions in the Scottish Government since 2012, and joined the Cabinet in June 2018 as Cabinet Secretary for Justice.\n\nHe was then appointed as Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Care in May 2021.\n\nHe officially took up the post of First Minister of Scotland on 29 March 2023 when he was sworn in at the Court of Session.\n\nModelling published in February 2024 estimates that Scottish Government's policies will keep 100,000 children out of relative poverty in 2024-25, with relative poverty levels 10 percentage points lower than they would have otherwise been. {"uri": "8115639870", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "13:22:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T13:22:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T13:21:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3882353007793427, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/news/24303589.humza-yousaf-praised-ditching-pantomime-tradition-king-letter/", "title": "Humza Yousaf praised for ignoring 'pantomime' tradition in letter to King", "body": "CAMPAIGNERS have called for the \"ludicrous\" requirement for MSPs to declare service to the monarchy to be ditched after Humza Yousaf broke with tradition in his resignation letter to the King.\n\nAs he quit as first minister, Yousaf said in a letter to King Charles that \"with my humble duty\" he was writing to resign from office.\n\nHe added it \"has been my pleasure to serve Your Majesty\" but notably Yousaf - who is a republican - did not repeat his predecessor Nicola Sturgeon's words, as she wrote: \"I have the honour to be, Sir, Your Majesty's humble and obedient servant.\"\n\nAccording to Debrett's, a London-based etiquette coaching company, the first line of a letter to the King should begin with the phrase \"with my humble duty\" but it should also end with: \"I have the honour to remain, Sir, Your Majesty's most humble and obedient servant\".\n\nREAD MORE: Former Tory minister introduces Rachel Reeves for economy speech\n\nCEO of anti-monarchy Republic, Graham Smith, said he hoped John Swinney - who looks likely to be elected first minister on Tuesday - would take note of Yousaf's \"small step\" towards ditching the \"arcane\" language MSPs are required to use towards the monarchy when they are elected.\n\nAfter an election, MSPs are sworn in by taking an oath or affirmation with the oath being \"I swear by Almighty God that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to His Majesty King Charles, his heirs and successors, according to law. So help me God\".\n\nSwinney has previously said he would prefer to keep the monarchy in the event of Scottish independence.\n\nAsked what he thought of Yousaf toning down the language of Sturgeon's letter, Smith told The National: \"First ministers, like all politicians, should see themselves as servants of the people, not of an unelected monarch who represents no one but himself.\n\n\"Let's hope [John] Swinney and others take note of this small step toward ditching this arcane language that is offensive to all our democratic values.\"\n\nCampaigners branded Sturgeon's letter \"deeply disturbing\" last year with Scottish anti-monarchy group Our Republic calling out the \"bizarre an anachronistic ritual that paints the head of Scotland's Government as no more than a servant of the King\".\n\nTristan Gray, convener of Our Republic, said MSPs should be able to choose who to declare their loyalty to, adding that Yousaf's letter still showed he had to tread a \"bizarre middle-ground\" as a republican.\n\nREAD MORE: Downing Street issues statement on UK university Gaza encampments\n\nHe said: \"After the 2021 election many MSPs took the opportunity to protest the ludicrous, archaic, and anti-democratic requirement to declare their service to the monarchy before taking their seats as representatives in the Scottish Parliament.\n\n\"Nicola Sturgeon was one who did so, on behalf of her party, declaring her loyalty first to the Scottish people.\n\n\"For her [Sturgeon's] resignation to have included a dedication as an 'obedient servant; to the King was a shock, and cast doubt on the value of that earlier protest.\n\n\"Humza Yousaf, by contrast, has stayed true to this bizarre middle-ground our political representatives have been forced to tread. Both in doing their actual elected jobs as representing the people who elected them - and playing this pantomime act of subservience to a monarchy we now know, from polling this week, that Scots don't even want.\n\n\"It's long past time we put this charade behind us, and I hope we see the Scottish Parliament make a request to Westminster that the Scotland Act be amended so that Scottish Politicians can choose who they declare their loyalty to - and let the Scottish public judge them on that.\"\n\nGray added he hoped Swinney would \"bear in mind\" his view of keeping the monarchy \"is not the position held by most of his supporters or most Scots\" in his own language should he take up the position of first minister.", "source": {"uri": "thenational.scot", "dataType": "news", "title": "The
