{"uri": "2024-05-347977238", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:08:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:08:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:03:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3411764800548553, "url": "https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/his-downfall-was-self-inflicted-but-humza-yousafs-departure-showed-grace-4619444", "title": "His downfall was self-inflicted. But Humza Yousaf's departure showed grace", "body": "An emotional Mr Yousaf addressed MSPs for the last time from Holyrood's front bench\n\nHumza Yousaf said he had promised his 15-year-old stepdaughter, Maya, that he would not \"embarrass her again\" by crying on national television. He lasted almost six minutes before breaking that pledge.\n\nSpeaking from Holyrood's front bench for the final time, the departing First Minister was overcome with emotion as he spoke of the racism he had battled from a young age, and the direction his life had taken in the years since. He was first told to \"go home\" at the age of six, he said. Back then, he could never have imagined one day leading his country.\n\nIt was a powerful moment. As both the youngest person to take on the job and the first person of colour to be First Minister of Scotland, Mr Yousaf's place in history is secure. His portrait hangs on the wall of Bute House in Edinburgh's Charlotte Square beside that of his predecessor, Nicola Sturgeon - the first woman to hold the role.\n\nBut there is little doubt Mr Yousaf will also leave office with a lasting sense of regret. His decision to end the power-sharing deal between the SNP and the Greens was a monumental misjudgement. That, too, will be remembered.\n\nHe was dealt an extraordinarily difficult hand. Within days of Mr Yousaf being elected SNP leader last year, the police investigation into his party exploded into the headlines. The manner of his downfall, however, was entirely self-inflicted.\n\nNevertheless, Mr Yousaf has handled recent days with grace. Addressing MSPs, he said he would remember the \"kindness and generosity of colleagues over the years\". Elsewhere, he issued another passionate plea on behalf of the people of Gaza - an issue close to his heart.\n\nBut it was his comments about defying the racists and bigots that stood out. \"I was six years old when I was first told to go home, and I'm afraid since then it's been a regular occurrence,\" he said. \"In fact, almost daily if you look at my social media feeds.\n\n\"I won't lie, presiding officer, it is that racial slur that probably hurts me the most, very simply because I have no other home than this one. I never will, I never have. My heart will forever belong to Scotland.\n\n\"So to have the opportunity to defy the far-right, to defy the racists, to defy the bigots who told me to go home, but be in a position to serve my home, to contribute to public life in my home, and to have had the opportunity to lead my home - well, that has been the most tremendous honour that I didn't think was reserved for people who look like me.\"\n\nVisibly emotional, Mr Yousaf added: \"And there, I have broken my promise to my 15-year-old daughter. I hope that from my example, other little boys and girls who look or sound different know that it is our differences which make us unique, that should be celebrated as part of a modern and diverse Scotland, and that in no way should those differences ever hold you back from achieving your dreams.\"", "source": {"uri": "scotsman.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Scotsman"}, "authors": final speech as FM", "body": "HUMZA Yousaf shed tears as he gave his final speech as first minister as he lamented the \"daily\" racism he has had to endure his whole life.\n\nIn a speech to the chamber, Yousaf said it had been the \"greatest privilege\" of his life to serve his country in government and as first minister and became emotional when he looked back on being handed the opportunity after being told to \"go home\" most days since he was six years old.\n\nHe said it was the racial slur that hurt him the most as he added \"my heart will forever belong to Scotland\".\n\nYousaf added being first minister was a \"tremendous honour\" he didn't think was reserved for people \"who looked like him\".\n\nYousaf said: \"I've had the greatest privilege of my life serving my country in government for almost 12 years, as minister for external affairs and international development, minister for transport, cabinet secretary for justice, cabinet secretary for health and social care and of course most recently as first minister.\n\nREAD MORE: SNP call for halt to UK arms sales to Israel amid Rafah offensive\n\n\"So my thanks must go to the people who gave me that opportunity by electing me to this place, the good people of Glasgow in 2011 and the fine people of Glasgow Pollok since 2016 who have continued to put their trust in me to stand up for them and to serve them.\n\n\"And also to my predecessors as first minister for giving this boy opportunities he could only have imagined in his wildest dreams.\n\n\"I'm grateful for the trust that you put in me over the years, because you see presiding officer a young Humza Yousaf could never have imagined that he would be able to lead this country.\n\n\"I was six years old when I was first told to go home, and I'm afraid since then it has been a regular occurrence, in fact almost daily if you look at my social media feeds and I won't lie presiding officer, it is that racial slur that probably hurts me the most, very simply because I have no other home than this one.\n\n\"My heart will forever belong to Scotland.\"\n\nYousaf also used his speech to make another plea for a ceasefire in Gaza after Israeli forces established \"operational control\" over the Gaza side of the Rafah crossing.\n\nIt comes after \"targeted strikes\" were carried out on eastern Rafah with an Israeli army official saying the vast majority of people located in the evacuation zone have left.\n\nYousaf said: \"I cannot let today's remarks go by without pleading one last time from the frontbenches for the international community to stop any further massacre of the innocent people of Gaza.\n\nREAD MORE: One-year-old killed by 'single gunshot to head' in Gaza\n\n\"A full-scale invasion of Rafah, home to 1.4 million people, 600,000 children, will only result in the slaughter of more innocent civilians in what is likely to be one of the clearest violations of international law to date.\n\n\"A clear signal must be sent to the Israeli Government that to defy the international community in this way will come with significant consequence and sanction.\n\n\"Everything possible must be done to demand an immediate ceasefire, a release of all the hostages and an end to arms sales to Israel. We must be on the right side of history and that must mean standing with innocent men, women and children. {"eng-9546218": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119849890", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "22:04:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T22:04:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T22:04:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/12652705/john-swinney-slammed-snp-teacher-promise/", "title": "John Swinney under fire for refusing to confirm 3,500 more teachers by 2026", "body": "JOHN Swinney has been slammed for repeatedly refusing to say he'd honour a flagship SNP pledge to recruit 3,500 more teachers by 2026.\n\nThe new First Minister was put on the spot about the Scottish Parliament election manifesto pledge at his inaugural FMQs on Thursday after taking over from Humza Yousaf.\n\nIn response to a question from Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross - who asked him whether he'd stick to the vow - Mr Swinney said: \"I have to answer directly, Mr Ross's question, about the challenges we face in the public finances, due to the pressures of inflation, and the persistence of austerity that is framing public expenditure from the United Kingdom government.\n\n\"But I assure Mr Ross, and parents most importantly in the city of Glasgow and around the country, of the government's commitment to sustained investment in education to maximise the investment we can make available.\"\n\nWe told this week how the new First Minister faced fury from parents and demands to step in to reverse teacher cuts in Scotland's largest city, where the SNP-led council is set to axe 450 classroom posts.\n\nIt comes despite the SNP's 2021 manifesto pledge to \"recruit 3500 additional teachers and classroom assistants, allowing teachers more time out of the classroom to prepare lessons and improve their skills\".\n\nAnd at FMQs, Mr Swinney - who this week vowed to turn over a new leaf after becoming known for his aggressive heckling in the Holyrood chamber - refused a further three times to give a Yes/No answer.\n\nMr Ross said: \"We were supposed to have a 'different style of politics', but it sounds like the excuses are the same as we've had before.\"\n\nIn his responses, Mr Swinney repeatedly said he wanted to be \"clear\" with parents but pointed to the \"effect of austerity\" and \"a rampant increase in inflation on the watch of the Conservatives\". He added: \"We will set out our commitments as we take Budget decisions.\n\nPushed for a Yes/No answer by Mr Ross, the First Minister said: \"I've nothing really to add to Douglas Ross about the financial position we face.\"\n\nHowever, Mr Ross accused Mr Swinney of \"not being straight with the public\".\n\nWe told how parents took to the streets of Glasgow in protest at the SNP-led council's decision to axe 450 classroom posts.\n\nAnd campaigners raised fears over similar losses across Scotland as they urged the First Minister to step in and reverse the slashing of numbers.\n\nScottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar, who spoke with some of those who gathered in the city's George Square on Wednesday, said: \"Of the teachers I met, one told me they had re-trained two years ago and was now going to lose her job.\n\n\"Another hasn't been able to get a permanent contract since he qualified, and a third said this doesn't feel like the thanks and reward the Government promised them coming out of the pandemic.\n\n\"John Swinney bears responsibility for the broken finances in our councils and the decimation of our education system.\"\n\nAnd speaking after FMQs, Tory chief Mr Ross said: \"John Swinney's repeated failure to stand by the pre-election pledge he made as education secretary to increase teacher numbers will have been heard loud and clear across Scotland.\"\n\nAt a post-FMQs media briefing, a spokesman for the First Minister said Mr Swinney had shown \"complete candour\" about the financial pressures faced by the government.\n\nBut when pressed by The Scottish Sun on why the First Minister refused to give a straight Yes or No answer about whether the pledge will still be delivered, the spokesman said: \"He gave a commitment that he wanted to look very carefully at this and he wanted to engage with local authorities, and indeed, with parents and others.\"\n\nMr Swinney's inaugural FMQs in the top job came just days after he was officially confirmed as the new SNP leader and First Minister following the resignation of Humza Yousaf.\n\nIn a speech accepting the leadership of the SNP this week - having stood unopposed for the job - Mr Swinney vowed to adopt a different approach to politics and suggested nothing would be achieved by \"shouting at people\".\n\nAnd before FMQs, new Deputy First Minister Kate Forbes heaped praise on Mr Swinney, saying he had been \"truly inspiring\" over the past week.\n\nMr Swinney - Nicola Sturgeon's No2 during her entire tenure as First Minister - revealed a \"new\" cabinet with only one change, bringing in Ms Forbes as Deputy First Minister. But all of Humza Yousaf's top team stayed in place.\n\nAs she walked to the Holyrood chamber for FMQs, the Scottish Sun asked Ms Forbes about her waspish comments during the 2023 SNP leadership race in the wake of Ms Sturgeon's resignation that \"continuity won't cut it\", and how that squared with the virtually unchanged regime.\n\nShe said: \"Well, I was very clear in my statement last week about why I wasn't going to run.\n\n\"I had huge confidence in the agenda that John Swinney had set out about uniting the party and the country and ensuring that we work together to deliver on the priorities of the people of Scotland.\n\n\"That remains my position, and I think he has been truly inspiring in the speeches that he's given over the last week, doubling down on his commitments to unify, to deliver and to ultimately make sure that as a government we are delivering for people.\"", "source": {"uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Scottish Sun"},
